If there were other issues that were brought in, the fact that this debate has developed into such a wide ranging one would allow that course of action.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDIVIENT
text: The Prime Minister tried to rely on the fact that this was not a public company. He tried to use a dictionary definition that a public company was one which offered shares to the public. But this is the Prime Minister, a lawyer by training and a man primarily responsible for all Commonwealth law. The law over which he presides makes it clear that a company limited by guarantee is a public company. The point I am making is that he tried to weasel his way out through a dictionary definition because he knew he was caught by his own code of conduct. The mere fact that the company does not trade in shares is immaterial. The Prime Minister's other desperate argument in relation to the centre was that it was a not for profit company and that he was really not involved in the running of the company. That is also spurious because, in the case of the Commonwealth of Australia v. Friedrich, the court found there was nothing in company law to suggest that the standard expected of a part-time non-executive director of a company not for profit was different from the standard expected of any director of a profit making company. Despite the semantic gymnastics of the Prime Minister, the case against him is clear. He did not resign the directorship of the Menzies Research Centre when he became Prime Minister, and he should have. How can the Australian public have any faith in a man who flagrantly breaches his own guidelines on integrity and honesty? I was very interested in the dictionary defence in relation to this matter. He did not use the dictionary in relation to 'never ever'. Mr Miles- Mr Deputy Speaker, I again raise the point of order in respect of relevance. This is very repetitious. I am not sure how many times I have heard this; it is probably 30 or 40 times now. I do not believe it is relevant to this legislation and I would ask that you draw him back to the debate which is in hand.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDIVIENT
text: The honourable member for Hotham is relating his comments to schedule 5. Perhaps he is overly dwelling on the matters that led up to the decision to create this schedule 5 element but I am sure that, in his concluding few minutes, he will make sure that he is relevant to the bill.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDIVIENT
text: The relevance is this: we are debating in this parliament a bill to give deductibili ty. We are not against the deductibility, but the process that led to it: a Prime Minister-a director of a companymaking a decision in a cabinet to benefit that company. So we have a piece of legislation before the parliament that, in the process of coming here, involved a breach of the Prime Minister's own code of conduct. The point I am making is that it is a conflict of interest. The Prime Minister tried to argue in defence that it was not a conflict of interest because this was not a company. But in saying it wasn't a company, he relied on a shonky dictionary definition. When we asked him in the parliament what the dictionary definition of 'never ever' was, he said 'not for three years' . If you look at the same dictionary that he relied upon, you will see that the definition of 'never ever' says: At no time. On no occasion. Not ever. As an negative. Not at all. He also redefined the definition of 'regular' when he said the cabinet would have regular regional cabinet meetings. They have had them three times in two years. He redefined the word 'soon' when he said, 'I'm going to Newcastle soon.' Remember when they closed the Newcastle steelworks? 'Soon' means 'not before I've been to the second test at Lords' . He also redefined the word 'immediate' when he said that they would introduce the car tariff legislation immediately. Twelve months on, we still do not have a bill. He redefined the dictionary definition of 'continued funding' when he said that he would continue regional development funding, but then cut the funds and abolished the department. He also redefined the word 'preference'-'to like better', 'to promote or advance a thing preferred', 'giving or receiving a favour'

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDIVIENT
text: Order! The honourable member for Hotham should go back to the processes rather than the definitions.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDIVIENT
text: I will do that; I just have to finish this point on 'preference'. What is his new definition of 'preference'? 'We don't like One Nation, but we will put them ahead of Labor.' This is a Prime Minister who has lost trust. This is a Prime Minister who has breached his covenant. If, in fact, he is going to give tax deductibility to the Menzies Research Centre out of this program, maybe one of the first tasks he should give it is to rewrite the Concise Oxford Dictionary because he has redefined it in this place. If the Menzies Research Centre is to continue to receive the benefits from this-which we do not oppose-we want to know why the Prime Minister did not fess up; why the Prime Minister has broken his covenant with the Australian public; why the Prime Minister has continued to be deceitful; why the Prime Minister has twisted the truth; and why the Prime Minister has changed definitions. That is what we want to know, and we want to know the true circumstances that led to this bill coming before the House. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDIVIENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) emphatic (10.17 a.m.)-The Australian public are getting used to the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) griping, whingeing and whining. It happens in question time where they see the aggressive antics of the member for Hotham, and we have heard it again-just taking up the time of parliament and wasting time. As I said, I have probably heard what he said 30 or 40 times. This is not a constructive way of continuing debate about important legislation like the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998. I want to rebut a couple of things he said, since the debate has been allowed to continue in that way. The honourable member for Hotham is well known throughout Australia for his R&D syndicates-where billions of dollars were being used. He was looking after his rich mates. He is accusing the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in regard to the Menzies Centre. The implication is that somehow the Prime Minister was going to get some financial benefit. There are no tradeable shares in that company. Yet the member for Hotham protected his rich mates in regard to R&D syndicates in this country, which was costing other taxpayers billions of dollars. It is the height of hypocrisy for the member for Hotham to come in here and waste time;, split hairs and be so pharisaical in his approach over the issue of the Menzies Centre. It is very interesting that we are giving tax deductibility to the Menzies Centre in exactly the same way as there is tax deductibility for the Evatt Foundation. In other words, the Labor side of politics-the Evatt Foundation-is getting the same tax deductibility. What do we know about the history of this? Who gave that tax deductibility? It was given by the now Prime Minister back in 1981 when he was Treasurer. He granted tax deductibility status by way of legislation in exactly the same way as tax deductibility is being prqvided for the Menzies Centre. We have heaM 20 minutes of nonsense from the member for Hotham, but that is not new. I guess we are going to hear a lot more nonsense from the member for Hotham who likes wasting the time of the parliament on some of these matters. There is no doubt that this country, in electing John Howard to the position of Prime Minister, elected a person who is very straightforward and honest. He is a man of integrity and he can be trusted. His commitment to the Australian people is very clear. There is no doubt that the Australian people know of the decency and honesty of John Howard. They have seen that over the 20-odd years or more that he has been in this parliament, and they will continue to see it. I rebut entirely everything the member for Hotham has said in that regard. As somebody who works very closely with him, I see him as one of the most decent, honest people in this country. Certainly compared with some of the people represented on the other side of politics, he stands out. This bill covers a large number of measures. Firstly, it delivers further on the government's commitment to reduce compliance costs for small business hy implementing the fringe benefits tax record keeping exemption in response to a recommendation by the Bell task force. Other FBT reforms designed to reduce compliance costs for small business are contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.6) 1997, which is awaiting debate in the Senate. These measures include an FBT exemption for employee taxi travel to cover travel to and from work at any time of the day, an FBT exemption from 1 July 1997 for car parking on small business premises, and simplification of the range of provisions. The small business recording keeping exemptions may benefit up to half of the small businesses in Australia paying FBT and will come at a cost of $70 million over four years. The record keeping exemption targets those employers whose fringe benefits tax does not exceed an indexed threshold amount and who do not significantly alter the fringe benefits provided in later years. Eligible employers will not be required to keep fringe benefit records and will have their FBT liability in future years determined from base year taxable benefits. The benefit threshold for the 1996-97 FBT year is $5,000. The measure applies to benefits provided from the date of royal assent and to FBT liabilities from the 1998-99 year. Secondly, the bill implements a number of important 1997-98 budget measures. The first is part of a package of measures relating to preventing franking credit trading and dividend streaming. This bill introduces a rule to limit the source of franking credits available for franking credit trading. The Senate recently passed Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1998 which contains the general antiavoidance rules. The second budget measure relates to depreciation of plant previously owned by exempt entities. The bill sets a common base for the depreciation deductions for plant that can be claimed by exempt entities which become taxable and by taxable entities which purchase plant from an exempt entity in connection with the acquisition of a business. The measure is designed to align the treatment of asset sales with the treatment of sales of shares in the entity. The third measure amends the tax law to prevent taxpayers obtaining deductions for capital expenditure in excess of their actual outlays. Where the expenditure has been financed by hire purchase or limited recourse finance, an associated amendment will treat taxpayers who finance assets by hire purchase as the owners of those assets for purposes of applying the various capital allowance deductions. In addition, the bill amends the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 to rectify defects in the current law, thereby ensuring that sales tax exemption for goods incorporated into properties owned by or leased to always exempt persons or the government of a foreign country is only available for the purchase of goods principally for their own usc or for use by organisations conducting the business of always exempt persons or the government of a foreign country. This measure applies to any dealing from the date of the introduction of the bill into parliament. The bill also demonstrates the government's commitment to dealing promptly with technical areas which occur in the rewrite of the Income Assessment Tax 1936 by the tax law improvement project. The bill also amends the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to include the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission within the definition of a law enforcement agency for the purpose of obtaining access to taxation information. I want to make a fcw brief points about some comments made during the debate. The member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) made commcnts regarding the amendments to the sales tax law and the erosion of the PAYE base. In relation to his comments on the sales tax, the amendments apply to dealings on or after 2 April 1998-the date the bill was introduced into the House. The measure is not retrospective. Where a contract has been entered into on the basis of that, sales tax exemption will apply. Section 128 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 allows the contract price to be altered as a result of a change to the sales tax law which directly causes an increase in the cost of the party complying with the contract. As the member for Wills should know, increases in sales are generally applied from the date of announcement. The other point I would make is that, following the introduction of the bill into the parliament, advertisements were placed in the national papers advising of the proposed change. The advertisements made clear that the sales tax does not need to be remitted to the tax office until 28 days after the bill receives royal assent. The member for Wills also made comments about leakage from the PA YE tax system. Despite its apparent concern about this issue, Labor had not passed its legislation to amend the PAYE laws before it was thrown from office on 2 March 1996, and Labor never issued the promised discussion paper, although the budget documents of May 1995 said the paper would be issued 'shortly'. If we are going to have the member for Hotham in here debating definitions, the word 'shortly', in regard to the previous Labor the government, ought to be clearly addressed. I suspect that this splitting of hairs does not get the country any further ahead and I suggest to the opposition that the best way to proceed in the future might be to ignore these silly nitpicking debates. Let me reassure you that the government believes that all taxpayers should pay their fair share of tax. However, small businesses were highly critical of Labor's proposed changes to the PAYE provisions. We received representations that the proposed changes would in some circumstances have brought payments to independent contractors within the PAYE provisions. In response to those representations, the government decided not to proceed with the legislative changes introduced into the parliament by Labor. However, the Commissioner of Taxation is continuing to take steps to safeguard the operation of the law and, in relation to alienation of personal services income, we have asked the commissioner to ensure he continues to apply existing provisions including the anti-avoidance provisions of part IV A to ensure that taxpayers do not avoid paying tax on personal services income through the use of interposed entities. To this end the tax office is currently conducting compliance projects that are dealing with personal service incom--t-e P AYE enhancement project and the ahenatIOn of personal services income project. The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) made a number of comments about schedule 13 that is, limiting the source of franking creditavailable for t-ading. In particular, ed that there IS an anomaly in the provisions because whereas minority non-resident shareholders in companies effectively wholly owned by the non-residents can benefit from the. franking credits of the company, minority resIdent shareholders cannot, and the government has not provided revenue figures for the measure. In regard to the alleged anomaly, it is not anomalous to allow minority non-resident shar-hol.ders to gain the benefit from franking credIts m the form of an exemption from divid-nd withholding tax while denying frankmg rebates to resident minority shareholders. This is a necessary consequence of the provisions if they are to be effective in preventing such companies selling off their franking credits to franking credit buyers. That is the very mischief the measure is designed to prevent. In regard to revenue, while it is not possible to provide an exact estimate of the revenue lost that already existed from franking credit trading and dividend streaming, $130 million a year is now being factored into the forward estimates for 1998-99 and subsequent years to take account of the effect of the measures on existing activities. This revenue effect will be reflected in the explanatory memorandum for Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.5) introducing the 45-day rule. I commend the legislation to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Third Reading Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith. Bill (on motion by Mr Miles) read a third time. NA SERVICES (DIGITAL CONVERSION) BILL 1998 Cognate bill: NA (IMPOSITION) BILL 1998 Second Reading Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by he suggest- Mr Warwick Smith: That the biJI be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The legislation which is currently before the House-the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998-is currently being considered by a Senate committee. The Senate committee is not expected to report until, I think, 22 June. It becomes rather difficult for the House of Representatives to consider these matters when the public inquiry which is being conducted by the Senate and the report which is expected from that Senate committee are not in the public domain. But that is perhaps typical of the process by which the government has pursued this particular legislation. I will say a bit more about that later. I begin by saying that, just as the last parliament and this parliament spent a lot of time working out the right series of measures that needed to be put into the Telecommunications Act to open up the telecommunications market to full and open competition, !here is a. similar number of very complex Issues which need to be dealt with in considering the transition from analog to digital broadcasting in Australia. In telecommunications there were a whole series of issues that placed many of the different stakeholders at each other's throats; a whole series of issues that needed to be weighed up. Many decisions had to be made, each one of which determined the final impact of telecommunications on the Australian public for many years to come. In the same way in broadcasting, this legislation deals with many complex issues; issues on which a considered judgment needs to be made about what is in the public interest. In some ways, I am reminded of a book that I read over the Christmas break called Longitude. It portrays the history of the development of accurate chronometers that allowed sailors to determine their longitude so that they did not hit hidden reefs and allowed them to accurately plot their position on the globe. Actually, a competition was established by an act of the British parliament to encourage timepiece makers to develop accurate chronometers. The chronometers ended up being massive machines which had many different working parts and many different springs and metal objects to try to ensure that, whatever the changes in temperature, however rough the sea, they maintained their time. In some ways it is the same in broadcasting. With this legislation we have the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) weighing up the many compromises and decisions that need to be made to try to ensure that, when we look at the future of broadcasting in Australia, we protect the public interest. Despite the views of many of my constituents, I think we currently do have reasonably good quality television in Australia. I am reminded of that old comment by Winston Churchill that democracy is the worse way to run a government, except for all the alternatives. In some ways in Australia our television, despite its faults, is perhaps one of worse, except for all the alternative forms of television which are available in every other country. In Australia we do have a very healthy mix of national broadcasters and commercial broadcasters. When we make a comparison with Britain and Europe, we see that they do tend to have a much stronger public system and often a much weaker commercial broadcasting sector. Whereas, in the United States there is-as is the case in so many other areas, such as health-a minuscule public broadcasting system and a very strong, dominant commercial broadcasting sector. I think that our healthy combination of public broadcasting and commercial broadcasting, with a dash of community broadcasting on top, means that we do tend to get some of the best of the programming that is available in other countries. But we have also seen over the last 20 to 25 years-since the Whitlam government years-a healthy increase in the level of quality Australian content on television. We have local content quotas which ensure that we have quality Australian material, particularly drama, on our TV screens at prime time. I am pleased to say that not only docs it get high ratings in Australia but also it is earning export dollars for Australia in export sales to other countries. We are recognised around the world for producing some of the best quality children's television programs. It is often not shown at prime time, but we do have many children who know when quality children's programming is put to air. I am sure that the recognition Australia receives around the world is testament to another policy success in getting that balance between ensuring that commercial broadcasting is profitable in Australia but that commercial broadcasters have certain obligations to the public. They get to use the spectrum, they get to operate as free to air broadcasters, they get a piece of paper with a television broadcasting licence which allows them to make a lot of money out of free to air broadcasting. In return, the Australian public, through the Australian Broadcasting Authority, puts the obligations on them to make sure that they meet minimum Australian content rules, that they have a certain amount of new Australian drama, new children's television and new documentaries going to air each year. That is part of the balance. There is a very complex machine that is Australian television, that compromise between how many public broadcasters, how many community broadcasters, how many commercial broadcasters to have in each capital city market. You look at the profitability of the commercial broadcasters. What are the public obligations you place on them. What is the competition for advertising revenue between commercial television, radio, newspapers and magazines. All of these things comprise a very complex machine. We have to make sure that we get the balance right, otherwise we could end up with a television broadcasting system that does not deliver the level of quality we have today. If we make the wrong decisions on digital television, we could end up with a broadcasting regime that does not allow us to maintain the current standards of broadcasting in Australia. With those preliminary comments, I tum to the legislation. I would like to briefly remind the House of why I think we have this piece of legislation before us today. This is a piece of legislation which the government is already on record as saying that it is determined to see rammed through the parliament before the end of the next two sitting weeks. We all suspect that there might be an election called before the parliament resumes in August. I think it will be very unfortunate if the parliament does not get sufficient time to consider the implications of this bill because of the government's election timetable. Why is the government trying to ram this legislation through in the next two weeks? Let me remind the House that when the current broadcasting bill was before the parliament, I think way back in 1991 and 1992, the Minister for Family Services, the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith), introduced a second reading amendment to this particular legislation. In those days he was the coalition spokesman on communications. He was responsible for an amendment moved to the broadcasting bill in the Senate which required the then Labor government to conduct an inquiry into whether or not it was in the public interest to have a fourth commercial television network in Australia. When I had the honour of being Minister for Communications and the Arts, we tossed around whether to have another commercial network, an open university channel, a channel which provided for community broadcasters in each of the capital cities and regional areas or a family channel. There were a number of people in the Labor Party who were pushing very strongly for a channel perhaps similar to some of the specialised channels on some of the pay TV networks where parents could be assured that there would be less violence and, if there were news services, that they would not have as much graphic footage about disturbing images. Mr Hardgrave-About parliament.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: About parliament perhaps on certain days. Certainly there was a view that in those days on the coalition side we needed to look at the possibility of extra competition in commercial television broadcasting. Having moved this amendment way back in 1991, it was in the legislation that this inquiry be conducted before 30 June 1996 or 1997. During the period that this government has been in office it has stopped an inquiry. The Australian Broadcasting Authority had a reference from the former Labor government to conduct an inquiry into whether or not there should be a fourth commercial television network. The Liberal Party stopped that inquiry. They have taken no action whatsoever to look at whether or not it is in the public interest to have an open university channel, a family channel or a commercial broadcasting channel network. Accordingly, we have not had that full debate which certainly the member for Bass thought we needed a few years ago. That is a minor offence compared to the undertakings which the government gave before the last election to conduct a full public inquity into the cross-media ownership rules. Some people might ask, 'What has that got to do with digital television?' We on this side of the House believe it has everything to do with why this legislation is being rammed through the parliament before the next election by the Howard government. Before the last election, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised a full public inquiry into the crossmedia ownership rules. As soon as he was elected, the government announced that it had scrapped the need for a full public inquiry and that instead it would simply hold a private, in camera departmental review. Not surprisingly, when that review was completed the government was given the recommendation it asked for: a recommendation to water down or abolish the cross-media ownership rules. There was a public outcry at the Prime Minister's intentions to abolish the cross-media ownership rules, which would have allowed Mr Murdoch to purchase Channel 7 in addition to owning his Australian newspapers, which would have allowed Mr Packer to purchase the Fairfax newspaper group in addition to owning Channel 9, which would have allowed Channel 10 to purchase radio stations in addition to owning its television networks. It would have meant that we would have had an even greater concentration of ownership in the Australian media than we have today. I am pleased to acknowledge that a number of government backhenchers spoke out with many of us on this side of the House about the dangers posed by that greater concentration of media ownership under the Prime Minister's plans. The next speaker-and I hope I do not put a hex on him-was one of those who was reported within the Liberal Party to have spoken out strongly against the Prime Minister's changes. We acknowledge the courage of the government members who were prepared to speak out on what I consider still to be one of the most important decisions that the Howard government has made to date. Thank God the Prime Minister was rolled on that one. Having denied the media proprietors the watering down of the cross-media ownership rules, we then have digital television placed on the agenda. Instead of having the long debate that all of us believe is necessary, unfortunately we have the government commissioning reports from the Australian Broadcasting Authority-reports that we on the opposition side believe did not consider all of the issues as thoroughly as was required. It is pretty rare for the Broadcasting Authority to do this-in the past it has had a pretty good record in its work on producing reports on broadcasting-but we believe on digital television the ABA has tended to be very strongly influenced by the free to air broadcasters. I am disappointed that the government has not been prepared to ensure that there is a wider debate about many of the consequences of these issues. The Minister for Family Services, the member for Bass, who introduced the legislation, said: ... we need to ensure broadcasters have clear signposts along the road to digital television, and are able to embark along the risky conversion process with a degree of certainty about government policy. That sounds like a motherhood statement. The concern we have is that the legislation does not contain clear signposts along the road and does not give the degree of certainty that stakeholders are entitled to have. This legislation leaves the minister with enonnous powers to give directions to the Australian Broadcasting Authority to determine how digital television will be introduced. There certainly are not clear signposts; there is actually a sign which says, 'Watch this space for what the minister will do after the election.' It certainly does not allow us to reach any firm conclusions about whether the minister has set all of the levers and knobs on this complex machine to the right settings. We think that, in those circumstances, the minister cannot claim that this legislation is providing the certainty that is needed. The legislation seeks to allow digital television broadcasting to commence on 1 January 2001; it also claims that all areas will have digital coverage by 1 January 2004 and that, if any regional television broadcaster drags its feet, it wiIi be required to surrender its digital licences. One question I would like to put to the minister who sums up at the end of this debate is: is the government prepared to give a guarantee that anyone who currently receives analog television channels will receive all of the digital channels that will be broadcast? We all know that the transition from analog mobile telephony to digital mobile telephony has seen many areas where there have been holes in the coverage of digital mobile telephones, and, where the Broadcasting Authority has moved analog broadcasters from the VHF to the UHF band, there have been occasions when the broadcasting authorities have not been able to ensure that every person who used to receive a signal receives a signal from the new translator or the new antenna. So we seek some guarantee from the government that, if we are going to see a switch from analog to digital; after the year 2008, after the period of simulcast when the current analog stations shut down, anyone who currently receives the analog channel will have access to a digital channel. Mr Hardgrave-Better quality.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The member interjects and says, 'Better quality.' I seem to remember that we were promised better quality when we moved to digital mobile phones, but I am not sure we actually have delivered better quality on digital mobile phones. Mr Hardgrave-That is your fault.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: He says that is our fault. I think we have to sometimes question whether the so-called experts in these areas do know as much about what will happen as they claim, and on digital broadcasting I think we are entitled to ask whether anyone who currently receives analog television channels will be able to receive digital television channels. If there are areas where people live in valleys or in places with difficult terrain, if there are places where they will not receive digital television, who is going to meet the cost of putting in translators to make sure that they then get access? Normally in commercial television broadcasting it is up to the commercial television channels to decide whether they will spend extra money to pilt in additional translators improve their signal. If this government is going to leave it up to the Seven, Nine and Ten networks to decide how many of their viewers will get access to digital television, then I suggest that there is a danger that many of their current viewers who now get analog channels 7, 9 and 10 may not get digital 7, 9 and 10 and all of the other digital services that are coming. For the people in the gallery and the people listening, the other message the government has not told you very clearly is that you will have to purchase a new digital television which may cost quite a considerable sum of money. It is difficult at the moment to accurately estimate how much the new digital televisions will cost, but you can imagine the cost to the community when every television which now operates in Australia will not be able to pick up signals when the current analog signals cease in 2008 or later. It is quite a dramatic cost to ordinary families, and we certainly need some guarantee that the signal will work in all the current areas where people are receiving signals. As for the phase-in period, the Labor Party has indicated in-principle support for the simulcasting time line, that is, for commencing the digital broadcasting in 2001, and for the period of simulcasting to proceed at least until the year 2008. We support that panicular time line. We have indicated our in principle support for the free loan to the free to air broadcasters of a second block of seven megahertz of spectrum to allow them to simultaneously broadcast the new digital service and their old analog service. We have also indicated our in principle support for a ban on multi-channelling. This was one of the requests or demands that the free to air broadcasters put on the table during the debate. Basically it would mean that channels 7, 9 and 10 could have converted their single analog channel into five or seven different digital channels-not high-definition television, but into a number of different channels. Basically today in Australia, instead of having our three commercial broadcasters, if to we had enough - spectrum for 15 commercial broadcasters, I think very few people would think it would be fair to allocate all of those new channels to the existing broadcasters, to allow the current three networks to maintain their monopoly of the Australian television broadcasting market. Quite rightly, the government is saying that the commercial broadcasters will not be allowed to introduce multi-channelling. We are a bit quizzical about the government's decision to allow the ABC and SBS to engage in multi-channelling broadcasting. The reason I am a bit quizzical about that is that I think it will be very difficult for the government to allow public broadcasters to introduce multi-channelling but to prohibit commercial broadcasters from bringing in multi-channelling. I suspect that this might be the government deliberately allowing the free to air broadcasters to put a foot in the door for multi-channelling or, in fact, for the commercial broadcasters to see the ABC and SBS foot in the door so as to perhaps allow the commercial broadcasters to come back at some future date and seek to have multichannelling options. The debate in Australia started off in the same way as the debate in the United States. Free to air television said that this was all about delivering high definition television to Australian viewers. What they said was, 'If you give us this extra quantity of spectrum, this seven megahertz of spectrum' which, by the way, blocks out any other new competitors, 'then we will move towards high definition television that will give cinema-quality pictures to Australian viewers around the country.' In the United States, exactly the same argument was used when they went through this debate but, having received the spectrum, the US broadcasters are now saying that they have no speedy plans to introduce large quantities of high definition television broadcasting. They are into multi-channelling as much as they can. They are into making sure that they do not do what they said they would do, which was to introduce high definition TV. It is all about trying to maximise their revenue rather than delivering an improved service to their viewers. I think we have to be very sceptical about whether the government will in fact set up a regime that will deliver high definition television to Australian viewers. I suspect that the demands for multi-channelling will still be not far from the top of the list of objectives free to air broadcasters. On the restriction on new licences, we have the government saying that there will be no new commercial television licences allowed before 2008. That is one of the few specific clauses that are hard and fast and not given over to the discretion of the minister. As I say, that contrasts quite dramatically with the views of the member for Bass when he was the opposition spokesman on communications earlier this decade and was arguing for a public inquiry into whether or not we needed a fourth commercial television network. The Labor Party has said that we will be considering amendments to this period of exclusivity which goes all the way to 2008. Our final decision on that will be made clear once we have seen the outcome of that Senate inquiry. There are several other issues which we believe are worthy of consideration. They include the question of industry development. The Labor Party believes that it is important for the legislation to explicitly recognise the industry development obligations and the opportunities that will arise for Australian manufacturers and those who are involved in software development through digitalisation. We think it would be helpful for the government to require industry development plans in the same way as in telecommunications where the major carriers are required to develop plans to maximise the opportunities for Australian manufacturers and software developers. We would also like to see digital broadcasting offering new and innovative opportunities for information service providers in rural and regional areas. Many of these, we believe, are worthy of consideration. For these reasons, we have concerns about the government's attempts to ram this through in the next two weeks. We are concerned that the government has not got the settings right on all of the knobs and levers in this complex machine known as broadcasting in Australia. We believe that, unless the government gives this greater thought and consideration, then there is a risk that we will not have as high a quality Australian television as we have today. Therefore, I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to of the substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that further consideration of the Bill should be deferred, for the following reasons: (1 ) the Government has provided insufficient time and opportunity for a wide public consultation process to examine the impact of the introduction of digital broadcasting into Australia; (2) the Government has introduced this Bill with undue haste which is reflected by the fact that it was necessary to circulate substantial amendments even before the resumption of the second reading debate; (3) the Australian Broadcasting Authority provided advice that indicated that legislation could be tabled in Parliament in October 1998 providing for a digital broadcasting commencement date of 1 January 2000, and the Government has given no reasons for ignoring this advice; (4) given that the Government received the digital broadcasting report of the Australian Broadcasting Authority in July 1997 and then took over eight months to make a public announcement on its proposed framework for digital broadcasting, its claim that the legislation needs to be dealt with as a matter of urgency is disingenuous; (5) the Senate is conducting an inquiry into the legislation, and although the inquiry has been given insufficient time to report by the Government, it is likely that evidence and recommendations will emerge from that inquiry which would assist the House in giving proper consideration to the Bill; (6) the Government's legislation does not address the enormous potential that is presented for industry development in Australia through the migration into a digital broadcasting environmentopportunities will exist for Australian manufacturing and software development industries and the contribution this can make to Australian employment and export earnings should be recognised and supported in the legislation; (7) the Government's legislation does not provide sufficient recognition ture issues faced throughout regional areas, and just as digital broadcasting provides special opportunities for access to new services in rural and regional Australia, disproportionate expenditure will be required to ensure that the capacity exists for the development of appropriate infrastructure; (8) the Parliament's consideration of this Bill must place paramount importance on the interests of the broader Australian community and consumers, and given the impact that digital broadcasting will have on the delivery and reception of television and other broadband and online services, any attempt to hasten the legislative process without proper parliamentary scrutiny, public debate and discussion, could jeopardise those interests".

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Mr Jenkins)Is the amendment seconded? Mr MCMullan-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The Australian Labor Party have proved yet again that for them the information superhighway should be tom up and turned into a dirt track. The Australian Democrats have a view that is slightly different: it should not just be a dirt track; it should also be a toll road. Anyway, we will let them work that out as time goes on. I think the bottom line is that in Australia we have the very best television in the world. We have free to air terrestrial television that the rest of the world could only envy, with three commercial operators offset by a very effective public system of the ABC and SBS providing an effective range of views and access to programs. This has been supplemented in recent years by an emerging cable sector. With a strong public sector, a strong private sector and an emerging cable television sector, Australia is very well served. We have been strong adaptors of techn01ogy over the years. Television started in time for the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne and colour TV seemed to be hinged more around the Commonwealth Games of I 974-or was it the Olympics of 1976? We have seen Australians over a long period of time readily take up technology and readily accept the need to be part of what is new and what is also to their benefit as far as entertainment and information access are concerned. We for the particular infrastruchave a successful quality and quantity of Australian content. All of this comes as a result of quite deliberate action by government over the yearsdeliberate action to require the telecasters of such programs to provide Australian content through a carrot and a stick approach and also deliberate action because one of the few things that we can claim is directly underpinned from the 190 I version of the constitution is management of the spectrum. As a result, we can quite legitimately legislate in this place, and in no other place in Australia, those rules and regulations which govern the access to the spectrum, the basis on which television and telecommunications signals arc sent. Commercial channels sen access to the spectrum, which governments make it possible for them to access by licensing arrangements. As a result of those licensing arrangements, we can set and demand certain outcomes. In that regard, the bill before us today is consistent with everything that has ever been passed in broadcast or television policy since whenever. After all, we have a set of regulations and requirements and a set of outcomes that are well specified, and we have a set of deliberate actions that we want those who want to have access to digital television to meet, otherwise they will not have the access. It is important to address a couple of the matters mentioned by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), a former minister for communications in the Keating government. I think it is important for him to know that no-one on this side will allow digital television to become the technological stalking horse for the crossmedia ownership debate. I can assure you that that matter has been well addressed by the government's communications and the arts backbench policy committee. Mr Lee-What about the next term?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: We are certain that, whether it is in this term or the next term, doors are not going to be left open to allow those sorts of things to occur. In fact, quite the opposite: the doors are left open to a range of possibilities as far as the use of this technology is concerned, but there are mechanisms contained within this bill which will ensure open inquiry and accountability for the decisions which are made. We have to make sure we do get specified in this bill the outcomes we want. We have to make sure also the industry itself is given some very clear guidelines as to the timetable it needs to embark upon. I am concerned the Australian Labor Party and their cohorts in crime, in a metaphoric sense, in the Senate are very much hell-bent on the delay of this bill. They want to drag it out and drag it out for no apparent reason other than simply blatant opposition for opposition's sake. What is at stake? It is an industry in which I once worked and in which, I know, the member for Calare (Mr Andren), who will be speaking as well this morning, also worked. An industry such as this, like any industry, needs to understand where they are going, how they can invest and what they have to invest in, and what are the rules and regulations governing such investment. Queued up all around this country at the moment, from the smallest country town to the biggest city like Sydney, are television operators waiting for this bill to be passed to bring some certainty to their actions. They want to get on with the job of purchasing the equipment and getting in place the technical side of things so the new digital age can be realised. And we have the Australian Labor Party professing delay, which I think is anchored in the basis of opposition for opposition's sake. In my own electorate people in the suburbs of Wishart, Upper Mount Gravatt, Mount Gravatt, Holland Park West, Wellers Hill and Tarragindi and people up Weller Road find that they get a poor quality analog signal now. They are getting ghosting and scratching because of the physical intrusion of Mount Gravatt. To address one of the matters raised by the member for Dobell, in the digital regime the clear signal which is available close to the transmitter will be available in those sorts of scratchy areas. It is a technical fact that digital transmission is more robust than analog. The signal is resistant to electrical interference and to ghosting. Ghosting is something which happens when the signal cannot distinguish between some physical interruption and the place where it is supposed to go, so hills, buildings and so forth cause problems. Being digital, the signal cannot readily contain additional data which allows the receiver to correct errors caused by this interference. In most instances, as a result of digital transmissions, a perfect copy of the signal is transmitted. This information was given to me, I confess, by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, but if they are prepared to put this in writing, then I am prepared to relate it in the parliament. I think this in itself is a mechanism of accountability for such an organisation and for the members it represents to actually deliver on it. For those constituents of the member for Dobell, of the member for Calare-and, I think, yours as well, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl-who are on the edges of the transmission area and get a scratchy signal, digital will produce a clear signal right to the edge of the scratchiness we currently get with analog. To delay this bill longer means constituents of mine, of yours and of other members in this place will continue to experience the poor quality transmissions they are currently suffering. If the Australian Labor Party want to continue to delay the bill, this sort of problem is going to continue for a long time. They are actually threatening the gentle balance which exists in this industry, a balance which has the potential for high profits but which also returns profits into the employment of people through the creation of Australian content television productions and so forth. Delays will interrupt such an investment regime and the process of logical planning for what is to come, I think the Australian Labor Party should get out of the way so we can get on with the job we are supposed to do. Far from ramming this through, the government is recognising the need for Australia to be part of what is happening in the world. In November of this year the United States is switching on to digital television, and the Australian Labor Party are professing delays to keep Australia further behind. There is no need for it. What is the consumer going to get out of this? They are going to get higher quality pictures, CD quality sound and access, for a lot of their programming, to cinema quality broad screen pictures on their television sets. Yes, they will have to purchase new television sets, but Australians have never been afraid of buying into new technology. As more Australians purchase into this new technology, they will find the costs will continue to decline, as they have with mobile phones. For those who purchased a mobile phone very early on-and I certainly was not one of them, because I could not afford it 10 years ago-the cost was around $1,000. They are now down to $49, and I suspect the same thing will happen when it comes to digital television. At the end of the day, it is not just about television programs and the hedonistic experience of enjoying your favourite show-the member for Moore (Mr Filing) perhaps like Neighbours or similar shows; it is also about access to the information superhighway, because digital television contains within it the prospect for the television set to be accessed by computer and data content, a bit like the movie Back to the Future. People will be able to receive phone messages, access the Internet and all these sorts of things, all from the comfort of their loungeroom. Those matters are not going to be an automatic right for the current free to air carriers because the government has quite rightly said that is beyond the basic job they currently do. This bill specifies, as is the case with all these sorts of matters, clear understandings and clear obligations on the free to air channels to gain access, in a loan sense, to spectrum, provided they do the job they are supposed to do.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: It's a free gift.

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: There is no sense of giving away anything here because, after all, giving access to the spectrum for digital to operate in a simulcast with analog in the transition period of about eight years is an additional cost to those involved in television transmission, because they have two sets of transmitters to maintain. That in itself is a major undertaking for television operators in Australia: that they will meet the requirement of the government to provide certainty to those who have analog receivers only, as well as access to those who are going to get their digital receivers from day one. Over a period of time, as people start to go to their neighbours' and friends' homes and see high definition television-just as people went to their friends' homes and saw colour television for the first time-they will start to purchase these sets. As a basic consequence, people will go over to the digital regime more than analog. When they see the better quality pictures, when they hear the better quality sound and when they start to see and hear things their neighbours have got, there will be a 'keeping up with the Joneses' approach. To facilitate this process and to allow the television operators-both the public sector and the private sector-some certainty and some dignity after 40-odd years of being involved in the industry, we need to make sure there is this requirement to simulcast. Those opposite who suggest there is any sort of cosy deal misunderstand completely the way the government is going with this. In fact, the requirements are, from the commercial television stations' viewpoints, quite draconian for them. Their natural aspiration to take up multi-channelling and data casting and to expand their current business using this technology as a stalking horse to concentrate media ownership in this country even more is not going to occur, because this bill specifically states they cannot depart from what they have been doing. Channel Nine have to continue to run the programs they currently run. They run it on both analog and digital. There are some programming enhancements they are allowed to undertake. For example, in the case of a football match, if Alfie Langer scores a try in the State of Origin on Friday night-and I hope he scores about five-then you might be able to access a profile on Alfie Langer. That is an enhancement of the same basic task the channel was doing pre-digital. So those sorts of basic, straightforward rules and regulations are specified in those in the Australian Democrats who have said that we perhaps should have sold access to the spectrum to the commercial channels underwrite the ABC's costs of meeting the technical requirements, I say this: if you actually sell something to someone, moral point of view you have less of an opportunity to actually dictate to them the terms of what they do.

For these many reasons I commend the bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I have listened with interest during debate on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 to the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) and, before him, to the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). I say to the member for Moreton: let us not forget, as we are debating, the analog/digital phone decisions and how we are regretting now that we acted in haste five or six years ago, expecting the digital technology to deliver more in fact than it is actually capable of. When members of this House first debated the introduction of television back in the 1950s, there is no way they could have foreseen just how powerful and influential this new medium would become. It is fair to say that members back then probably had trouble fully coming to terms with what this exciting new technology was really all about, just as many of us are equally unsure of what digital this bi II. To TV will really mean. Never would they have imagined that some 10 years later this medium would bring war to into people's living rooms as Australians fought in Vietnam. In the same decade they would watch Neil Armstrong take that first from a step on the moon. It has taken us to royal weddings and funerals. It has changed the face of politics, making successful practitioners masters or you slaves of the 20-second news grab. It has changed the sport we play, taking cricketers out of whites and having them play under at night. It has seen us humming jingles and reciting slogans, making it a most powermedium for advertisers to the point where prime time commercial spots can be sold for many thousands of dollars. It is fair to say is such a powerful means of communication that it has been one of the greatest I impacts on the world in this century. These bills lay the foundation for the future of television in this country, at the same time By making it an even more powerful medium because they also give broadcasters the technical potential to operate multi-channel services. For the first time, viewers in the home will be able to interact with the medium. As well as being more powerful, it also has the potential to have a greater capacity for earning revenue. Data capability means we will be able to watch an advertisement and click on an icon to make an immediate purchase. Again, we cannot begin to imagine the full capability of this new medium, but it is fair to say it will in time generate even more revenue for its key players. Since the introduction of television there has been a decline in newspaper circulation and titles in Australia. It is quite possible that this newest development will see a further decline in newsprint as a means of communication and a huge expansion in on-line information services. When this House was charged with the task of deciding what to do with television back in the 1950s, the Menzies government decided it was best to keep onside the most powerful media proprietors of that era. So back then they decided to give the first licences to the existing newspaper barons. While a lot of things have changed since the 1950s, a lot of things have stayed the same. Today's politicians are still preoccupied with trying to serve the best interests of powerful media barons, especially in an election year. Mr Hockey-You used to work for them.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I know all about it then. I  broadcast, questioning the line-up of my bulletin. I say to you: it still goes on. Critics have been describing these bills as a goldmine for the existing free to air networks. Certainly any objective person who has looked at them would have to agree they certainly have that potential and at the very least will be favourable for the major networks. Just how favourable will depend on what fees the networks are eventually charged for so-called datacasting services and what other services they may be permitted to offer with the section of broadcasting spectrum being given to them. It will also depend on what other competitors are given access to the broadcast spectrum and can compete on favourable terms with the networks. The problem may well be that these bills will allow the three existing commercial networks to become so dominant in the fields of datalink broadcasting over the next decade that any real competition will have difficulty getting off the ground. These bills really set up the framework for the introduction of digital TV to allow stations to begin planning, but much of the fine print has still to be worked out by the Broadcasting Authority and the government. It is a case of 'she'll be right, mate'-and I say: remember the mobile phones. These bills have in-built flexibility to, hopefully, with a prayer, allow correct decisions to be taken in the future as the digital networks begin to take shape. This flexibility is obviously necessary if we are rushing this thing in now because the Australian government's most recent significant decisions in relation to communications planning have been disasters. The introduction of pay TV is perhaps the most relevant example. Mr niHson-That was Michael Lee.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I am talking about 'government'-previous and this. The introduction was delayed to once again appease the free to air networks. While the delay should have given government time to make the right decisions, it instead made such a mess of that industry it has lost hundreds of millions of dollars. The other completely botched communications decision relates to the introduction of GSM digital mobile phones and the ridiculous policy to phase out analog by the end of next year. Lessons should be learnt from this disastrous compulsory analog phase-out-whoever brought it in and whoever is continuing it-so it should not be repeated. With those two planning disasters behind us, I hope our communications planners will not make it three in a row and that these bills will set us on the right path for the introduction of digital television. Of course, these bills already have many critics who see them as a huge leg-up for the existing free to air networks. These critics include News Corporation, Optus and Telstra, who see the existing networks are being given a big share of the broadcast spectrum for nothing and will possibly be able to compete with their pay TV multi-channel ventures in which they have invested hundreds of millions of dollars to set up. The massive giveaway argument has been denied by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations representing the networks, which argue that the industry needs help to compensate for the huge costs involved in building digital television networks. I have read th- arguments on both sides and, as is often the case with arguments such as this, I suspect the truth lies somewhere in the middle. The cost of digital conversion is huge, particularly for the regional television industry. A typical regional broadcaster maintains about three or four studio complexes, six transmitters and up to 50 translators in each aggregated market. Compare this with a metropolitan station, which may have just one studio complex, one transmitter and a few translators to get to the same population base. Regional TV owners estimate it will cost as much as $250 million dollars to buy digital equipment for each aggregated market. Maintaining analog broadcasts during the eightyear simulcast period could cost as much as $175 million for the regional stations. One network employee told me that these estimates are extremely inaccurate and that the prices appear to be rising every day. Indeed, they are not even certain which equipment they will be buying-whether it will be the European or American format. Certainly, as far as regional broadcasters are concerned, this policy is no giveaway. For the more profitable capital city networks, 10, 9 and 7, it could be described as a very generous policy. It is true that the networks will have si ve use of broadcast linked datacasting services. They have also been given a guarantee that it will be 10 years before another free to air television channel is licensed. So there are some big wins for the networks in this but, when you weigh it up against other considerations, perhaps it can be justified. When the analog service is phased out, the broadcasters will hand back an equivalent share of the broadcasting spectrum to what they are gaining under this policy, so it can be more fairly described as a spectrum swap rather than a giveaway. Provision has also been made in the bills for the networks to be charged fees for any data services they provide--but those fee levels arc the important thing. Once again, it is not necessarily a giveaway-it depends crucially on the fee structure. There is provision in the bills for networks to be charged for data services they provide in future. Clearly under the policy there were only going to be winners and losers. The three major networks have a reasonably good business record. They are Australian owned companies and they invest heavily in Australian programming. They will be required to continue to meet Australian content rules while digital TV is introduced. Most of those complaining about the networks' so-called 'win' include Fairfax, News and Optus, all with foreign interests. Telstra is also likely to be largely foreign owned if the government succeeds with its plan to sell off the remainder. Government members-That's wrong!

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Why? What is the figure? Mr Hockey-It is well below 30 per cent.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. I used the term 'largely'-35 per cent to me is fairly large. The lO-year freeze on new entrants into the market has reportedly been criticised by the Department of the Treasury as an unnecessary restriction on services to the consumer. According to newspaper reports, the Departexclument of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance and Administration, the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism and the Office of Regulation Review have all expressed a range of concerns in relation to this policy. The central criticism appears to be that the networks are being given an unfair advantage in establishing and controlling what is expected to be the most dominant new media. The loudest critics have understandably been those other companies who would like a share of the market. I will certainly look closely at any amendments the opposition may put forward. I have noted the one that has been tabled today, one part of which I have a fair degree of interest in; I will allude to that in a moment. I support the thrust of these bills. As I said, they lay the groundwork for the existing television broadcasters to begin planning but allow the flexibility that is essential. But that flexibility and the lack of detail really do concern me. Whether it will eventually become a successful communications policy will depend on what decisions are taken down the track-and that is a worry. Decisions will need to be taken to ensure there is wide-ranging competition in the datacasting services. Already we see conflict appearing about what this policy will actually mean. The Sydney Morning Herald reported that can get. the ABC was keen to use its extra broadcast capacity to provide additional sion services, if it has the money. The dispute over what the networks will actually be abJe to provide does need to be sorted out. To say that it does allow multi-channel services to back up the argument that it is a goldmine for the networks and wi II be unfair to pay operators. If, however, a Melbourne network can argue it will provide a new service that no-one else is providing and that pay TV operators are not interested in providing-for doesn't it? example, a regional Geelong news service or, say, one for the Central Coast or the Blue Mountains from Sydney-then I would support the network's right to be able to do that. I assume this apparent vagueness over what the networks will actually be able to provide is an indication that at this stage exact rules have not yet been defined. It will be highly successful if regulations can be made to ensure multi-channel services may be offered in such a way that provides a new service to viewers in the individual station's market, rather than just another entertainment channel and source of revenue for the networks. As for the ABC being able to provide regional services-something I other residents west of the mountains would strongly support-it is already obvious ABC is going to need extra assistance from the government to just get its existing service converted to digital. If that extra assistance is not forthcoming in enough quantity, then this policy could devastate the ABC or see it unable to take advantage of the new technology. We hear the minister saying the ABC will have to rely on property sales to help meet the full cost of conversion to digital. One would seriously hope that there really is the potential within the ABC's property portfolio to raise the sort of money needed. One of my great concerns is that many regional viewers are going to find they no longer get television at all once digital is introduced. At the moment, many people in my electorate live in fringe viewing areas and sometimes their picture is not of a good quality, yet they persevere because it is the only signal they Mr Hardgrave-They will get better regional televiquality out of this.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: You get excellent quality, but it falls away the moment you get outside that edge. Digital TV, as far as I am told, has tends no fringe viewing areas. You either get a signal or you do not. It is highly likely that TV many thousands of viewers in regional Australia will find themselves without TV once the analogue transmitters are turned off. It sounds a little like the analog phone issue, A number of points need to be made about this. Firstly, the government must give concessions to regional broadcasters to allow them to establish new transmitter and translator sites when they are needed. The member for Dobell issued a challenge, I understand, to the the government to guarantee this sort of coverage for the regional areas. I argue that a subsidised satellite option should be offered to those viewers who can demonstrably show that they are going to suffer from this lack of digital coverage a la mobile phones. Secondly, the existing analog signal should not be turned off until such times as it can be guaranteed that it will not leave significant and numbers of people without any television services. Those of us who have witnessed the the delocalising and downsizing of regional television as a result of the former government's aggregation policy would sincerely hope there are no further cutbacks. Local news is really all that is left of regional television today. In most cases that runs on a very small budget, with generic stories shared around each network of little local relevance. Now even national Aussie Rules reports and promos are jammed into the local news services, allegedly as part of local news coverage. Mr Lee-Compulsory.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Compulsory. It is further dilution of localism. So if the regional operators are serious about requesting taxpayer assistance to get this signal up to benefit them, let them get more serious about local program content. I mean regional local program content. I mean current affairs. I mean coverage of council businessMr Lee-The local member!

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Coverage of the local member more often-four times a week instead of twice. I can also guarantee that, if the cost of digitalisation proves too expensive for regional broadcasters and there is insufficient government support, then what remains of local programming will be axed. They will become total slave stations of the networkscash machines, but locally irrelevant. Finally, it is highly likely that the introducneed tion of this new and very powerful form of datalink broadcasting will add to the pressure for review of national media laws. The ability of digital TV to bring selective news and information such as classified as into people's living rooms instantly is likely to see the demise of more newspaper titles, while others obviously already see the writing on the wall and are embarking on online services. The decisions to be taken in the future on media ownership and competition will be of greater importance than this bill. This government toyed with the idea of changing media policy but decided it was too sensitive and has put it off at least for this term. I hope before the next election both sides will spell out their media policies in detail and let us know what changes they would like to see so that voters can make up their own minds on who they believe will best deliver an industry that is as diverse and as competitive as possible but ensures that regional television remains viable and relevant. Looking at this second reading amendment from the opposition, I tend to support at least paragraph (7), which states that the legislation 'does not provide sufficient recognition for the particular infrastructure issues faced throughout regional areas'. The bill is going up every day. They are in a quandary. Regional television requires a longer lead period before it and the taxpayer commit to supporting the establishment of this hugely new and expensive infrastructure. With those reservations, I commend these bills to the House.

Speaker: Mr BILLS ON
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Dunkley) (11.34 a.m.)The Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 and the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 are about implementing the government's policy on digital terrestrial television broadcasting. In a highly technical article I was reading recently one sentence stood out. It said: Digital transmission is a technology that will take television broadcasting well into the 21st century. Broadcasters, would be broadcasters and techno junkies might read such a statement and simply agree. Governments, however, to appreciate this fact and formulate policy to include ordinary people in this future. This is what the government has done. Not only does the coalition's digital conversion policy seek to fairly manage the vested interests of the current and aspirant broadcasters, but it squarely focuses on the interests of consumers, the viewers. The policy reflected in the bills before the House rightly has the viewers' interests as the key imperative. The discussion in the media about the government's policy on digital television conversion has centred on the television industry players and media mogul manoeuvrings. Some commentators have claimed that existing TV broadcasters are receiving a that mammoth gift from the government, that the policy suboptimises the economic returns to the government for the spectrum and that the policy framework is both helpful and unhelpful to the entry of new services and products, depending on who you talk to. There has been a lot of talk about the rights of pay TV operators versus commercial television owners and the cost of digiti sing productions and broadcasting technology. These vested media interests talk about their perceived wins and losses within the industry from the policy framework that is at the heart of these bills. One thing is certain-the media players themselves are certainly not lacking a voice to push their pecuniary interests. They have their own products for that. In language the media understands, let me simply state a newsflash: 'Dunkley MP bats for viewers in TV change.' Our first priority has to be what is best for consumers like the people of Dunkley. Back in March the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) said: We want to make sure that all Australians get the benefits of the exciting new applications and opportunities that digital television offers. Established broadcasters have a critical role to play, as do ... the ABC and SBS. People in Dunkley are pretty avid TV viewers. Our community welcomed the introduction of black and white TV in 1956-57 and colour TV in 1975. We watch about three hours a day on average, each of us. Over four in 10 of us use television news and current affairs as our major source of information, as against newspapers being used by three in 10 of the local Dunkley community. Ninety-nine per cent of homes in Australia have television, 77 per cent have videos and more than a third have personal computers, rising to three out of every five for families with teenage children. Australians have always been early adapters to new technology. No more graphic illustration is provided than in the case of mobile telephones, where Australians rank only second to Scandinavians in the speed with which we have taken up this great communications tool. In the use of the Internet, too, we are up there, with about 40 per cent of us accessing it each day. Digital technology and high definition television offer many advantages over the current analog systems. These include better picture quality and surround, and CD quality sound in the form of high definition TV; HDTV is the jargon. It is wide screen technology, similar to going to the movies while you are at home. The Internet can be linked to set top boxes so a TV receiver becomes 'interactive' or a centre of information in the home. Valuable spectrum can be more efficiently used. If you are a mad keen follower of Australian cricket, you may be able to access detailed statistics about the performances of Mark Taylor instead of relying on bits of stats coming from Channel 9 on the screen or through its commentators. Because the United States and the United Kingdom have already got the jump on us, and countries like Canada and Japan are moving to introduce digital television, Australia cannot afford to delay passing these bills if we want to keep a modern, high quality terrestrial broadcasting system. By May next year, the top 10 markets in the US will have digital television. This will create a huge demand for transmission and other equipment. Without the action taken by the government, we would have seen this technology filtering its way into our Australian television environment in an unregulated, unmanaged way to the disadvantage of viewers. To keep the analog system as the only method of terrestrial transmission would mean that TV networks would eventually be condemned to running endless repeats. Maxwell Smart is funny, particularly the episodes directed by my namesake, but my limit is seeing episodes once or twice every couple of years at most. Under these bills, digital television services in markets like Melbourne will commence in 2001. There will be a simulcast period until at least 31 December 2008. Over this eightyear period it will allow consumers to convert to digital television receivers. Most importantly, a review will be undertaken in 2005. If the take-up of digital services by consumers is faster or slower than we anticipate, we have the opportunity to adjust the timetable. Viewers in Dunkley will benefit from the enhancement of programs during the transitional period. For instance, different camera angles might be shown when Richmond takes on Collingwood, with fans able to move between different views as enhanced programming. However, multi-channelling, like the ability to watch a number of games or the provision of multiple or separate channels by commercial television broadcasters, will be prohibited during this eight-year period. This measure takes account of the huge investment made by subscription television service providers under the former Labor government regime. Free to air broadcasters which seck to provide advanced information services linked to programming will have to pay additional datacasting service charges. This is not a free kick. For example, if after Matthew Richardson kicks another goal for Richmond you can click on him and order a pair of his Lotto brand footy boots, join the Tigers supporter group, buy his favourite breakfast cereal or make an appointment with his hairdresser, this will be a new value added product, an added information service. Broadcasters should and will pay for the privilege of this new revenue stream. There are no free kicks. Already there is evidence that consumers want large TV sets with higher quality sound.
