This is what the market is telling us. Since 1990 the proportion of TV sets sold that are 62 centimetres or above has risen from 12 per cent to over 25 per cent. The member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) would know about some of the home entertainment products being made available which centre around the larger television screens. High definition television, or HDTV as it is called, will gradually introduce so-called standard definition television services (SDTV) with this 'multiview' capacity we have mentioned earlier. Regulations will speci fy the extent to which these programs should bc provided in HDTV or represent multi-channelling. A failure to meet these obligations will result in the cessation of licences authorising digital transmission. For the loan spectrum, it will be a matter of 'use it or lose it'. At the end of the simulcast period, the analog service spectrum will be recovered by the government and made available to the marketplace. Local Dunkley retailers say Frankston and Mornington consumers are early adaptors to technology, provided they are convinced of the benefits. Mr Barry Prior of Stanman Retravision in Beach Street, Frankston, says that local residents tend to replace their TV s a bit quicker than the sevento 10-year time frame that has been embraced in this policy. Mr Shane Roberts, who runs Mornington's Retravision store, placed a good ad in The Flier newspaper recently. Shane pointed out that conventional televisions will not necessarily go out of date. Set top boxes for analog TV s can eliminate ghosting and incorporate digital sound, and offer the benefits of those advanced information services I spoke of earlier. Shane made the excellent point that high definition television has twice the horizontal resolution with twice as much detail on each line, saying that looking at a high definition television screen is like comparing a colour photo in a high gloss magazine with one in a newspaper. For a new product to make its predecessor obsolescent, there must be an easily discernible difference between the two. The improvements in picture quality and sound are key selling points. The first high definition television sets in Japan sold for many thousands of dollars a number of years ago. Today, the cost is down to under $4,000. By 2005 or 2008, the price is likely to decline massively, mirroring the experience of mobile telephony. Purchasing a set top box is a possible alternative for consumers. In the 1998 budget, the government announced that the ABC would receive $20.8 million over five years and SBS $17.7 million in the same period to assist these public broadcasters in changing from analog to digital transmission. The ABC has the opportunity to realise existing underutilised assets to finance the balance of the corporation's digital conversion investment. The prospect of early multi-channelling for public broadcasters holds out exciting possibilities for the ABC and SBS. For commercial television broadcasters, the cost of conversion is huge. Not only have capital changeover costs been estimated at about three-quarters of a billion dollars but licence fees will continue to be paid to the Australian Broadcasting Authority, on top of which, if they choose to embrace the advanced information services, further licensing fecs will need to be paid. As I said earlier, there are no free kicks. In L997 these broadcasting fees totalled $147 million for capital city broadcasters, or almost nine per cent of gross revenue. The government wants technology to serve us all better. For this to happen, the goalposts must be realistic and known in advance. These bills and amendments before the House from the government meet this criterion. I commend them to the House.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: There were some interesting comments made by some of the previous speakers in defending the government's policy in relation to the digital television allocation. There is an argument that it is a free gift. Those members who have defended the allocation of spectrum to the free to air broadcasters have said that, for the free to air broadcasters to take advantage of the allocation, they will have to make extraordinary capital investments in order to be able to provide the service-and that would probably have been the case anyway. r want to dwell on a couple of areas where I consider there to be some substantial problems. I just want to declare an interest-I am actually a former Galaxy television subscriber. My Galaxy television subscription ran out when Galaxy stopped broadcasting after it got itself into financial trouble. I would have thought that the government should have looked very closely at the pay TV fiasco as a role model for what not to do. The pay TV fiasco, particularly in Western Australia, has been an extraordinary failure. In Western Australia, we have seen the Telstra roll-out finish, which meant that people who were endeavouring to subscribe to Foxtel were unable to do so because Foxtel services were then not available in particular areas. In my electorate, for instance, substantial areas cannot get Foxtel subscription services. Now, with the absence of Galaxy, satellite pay TV services from the Galaxy broadcasts are also now unavailable, although at this point in time. I imagine that many former Galaxy TV subscribers are receiving the signal from Austar. This will be scrambled within the next few days and will therefore be unavailable. At this stage, there is no indication as to whether or not any other particular organisation is interested in taking up Galaxy's subscribers. In my view, what is going to happen is that there will be a lot of people, particularly in my area of Perth, who will find themselves with translator boxes sitting around on top of their television or stereo systems which actually do nothing but which presumably belong to whoever is the successor to the Galaxy television broadcasting service. They are no doubt also going to have satellite dishes on their roofs which are useless. That in itself will be a very visible symbol of the failure of government policy in the pay TV area-a policy that evolved over a particular period of time but in many instances was heavily influenced by the interests of the free to air broadcasters of television, and that is one of the great problems. The other aspect of pay TV is-as one particular visiting British expert on pay television has made a very strong comment on-the poor quality of some of the subscription services that are available. As a subscriber to Galaxy television, I found that I never watched some of the channels that were available. It seemed that they were just stocking fillers. I like country music, but I could not see a huge section of the population wanting to subscribe to Country Music Television. I suspect that that channel, along with a number of other channels that were thrown in with the bundle, were in fact stocking fillers to make it appear that it was a good deal. The member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) was an apologist in previous debates over the cessation of the analog mobile telephone service. The member for North Sydney was an apologist for the early mistake by the Labor government in the agreement they made with Vodafone, which was then compounded by this government's decision to go ahead without checking and without being able to change its policy and make a decision on what would have been the best thing for consumers-that is, the analog and digital mobile services running side by side, providing the sort of choice that would allow people to pick the service that provided them with the best mobile telephone service. Even the government's own experts-the people who have been charged with going around the country and analysing consumer and public responses to the government's poliey---concede that the digital service in mobile telephony will not be able to cover the entire continent and, in many instances, may well be inferior to the mobile telephony service provided on the analog network. Australia seems to be going in a different direction from that of the biggest market for mobile telephony, the United States, where analog and digital mobile telephony run side by side. In the absence of an agreed standard on HDTV, Australia is already establishing a regime, which in my view is going to be a straitjacket in the delivery of a digital television service. Interestingly, one of the members. I forget which one now-mentioned the fact that, if you sold the spectrum in an auction to interested parties, that would provide less control. That is an interesting concept when one considers that the government itself is considering privati sing the rest of Telstra. The argument used in a number of instances by those who are opposed to that is that as a consequence of selling the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, many of Telstra's universal service obligations-the expectation of scrvice delivery in areas of low profitability or high service costs-will disappear into the void as Telstra operates purely and simply as a corporation endeavouring to return the best possible proceeds to its shareholders. The Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) shakes his head. I would be interested to know what the view of the Minister for Finance and Administration is in relation to the pay TV fiasco. He would have had a view in the earlier days when this was being debated. Mr Hockey-It was a disastcr.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Yes, of course, it was a disaster. Mr Hockey-It was a Labor disaster.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The interesting thing is that two years after the election of this government we have seen the disappearance of one of the players in pay TV service delivery. Many of my constituents cannot get Foxtel because Foxtel is not available in their area. Optus Vision, when I last rang and asked them when they were coming to Perth, gave a two-year horizon-if possible-but said they were going to Adelaide before Perth. We have a situation where, in essence, pay TV will be unavailable to many of my constituents. Free to air services in my electorate are not exactly the best. Many of my constituents find it difficult to get a good picture on free to air services. One of the reasons why many subscribed to Foxtel was that it provided a cable delivery of free to air television signals, providing signal strength that would allow people to see free to air television that they were unable to get through normal broadcasting services. As a person who represents people who live in a metropolitan electorate, this is a disgrace. We have a similar problem with radio services. For instance, I cannot receive AM radio signals on particular stations at all. At this stage in our development of broadcasting legislation and broadcasting technology, that is an absolute disgrace-the fact that my constituents cannot get free to air TV signals of sufficient strength because of the layout of the Perth metropolitan area and the positioning of the transmitters or they cannot get, for instance, AM signals sufficiently strong enough for them to be able to receive AM radio broadcasts in their homes. This is the ludicrous aspect of broadcasting legislation or administration and technology that in many instances, in places like my electorate, leads consumers to be totally exasperated with the people responsible for public policy on this issue. The digital revolution has been talked about-in many instances prattled about-ad nauseam over the years. I would like to point out that, from the years back when people were previewing what sorts of products would be available as a result of the 'digital revolution', there are many instances where some of them have not come to pass, some of them are not likely to, and some of them probably have been tried and have failed. One that will be of interest to people who have kept an observing role in relation to digital service and broadcasting technology and services would be interactive TV; the previous speaker, the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), mentioned that you are able to click on players and get their playing statistics while you are watching a particular game. The interesting aspect of interactive television is that in some instances where it has been trialled it has been a failure. There are going to be various types of models that are either going to be acceptable to consumers or not. A classic example of technological decision making that went wrong was in the 1980s when we had the great competition between Beta and VHS video cassettes. In the end one standard prevailed over the other, obviously to the chagrin of those people who had invested in the other technology. Also, in the 1980s we saw the advent of laser television discs; something that was looked upon as going to provide an extraordinary revolution in the reproduction quality of television sounds and pictures. Interestingly, out of the different types of models ranging from the RCA to the National Panasonic model, video discs, a la 1980s style, have been a tremendous failure as a product that gained general acceptance in households. As far as Australia is concerned, there has been little to no penetration of video disc products at this stage, although the DVD video disc product is relatively new and it will be interesting to see how readily accepted as a piece of technology that is in households. The other thing that was mentioned as part of the digital revolution was the Internet. Much has been said about the Internet. The term 'Internet' encapsulates a wide range of different services. It may interest government members to know that we are going to be able to see television broadcasting services on the Internet. And this is going to happen on the Internet in a reasonable time frame. At present, we know it is possible to receive digital radio on the Internet. Those who have a sufficiently powerful processor in their computer and the relevant software can listen to about 1,000 radio stations which originate from all around the world, principally from the United States and the UK. But there are many new radio stations appearing each day. This competition is going to be precisely the input into broadcasting that is going to make much of what the government is endeavouring to do with its digital television legislation irrelevant. One of the interesting facets of free to air television service delivery is the fact that as a service it is declining in popularity. Less and less free to air television is being watched. The interesting thing about this is that in endeavouring to cement what is considered to be the prevailing free to air service into its legislation, the government is encapsulating in its legislation elements of broadcasting which are becoming an anachronism. It is interesting to note that people are watching less free to air television as a proportion of their leisure time and they are looking at other types of activity-in particular, surfing on the Internet or computing. Another facet of the Internet of interest to those who have had a look at how readily technology is being taken up in homes is that a smaller proportion of Australians who own modems are using the Internet. It is an interesting facet that in many cases people are not surfing the Internet at all; they have got home computers that in most cases are being predominantly used for games that are on CDROMs or have been installed from discs. What we have is a situation in which the government, in endeavouring to establish a new administrative regime for digital television service delivery, has already incorpbrated into that something which is becoming less and less popular, and is likely to become an anachronism. The argument over whether consumers want to have high definition television or multichannelling is an interesting one. For instance, in the United States, when television broadcasters were surveyed on whether or not they thought consumers would prefer to have multi-channelling or high definition television, they suspected that multi-channelling was probably what people really wanted. I suspect that is probably the case too. I believe, as Alvin Toffler predicted back in his work Future Shock in 1970, that what we are going to see is a splintering of service consumer demand. This is the irony of the government's legislation; it solidifies in its oWQ legislation something that is already becoming an anachronism. What we are seeing with the preservation of the free to air regime that we have at present is the exclusion of new entrants in free to air service delivery. Also, with its requirement that free to air services provide similar services on digital television to the services they provide now, the government is building into its legislation a use-by date that is far shorter than it realises. The difficulty will be that we will see a similar fiasco to the pay TV fiasco. The consumers of Australia are very reluctant to jump into new technology without thinking about it. It is an interesting facet that one of the strongest arguments against the government's legislation, against the regime it is now setting up, is the high cost to consumers. Consumers will be asked to invest in new televisions which have a substantial cost. The estimation of $3,000 for a new set is, I believe, an understatement. I believe that television sets of this quality will be in the $5,000 to $6,000 range. Already there are Australians who are investing in rear projection, large screen televisions for their homes so that they can watch movies in a home theatre environment. They are prepared to pay from $6,000 to $8,000 for a television set. But annual average expenditure on TV by the average consumer is around $100 per annum. I suspect that many find HDTV large screen format costs to be excessive. That is one of the problems which will, I believe, affect the way in which this particular regime will work. I am attracted to the amendment of the shadow minister, the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) because, in essence, it asks for wide public consultation to be undertaken before introduction of the regime that is envisaged in this legislation. I subscribe to that. That is probably a smarter thing to do than to jump into something that, as I said, already incorporates an anachronism by virtue of its reliance on current free to air service delivery. The former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, made an interesting comment when he referred to the choice in free to air as being a choice between four buckets of slop. At the same time. I thought that was probably highly unfair, but given the quality of some pay television services and some of the things that are offered I do not think he was that far off the mark. Many Australians have rejected pay TV service delivery because they thought the $50 a month or whatever it cost was not worth it. They have gone back to borrowing videos and paying the rental to watch movies instead of subscribing to the movie channels on the pay TV services. As happened in markets in the US and elsewhere and in the pay TV service debate, the competition between pay TV services probably revolved much more closely around telephony than it did around pay TV or television services. In my view, the roll-out by Telstra and its cessation after losses of many hundreds of millions of dollars was much more to do with telephony and the ability to have the cable network than it had to do with the delivery of services to consumers. What we have seen, in fact, is a race to provide telephony. In the US, as is the case elsewhere where there are cable pay TV markets, the relative turnover of cable TV compared with telephony is a minute fraction. Therefore, telephony obviously has a far greater effect. I think that the amendment proposed by the shadow minister deserves consideration. I know the government will not be happy to hear that. I know the government is anxious to have its legislation go through this session as swiftly as possible. It obviously wants to solidify the arrangement it has set up; an arrangement that some have called a free gift to free to air broadcasters and an effective straitjacket on the rights of consumers. The Liberal and National parties are supposed to be the parties of fair and open markets, of competition and free enterprise. Unfortunately, in this legislation they are cementing what is, in effect, a highly protectionist regime in the area of digital television services; a protectionist regime which will in fact exclude real competition in the industry for a very long time indeed. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: It is a timely decision of the government to put the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 through the House. If Australia is to stay with the technology that exists in the world, then we must move forward. We must allow no further delay. I remember very clearly the introduction of PM radio in this country. Areas like my area of Townsville were denied that technology for many years. PM radio was used across the world for 30 years before it came to Townsville. Why should listeners in Townsville have been denied the quality of that service for so many years under that kind of government policy? It was just unsubstantiated-and so it is with digital television. The technology is there. Why should the people of Australia be denied the opportunity to access this brandnew and very exciting technology? I think this is a timely decision. It is one that we should move forward with as soon as possible. I would also like to say that a lot of credit has to be given to the minister who sponsored these bills-the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston). Senator Alston, as the minister for the information economy, is certainly very much across his portfolio. He understands the needs of Australians and understands what this might mean to our country. I also note that the government does not intend to repeat the debacle that was referred to earlier in this chamber-the mistakes in pay TV. Look at what has happened in that area. The people in the industry who know and understand the industry understand that the government policy that was introduced in relation to pay television was an unmitigated diaster. We saw the failure of the satellite services. We saw enormous amounts of money paid for something that was never going to be profitable. That we could have a system in this country which allowed two cables to be rolled out in parallel through the major metropolitan cities is certainly something that I find very inefficient indeed when a single cable system could have carried everything. This bill is good public policy. It is not about arrangements with certain media owners or certain groups; it is about preserving the free to air television system and preserving access to the free to air television system. is also about the introduction of digital technology, which I believe will be the most significant advance in television since the introduction of colour. Remember back in 1975 when colour came to our screens? It was a fantastic achievement. That was something that took many years to come to Australia after it had been available in the rest of the world. Australia does not need to be behind the rest of the world. Our people should have access to the technology that is available now. The timeliness of this bill is evidence that this government intends to allow the people of Australia to acceSS the latest technology. In relation to the technical details of digital broadcasting, I think the solution that the minister has proposed of allowing free use, for a time, of adjacent channels to the existing free to air broadcasters is a very good decision indeed. It was never possible to have two analog television channels running side by side because of the interference from either the upper or the lower side band, but it is certainly possible to run a digital channel next to an analog channel. The solution to put the digital program next door to the analog program is technically something that is most achievable and very welcome. With the digital broadcasting signal, in the future there are all sorts of other opportunities. Not only can you carry one channel; you may be able to carry multiple channels, although I am personally not in favour of the digital system being used for multiple channels for free to air broadcasters. I think you can have all sorts of added enhanced facilities with datacasting and high definition television. What a contrast to the industry that I was involved in many years ago. I can remember the technology that was available when I was in the industry when, on the morning after Harold Holt was lost at sea at Portsea, one of the first ever direct telecasts came up the link from the south to Townsville, and it was the responsibility of the local television station to broadcast the outside broadcast coming out of Portsea. I was the only person in the television station at that time. It was my responsibility when I arrived at the television station early in the morning to turn on the transmitIt ters, to line up the transmitters, to make sure that the signals were going out okay. I then had to record all the announcements that would be used during that broadcast. When I put the station on the air, I had to be the vision switcher, the audio switcher, the technician, the guard and answer the phone as well. In these days that would never happen. In a way there is some nostalgia there. These days we are tied to control rooms in Sydney and Melbourne, which is a shame. It gives me a very solid basis for telling the House of the importance of maintaining a quality free to air service. Current research is showing that free to air television is the main source of news for most people. Some 42.7 per cent of people who are surveyed indicate that they get their main source of news for the evening or the day from their free to air television service. I also alert the House to the fact that the free to air television providers and their associate companies are the main producers and funders of Australia's film and television programming. I think it is very important to make sure that that industry is supported. I am sure that members of the opposition would also agree with that. Again, very importantly, free to air television is the only source of TV news and entertainment for low income groups in our country. It would be a sad day indeed if there were discrimination against the free to air networks in favour of the pay television networks, because that would be discriminating against the low income groups in the community who cannot afford to access pay television. I think it is very important to maintain a quality free to air service that is there to serve all Australians. This bill that we have before us this morning will certainly bring certainty for both consumers and the free to air networks. It lays out clearly what the government's objectives are, what the rules are, when the services will start, when the transition period will be and what will happen at the end of that transition period. I think that certainty will be welcomed both by consumers and the industry alike. Existing broadcasters certainly need time and protection to justify the investment that they are going to have to make in digital technology because all the transmitters will have to change, the links will have to change, the video recording equipment will have to change and studio equipment will have to change. All of it will have to change. We are asking these free to air broadcasters to make this change, but at the same time we must make sure that we protect their investment in making that change, otherwise it will not occur. That is why it is very important to have clearly spelt out the transition time and to allow a transition time that is sufficient for the broadcasters to recover their investment. I am very concerned with what the opposition and the Democrats are currently apparently supporting. They are supporting a change from the government's lO-year transition period, which would end in the year 2008, back to a transition period that would end in the year 2005. That is not sufficient time for the industry to justify the enormous capital investment that it is going to have to make to provide this brand-new exciting service to the people of Australia. I ask the Democrats and the opposition to consider that they ensure the free to air industry is viable. It has to have . the ability to make an investment and then recover that investment. I would ask them to look seriously at the recommendations that are currently in the industry that it needs a 10-year transition period to make sure that we get this wonderful new service. I want to clearly put the industry on notice in relation to the delivery of digital television in regional areas. I believe that people in regional areas should not be second-class citizens of this country. I believe the transition to digital television should happen in regional areas at the same time as it happens in the capital cities. The process is scheduled to begin in the year 2001, and I see no reason why that starting date should not occur also in the regional areas. I put the broadcasters on notice that I certainly will be doing what I can to make sure that the process occurs in the regional areas in parallel with what is going to happen in the major metropolitan cities. I also put the broadcasters on notice that this investment in new technology must not be an excuse to further reduce local content. I have been very sad to see over the years more and more stations around the country becoming basically slaves to control rooms in Sydney. That is not the way that the televiwill sion system in our country should be going. It is very sad to go from the time when I in the television industry where I could basically stop the program any time of the night or day and insert something of local significance to the time now where it possible to stop anything because you are timed as to what is coming out of a control room in Sydney. It is not good for our counsive. try that the television stations which use a scarce public resource-namely, the spectrum-should be able to use that resource the way that they currently do. r would like to see the return of more localism to television. I think it is in interests of local communities, and certainly it is in the interests of rural Australia, because tures. what happens in local communities can be quite different from what happens in the broader metropolitan cities and so on. I think that regional viewers are entitled to coverage of local events. On a technical matter, I do think that it very important that we preserve the ability the free to air channels to move to high definition television. What that means is that we should allow them the opportunity to enough spectrum in that seven-megahertz Party channel that will allow the broadcasting high definition television signal. I do believe that that is the way that the system will go, the way the technology will go, and we new should be able to preserve that. This tion in fact does preserve that. I now issue a warning to consumers, to customers, to people who own television sets. When this was first announced, the sale analog television sets simply stopped. The reason apparently for that was that consumers felt that the new technology would be here tomorrow. It will not be here tomorrow. as Those who are thinking about this new technology should have every confidence this stage to go and purchase another analog set if that is their wish. I also think that, by delaying the purchase of a digital television set, the price of those sets is going to fall. I do not agree, because of what I have seen in the industry, that we are heading down the track of having sets that be worth $3,000. Digital television is really no different from analog television was other than some microprocessors. All of the scanning circuits, the video IF and sound IF and so on are all the same; the difference is just the processing of the signal that is being is not transmitted, which is done by some microprocessor chips. So, in that sense, there is no reason for digital sets to be more expenAs an aside, I am well aware that, while this technology will produce perfect pictures, in sometimes the viewers do not expect that at all. Sometimes you find that viewers are happy as long as the picture moves and talks. the That quite amazes me because I know that you can in fact get much better quality picFinally, I alert the House to the danger of the direction that the Senate is going in. If the Senate does not pass this legislation by 1 July, then the starting date of 1 January 2001, which would be very appropriate as it is the is centenary of Federation, will be likely to be for put back by another year. The Senate runs the danger of making the country wait another year for digital television. That is what alarms have me about these amendments that the Labor put up today in relation to wider public of a consultation. So I ask the Senate and the opposition to think about that. I think the people of Australia are entitled to a quality technology service, and I would like that legislato start on 1 January 2001.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I support the proposals contained in the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Converof sion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998. I oppose any amendments that seek to change them. I do so for some fairly fundamental reasons, and they are follows. Australia already has four free to air television channels in most parts, or at certainly in the cities, and varying fewer numbers in country areas such as I represent. If anybody believes that the imposition of additional charges on the providers of those free to air signals will remain with the providers-in other words, that we will be able to rip some more money off the rich-they do not understand the capitalist system. I make the same point when we talk about taxation. When we charge fuel tax to a trucking operator, any idea that he does not put a profit margin on it and charge it on to the person consuming his services is an argument that he has got to go broke. Any government which wants to rip some more money off the television free to air people, believing that they will not charge their advertisers and that their advertisers will not mark up their profit on the products they advertise to accommodate that extra cost, is silly. It is a fundamental argument, when governments add charges to providers of services throughout Australia, that they pass them on and the consumer pays. I put an argument to a journalist this morning that if you want to collect $25 billion through our present tax system, considering the number of times that a profit margin is applied to that tax in the system, the consumer pays $30 billion for $25 billion. With a GST where it does not build into the cost, the consumer would pay $25 billion. That is a little outside this debate, except that, when you talk about charges for the spectrum-and I support the concept of the government charging for that resource to ensure that it is available basically to the highest bidder-then you do so assuming that those charges will be passed on to a consumer. In every other direction we are going to do that and there is an argument emanating from the opposition that that should be done sooner rather than later. I think people accept that a free to air television service of about four stations for a capital city, at Australia's population level, is something they are entitled to. If there is to be a change in technology which will upgrade that service-and that is the history of life today-then there is no reason for the government to say that because there is a change in technology we should apply another charge. If, as a result of this technology, more revenue is attracted to the TV stations which provide the free to air service, then the government's revenue will improve because we already apply a licence fee to the licence they get to transmit free to air by whatever mechanism, be it analog or digital, and any increase in their revenues, as I understand it, increases their licence fee. So there is a direct relationship between revenue and their licence fcc-the tax they pay and pass on-but it is relative. In other words, their incomes increase with increased revenue and so does government revenue; whereas, of course, if you just add an additional charge for change of spectrum, then that must be applied to existing revenue. One of the great advantages for government in terms of this marketable product called 'the spectrum' which is available for all forms of communication is that, when digital transmissions are introduced and eventually replace analog transmissions, there will be a great narrowing of the demand on the spectrum that is needed-meaning all that spectrum each side of the channel provided for the pay TV station--once there has been sufficient acceptance of the new technology by the viewer, which they will demonstrate by buying a digital TV set. Then the government will have some very substantial assets within the spectrum to sell off. They cannot do that while we have a continuing analog service. It is an interesting challenge to say to the opposition: if you make the going too tough for the TV stations, the free to air providers, and they say, 'Go howl your hoop; we're going to stay with analog,' how will you ever get the opportunity to sell off all that surplus spectrum? In business you do cost-benefit studies. In business you occasionally put out a loss leader for the purpose of actually making more profit. When one addresses the fundamentals of this situation, the reality is that we have to entice the free to air operators into this market as much as they may wish to be there. In all of that, the free to air people are pressuring the government to actually add to their profit capacity through this medium. They say that they should be able to retain the breadth of the spectrum and use the additional channels to turn a profit by competing with other people whom we have told must pay for access to the spectrum. Recently, as I read in the paper, a group of them paid something like $350 million by way of auction for part of that very desirable medium. The government's response to that is to say, 'No. We are quite happy to give you apples for apples.' We accept the fact that there has to be a period-in the consumers' interests, not in the TV stations' interests-where there are parallel broadcasts. There was a much more cavalier approach to it in my electorate where the TV stations would be much better off turning off analog and turning on digital. Of course, most of the consumers would not be able to see the new programs. That is roughly what happened as digital transmission from satellites was introduced in my electorate. It was done in a fairly brutal fashion and people were forced to spend their money buying alternative black boxes to handle the signal and translate it into their analog sets. It is to the credit of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, that, in recognising this, he and the minister at the table, the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey)--he had to sign the cheque-convinced the cabinet to grant $750 per consumer of subsidy to assist them in that purchase. It was not an obligation on the government because it was in fact a commercial decision made by licensed suppliers of TV information, but the government did it. Through the minister, the government moved heaven and earth to assist me and others interested in this transmission to sort out the difficulties that arose as commercial considerations overrode the rights of people to have an adequate TV service in less populated areas. But that is a little bit outside the legishave lation. The point I want to make is that, in the interests of the consumers of Australia, we are giving them basically a 10-year window so that during that time both analog and digital transmissions are available to them. We expect that demand in particular will quickly run down the retai I price of new digital sets and a period of no less than 10 years will be necessary for people to wear out sets which, in some cases, they have bought quite recently. So this is a consumer based piece of legislation. It is guaranteeing the viewing that people have become used to for a reasonable period while they adjust to the new technology, which they will do because it is better and because it is sensible, as they replace old sets, to buy into the new technology. I repeat the fact that it is not the TV companies that are the big winners out of this. They are going to be obliged to spend very large amounts of capital to create the new systems. They are going to be obliged to continue to run their old system in parallel--even if the only additional cost were power and maintenance, that would be significant-so that the consumers of Australia get what they think is their right, and which I support. If it is done any other way or if the period is shortened, the loser will not necessarily be the TV companies, it will be the consumer, because all of those who have not yet been able to replace their set will suddenly see it turn black. That is silly; there is no need for it. The government has got it right. It is not charging the TV companies for the spectrum during the period of parallel use, notwithstanding that they will have a wider access to the spectrum. But the government will recover some of that prospectively when there is only digital transmission, which will narrow the spectrum required. Of course, we have told the TV companies that they cannot make additional profits from that arrangement. All of that is very sensible to me, and I therefore support the legislation.

Speaker: Mr FAHEY
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I listened with some interest in the course of the past hour to the contributions of many members in respect of these bills before the House, the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998. I note that there is broad support for them. The support comes on the basis that, as a result of this decision by government, a quality of transmission will enter the Australian system that will certainly be far greater than we have to date. There is without the slightest doubt a need to ensure that those that are currently providing the service in free to air television are given some assistance to make the change. With the costs that that will involve, it is not going to be an inexpensive exercise. It requires a significant amount of investment and a dual process. You cannot simply one day close down the analog service and the next moment start up under the new digital proposal. In those circumstances, there was a need for government to ensure that there was a process that allowed a smooth and seamless transition. It is for that reason that the existing spectrum that will be required for the current analog service to be provided will remain there. The new spectrum is provided to the free to air transmitters and television companies, including the national company, the ABC. As a result of having that additional spectrum to be able to provide digital television broadcasting, there will be an opportunity to ensure that that far greater quality, that much clearer service, with all of the other benefits that can flow from the 21st century technology, actually comes to Australia and that Australians arc given the opportunity to enjoy this high definition television. At an appropriate time, of course, there will be a need for those free to air companies and transmitters to vacate the spectrum that they currently occupy for analog. In their vacating that spectrum, that spectrum will become available for disposal, and there is a value attached to its disposal for the benefit of taxpayers. In those circumstances, I believe that the decision that the government has taken allows Australia to be one of the first countries in the world to provide this high definition transmission television picture and to be able to use that technology for the purpose of transmitting multiple programs to the benefit of Australian viewers. I acknowledge the contributions that have been made by all members to this debate, and I commend the bill to the House. Mr Warwick Smith-I understand that there other speakers who want to contribute on this debate and we are quite happy for them to do so. We have just had member arrive, so with the indulgence of the shadow minister on duty and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, we will be able to have the chairman of the government communications committee make his contribution to the debate before I proceed to sum up on behalf of the government. As they say in America, I cede the floor to the honourable member for Hinkler.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I thank the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) and the shadow minister, the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), for their indulgence in allowing me to give the committee's point of view at the end of this debate before the minister sums up. The Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 are probably a defining moment in Australian television. We were not amongst the first in the world to have television. With black and white television, we waited to see what the world would do and then we embraced it. When we did embrace it, perhaps more Australians than most in the world adopted black and white television. The same went for colour television: we watched what the world did, we made our decision and we followed. When VCRs came onto the scene, we were one of the countries at the forefront of the adoption of the technology. Australia has been at the forefront of not only broadcast communications but also telecommunications. It should come as no surprise, then, that when the government considered the change to digital television it made a fundamental decision which will probably distinguish us from most countries around the world. We have decided to make high definition digital television the benchmark-not some form of multi-channelling but high definition television. By that we mean cinema quality broadcasting and CD quality sound-the highest technology-in television sets that are sold in this country. We are not doing it in a piecemeal way whereby we allow some television stations to look at having a mixture of enhanced digital television and we are not talking about multi-channelling. We are talking about having, with our two public broadcasters and our three commercial broadcasters, a common standard that will be the best in the world. That cannot be achieved by auctioning the spectrum because you then create a completely uneven playing field. If you auction the spectrum, people are going to end up with insufficient spectrum to be able to deliver full high definition digital television or they will have some mishmash of enhanced television and multi-channelling. During this debate some people have talked about the British system. You have to recognise that in the UK they have BBC 1, BBC 2, Channel 4 and lTV. They also have enormous competition in Europe. So it does not come as any great surprise that the UK would decide to use multi-channelling to allow a diversity of programming. We do not require that level of activity in Australia because we have had a well-defined and controlled public broadcast sector, represented by the ABC and SBS on the one hand and three commercial television networks and their affiliates on the other. The charge has been made that we have given away the spectrum to the commercial television stations and that it should have been auctioned. Nothing could be further from the truth. We have put a responsibility on the commercial channels to deliver the highest quality digital transmission, the highest quality sound and, implied from that, the highest quality of sourcing of material and production. And we have done it within very strict time limits. By 1 January 2001, the three major networks will be required to have installed high definition digital television transmission in all the mainland capitals. By 1 January 2004, the regionals will be required to do the same. The cost of transmitters, translators, studios, equipment, OB vans and the like will involve the public and private television industry in about $700 million to $900 million of expense, to say nothing of the huge technical problems that will be involved in the installation of this equipment. There is another factor too. In the past, when we embraced black and white television and colour television, we had the benefit of knowing the mistakes made in other countries, which technologies were better and the like. On this occasion we will not have that lUXUry. We will be following very close on the heels of the Americans and the Europeans. Once the advisory committee which has been put in place by the minister advises on the technology to be adopted, the commercial capital city networks will have until 1 January 2001-not a very big time span-to install that equipment. That is a big ask, an expensive ask and a highly technical and involved ask. By 2004 their affiliates-albeit some of them linked corporately to those capital city networks, others by affiliation and others, independents, taking some of the programming-will be required to do the same thing. We should not underestimate the cost to provincial television stations. It will not be just a matter of one transmitter and a few translators in difficult spots in the capital city. It will mean in some instances up to 60 transmitters and translators-a very big ask. The government has mandated in this not to repeat the mistake the previous government made with mobile telephony where the digital signal has been found not to reach to the outer limits of the analog system, leaving great chunks of rural Australia-until the government's recent moves-without any mobile telephony. We did not wish to repeat that mistake when we came to the matter of regional high definition digital television, so it will be a requirement of all the provincial networks to reach to the same parameters as the existing analog signal. That will be a fairly big ask. The other thing we need to look at is how the channels will adapt to this system. Programming will provide difficulties. Arrangements will need to be made to feed the high definition digital signal to the affiliates in the provincial areas. The government is anxious, as I said, to make sure that what is seen in provincial areas is not some inferior service. Also there will be the opportunity for enhancement of the satellite service which goes to remote areas of Australia. The government has also allowed enhancement of existing programs. Where a core program goes to air-for example, it might be an AFL game or a cricket game-limited use of the multi'-channelling facility will be allowed for enhancement. That will mean we can have scenes of the crowd, close-ups of the players, the last catch or the last goal, statistics and the commentators on screen. By a simple flick of a button, one will be able to move from the main game to the enhancement channel, and that will greatly increase the visual experience for the viewer and the involvement of that viewer in the particular football or cricket game. That, of course, does not just apply to sport. It can apply to other media as well. It will mean, however, that the government will insist that any enhancement must be related to the core program. The broadcaster will not be allowed, for example, to run two separate programs. There will be a few variations in the government's regulations. One will be that a limited but different regime may apply to the ABC and the SBS in so far as those particular networks conform to their charter. The ABC may well be allowed to use mu1ti-c-annelling if, for example, it wished to show Its .educational programs or perhaps some of Its arts programs-similarly with the SBS. In summary, the government has mandated that we will have the best high definition television in the world-with high definition video picture and with CD quality soundwith the continuing free to air broadcasters, two public broadcasters and three commercial broadcasters; that there will be special arrangements for the ABC; that there will not be multi-channelling; that there will be a regime in provincial Australia which allows those particular channels three years in which to install their digital technology; and, that all of the channels will have an eightyear period in which they must broadcast both in digital and analog. We should not underestimate the cost of this to free to air broadcasters. This is another reason why the spectrum is being lent to the free to air broadcasters in that, during this transmission period, there will be a cost somewhere of the order of $20 million to $30 million a year to those broadcasters. So it is a big ask for them. I think the government has done an excellent job in putting this legislation together. The government's backbench committee fully supports the measure. It is a visionary concept that will put Australia at the front of the pack and will increase the quality of entertainment and quality of life for many Australians, both in capital cities and in provincial areas.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: It gives me great pleasure to speak on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998. I am very glad to see the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) and the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) in the chamber, some of whom will be following with, no doubt, some excellent speeches after mine. Australia has an excellent record in introducing new technology. We were the world leaders in taking up such new technology as the Internet and mobile telephones, as two examples. Australian television already compares well with its overseas counterparts. In Europe state broadcasters dominate the sector whilst in the United States the commercial sector rules. In Australia we have a very good balance between the commercial stations and the ABC and the SBS. Television came to Australia in the 1950s. A quarter of century later we got colour television. Now, a quarter of a century on, we are getting digital TV. Digital TV is as big a change as colour was. Viewers will get movie quality pictures and CD quality sound. It will also make new services, including interactive services, available to all Australians. The government is committed to ensuring all Australians can share in the benefits of the finally, new technology as soon as possible. In order to achieve this we will need to provide prospective digital TV broadcasters a degree of certainty so they can make the very large investment needed for converting from analog to digital. This Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill is the co- first step in providing that certainty. Commercial and national broadcasters will submit implementation plans to the Australian Broadcasting Authority and to the minister for communications. The bill provides extra channels to existing broadcasters so that they can begin digital broadcasting in parallel to analog services. The government chose the right policy to allow the free to air providers to have that access now because of the huge capital investment that they are currently providing and that they will have to provide, as well as the software. The start date for digital TV for Australia is 1 January 2001 for the cities and 1 January 2004 for regional Australia. The difference takes into account the huge investment reCD quired to upgrade services in rural areas. Broadcasters which fail to meet these deadwe lines will lose their licence. Broadcasters have to simulcast analog and digital TV services for up to eight years to allow conthan sumers time to switch over. They will then return one of the channels to the Commoncurrent wealth. Digital TV allows for multi-channelling. Commercial stations will not be allowed to multi-channel, but this option may be the ABC and SBS. I certainly hope that that happens with the ABC. Unused channels will be put out to tender for datacasting. The charge for datacasting is part of the Dataattention casting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998, which the House is considering concurrently with the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill. Importantly, the needs of regional Australia and the people in my electorate of Richmond are addressed in this bill. There is, as I tioned, a three-year period to allow broadcastcertain ers to set up in the bush. The government also review whether any laws need to be changed to ensure that all regional areas get three commercial services as do the period metropolitan areas. This is similar to what happened with aggregation back in the 1980s, but I do believe it will provide a far more secure and safe regime for those free to providers, particularly in non-metropolitan areas. I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I thank the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) for his warm introtelevision duction. The Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 is the most signifioant broadcasting bill that has come before this House for a generation. It is because this bill provides us with new techDatacasting nology and new access to technology, particuogy larly for the millions of television consumers in Australia. From a technical point of view, we are providing seven megahertz to each free to air television station, of which probably around 5V2 to six megahertz will be available for high definition TV, which means that the average consumer in Australia will have access to cinema quality television and quality sound. But, more importantly, it opens up a whole new access regime. When go to what is called digital terrestrial will television broadcasting, DTTB, we will be using the available spectrum more efficiently is the case with the existing terrestrial analog coverage. And that means that, for the amount of spectrum that is used for the signal you receive at your home now, you will get high quality television and the signal , that is coming across will be able to be used for other services such as data broadcasting or open to perhaps even multi-channelling. There are a number of key points about this legislation that I would like to bring to the of the House and then I will talk about the ramifications of this legislation, which will be of more significant interest to the House. Firstly, this legislation provides for a start-up date for the introduction of digital terrestrial television broadcasting of 1 January 2001. That is for major licences in metropolimentan areas. They will need to use it, within constraints, for high definition TV will and, at the same time, they will have the opportunity to use the leftover spectrum for databroadcasting. There will be an eight-year for simulcast, which means that the average punter at home will have the opportunity to retain the signal on their normal television set until 1 January 2009. So do not air rush out and selJ your TV sets. The opportunity here is that with the development of new technology you will be able to put a settop box on your existing television set and the digital signal and digital quality sound but you will not get high definition coming through your screen because your old TV set is quite constrained. The next point about it is the opportunity to so provide datacasting, and that is important. is a vital part of the new technolera. As one of my colleagues, the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), said a little earlier, datacasting means that you can be watching the football and you can use the computer icon control, which is in your hand, to place the icon on the player and up will come the player's home page and you will have the opportunity to buy boots from Rocca or visit the player's mum's kitchen and get the best recipe available from, say, the Richmond football club team. There will be a lot of opportunities to enter distant home pages on the World Wide Web. This is just the beginning of the opportunities with high definition television. There is a further provision in this bill which I would like to see changed-the prohibition on multi-channelling. As I said, with the spectrum that high definition TV uses, you can either run high definition TV so that you see Brian Henderson on Channel 9 news in full colour--every dot and creased out wrinkle--or you can have the opportunity to have perhaps six other TV channels in the normal analog coverage which you have now. The combination is this: currently, with the signal that we are getting at the moment at home, we can divide Channel 9 into six separate TV stations so you will have 9A, 9B, 9C, 9D, 9E and perhaps even 9F. On one station you might have Brian Henderson and on another station you might have A Current Affair and on another station you might have Max Walker and Wide World of Sport. So, all of a sudden, we have got an opportunity to turn our TV sets from being receivers of five free to air stations into receivers of up to 30, or perhaps even more, free to air TV stations. We have said they cannot do that. We have said they have got to use this new spectrum for high definition TV. And our major concern is that if Channel 9 can have a 9A, 9B, 9C, 9D, 9E then they will start to charge consumers for access to 9D, which might have 24-hour cricket, and of course that starts to impinge on the development of pay television services in Australia. Finally, and this is where I have a reservation as well, there are no new entrants until December 2008. I will be quite honest to this house and say that I would like to sec a further new competitor in free to air television. However, I recognise that there are huge investments by the major television corporations in free to air television in Australia. Channel 9, Channel 10 and Channel 7 have between $1 billion and $5 billion of capital invested in free to air television stations, not to mention the extensive interests of the ABC and SBS. All of them seem to have a presence in my electorate and I am very aware of that. But, at the same time, I also recognise that with that significant capital investment there arc future capital investments required and with the advent of digital televisionhigh definition TV-the major metro stations are going to have to spend up to $700 million on new equipment, up to $50 million a year. I must add, though, that the proof of the pudding out of the United States, where high definition is preferred as opposed to the multichannelling in Europe, is that the original estimates of the costs of the upgrade of the equipment were too high and the equipment is proving a little cheaper. What are the ramifications of this bill? The first point is that here is the greatest single effort to converge technology. All of a sudden you are going to have one unit in the house that will provide you with CD quality sound, that will provide you with a computer datahase and access to the World Wide Web and that will give you free to air television. And what that means is it will be the third most significant investment for every family in Australia after the house-the family homeand the car. That is what it means. So this is going to have a significant impact on consumer spending in Australia over the next few years. The other major ramification is in relation to cross-media ownership and ownership regulations. This bill makes cross-media laws and foreign ownership laws in Australia redundant. Why? Because you are seeing it come out now. For example, Channel 9 has entered into a strategic partnership with Microsoft-ninemsn, as they are promoting it. That is Channel 9 entering into a joint venture for datacasting or data information with a foreign owned company. That, of itself, shows that the spirit of the foreign ownership laws is made redundant. Secondly, in relation to cross-media arrangements, why can't Channel 7 enter into an agreement with Fairfax to provide data services so that once a story comes up on the news with Anne Sanders you can click the icon on the story and you get a full web page or two web pages or three web pages about that particular news item that came from Fairfax press. This is convergent technology; it is going to mean that within the next three years Australia's media ownership laws will become redundant. I am a great advocate for free trade in relation to media ownership. I believe you cannot just change one part of the media laws and not another. You have to change it holus-bolus. In this case it is a perfect opportunity, through market forces, to change media laws. The final point I want to make is in relation to content, particularly in relation to censorship. The World Wide Web is not censored, nor should it be. But we need to look at ourselves very carefully and ask ourselves the question: is it appropriate for us to try and regulate nudity and a range of other sexually related activities on television sets when you can watch Predator, with Arnold Schwarzenegger, where there are the most grotesque and humiliating and horrific scenes on television, and they remain unregulated? What sort of message are we trying to s.end our kids? It's okay to kill people in the most horrific and grotesque way but it's not okay to participate in what are meant to be natural activities. I think there is a strong message about content here and we need to be very careful in this new age of convergence not to regulate ourselves out of opportunities, but, more importantly, not to get carried away with censorship as it is currently being propounded. In conclusion, I would like to pay tribute to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. This has been an extremely difficult area of policy reform-a hugely difficult area-and he has negotiated through it quite correctly. I think the policy is good. If I had my druthers it would be a free and open market, but that was not to be the case. In this case we are making the most significant investment in free to air television in Australian history. I strongly support the bill. I strongly support the policy principles as laid down by the minister for communications, and I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr BOB BALDWIN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: It is with great pleasure that I speak on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998. It is a bill which, through amendments to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 and the Radiocommunications Act 1992, will see Australia enter not only a new millennium but also the digital era of broadcasting. The long awaited introduction of digital terrestrial television broadcasting and the provision of high definition television pictures to make, amongst other things, the TV set become the one-stop shop in every home, covering every aspect from entertainment through to modem learning, information and financial services, has been heralded as a brave new world. But rather than continue to promote the pros of digital TV-and clearly they are as immense as the technology is dynamic-I want to outline to this House my desire and downright determination to see regional broadcasters, quality broadcasters, of the mould of NBN, Prime and Telecasters Australia Ltd get a fair and equitable deal to continue to service their audiences. All three regional telecasters operate within the Hunter and mid-north New South Wales coast as a part of that aggregated market. In particular, NBN and Prime in the Hunter place great emphasis on producing substantial TV hours per week of local content, be it news, coverage of key cultural and social events, through to local sport and providing community announcements-simply by being an integral part of our community. The local programs screened in the Hunter, under NBN, include one hour of local news and network news five days a week and 30 minutes on Saturday and Sunday; This Morning, which is about Hunter entertainment and infotainment; our own local Romper Room with Miss Kim and Big Dog, a preschool program; Community Noticeboard; sports telecasts froni the Newcastle Knights, Newcastle Falcons and Surfest; the NBN telethon-some will remember a young friend of mine, Hayley Tull, a cancer victim-which raised over $3 million this year; and local documentaries. Prime dedicates 30 minutes purely to local news five days a week, and on weekends they do a local news and network news mixture. It provides Regional News Australia, a 30minute weekly program every Saturday; Our sporting country, which is 30 minutes of weekly regional based sporting activities; Community Noticeboard; regional TV specials; and, of course, one that we all know well, the Country Music Awards at Tamworth. These companies invest tens of millions of dollars in our local community by promoting our local community. All three Hunter telecasters actively promote and sponsor major sport, cultural and leisure events, plus charities within the community. In my meetings with both Denis Ledbury and his management team at NBN, along with Brad Jones and David Carr from Prime Television, the delivery of digital services regional Australia and for regional ers brings a lot of promise but also plenty of challenges and costs. Their thoughts on the matter extend further to the issue of retransmission of free to air TV services, which in the ncar future will also be brought before this House. That is a matter I have taken very much on board, having personally addressed the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) on it. My main aim as a part of this new digital ball game is to ensure regional television remains dynamic and continues to have a rock-solid commitment to local news and programming and be as much a vital part of the communities in the next century as they are now, and also to be a financially viable business in the process, employing local people and investing in local communities. I take on board the statement made by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, in their submission to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Committee just last month, which succinctly outlined the position that I am taking in relation to this bill and the real benefits that can and should bring to the people of the Hunter. That submission said in part: Itmeaning digital transmission technologyis not a new service which requires fundamentally new rules, it is a replacement technology which poses some difficult transmission problems because of the need to replace transmission equipment and replace or convert domestic receivers for digital reception. That is a very important point to make. It is a point my government has already taken on board to a large degree and it is a point that we will continue to push. Back on 24 March this year, when the minister, Richard Alston, unveiled the new digital era, there was a special place at the digital TV table for regional TV broadcasters-broadcasters acting either independently or within an aggregate market, which services 35 per cent or approximately 6.4 million Australians with a high quality, high Australian, high local content TV product. This is to about listening to the people of regional and broadcast- rural Australia. Prime Television, NBN and Telecasters Australia will face without question much higher costs per viewer to install digital transmission equipment. For instance, Prime Television, through its current analog service in northern New South Wales, has seven transmitters and 39 translators. In my own electorate, we have one transmitter at Mount Sugarloaf and then nine translators that take that signal. When I listened to my colleague and friend the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) talking about the benefits, quite simply in the bush we just want every house to be able to receive TV. We are not interested in all the fancy stuff. All they have to do in Sydney is put up one transmitter, compared with the seven transmitters and 39 translators just to service the small area of northern New South Wales. That is why this government's policy stance has the backing of regional broadcasters. Regional broadcasters, amongst other things, will have to meet a requirement to commence DTIB services by 1 January 2004, threc ycars after metropolitan stations. They have a free of charge spectrum, no allowance of new players in the market until the year 2008 and, further, the government will consider whether additional support to regional broadcasters, such as licence rebates, is required when planning is complete and the costs of transmission to digital are known. This is the vcry least that they need. FACTS estimates that in 1997 the cost of digital TV was $96 million for operations and $90 million for transmission to regional broadcasters in aggregated markets. As a comparison, metropolitan stations faced only a cost of $22 million for transmission. More recent figures are blunt: $245 million could be the bill for transmission to aggregated region,al players collectively, including Prime Newcastle and NBN. At least 75 per cent of the total free to air TV industry investment in transmission facilities will be made by regional aggregated market operators. Quite simply put, NBN, Prime and Telecasters Australia, the regional TV players from Newcastle to the Tweed border, must be given special consideration by the government towards helping them meet the financial burden. To put it another way, it is the equivalent of placing 15 years of expenditure into five financial years. It could, of course, come in the form of a licence fee rebate or tax relief on infrastructure inputs, in other words, sales tax relief-two clear-cut areas where regional telecasters pay substantial money to this Commonwealth government. Television licence fees for regional broadcasters paid to the Commonwealth during 1997 totalled $30 million. A more glaring statistic taken overall across the free to air television industry is that, collectively, 1997 licence fees as a proportion of revenue have reached eight per cent-the highest-it has ever been, according to FACTS. A further point that illustrates that a helping hand for regional broadcasters is genuinely needed is that the revenue from advertising for regional telecasters runs at $511 million, equating to 21.5 per cent of all TV revenue generated in Australia. The mathematics are quite simple: 75 per cent of the costs of restructuring the industry for digital is funded by 21.5 per cent of the income revenue for regional telecasters. Needless to say, 35.4 per cent of the Australian population serviced by regional broadcasters were within the New South Wales market and in particular the Hunter, which is the most difficult terrain for adequate transmission in all of Australia because of its unique topography. As I said, my aim is not for all the whiz-bangs; my aim is for each house to receive television. Over an eight-year period, with the delivery of aggregation within regional television markets, FACTS has produced figures which outline that $147 million was provided in capital assistance. Whilst not a benchmark, the point needs to be reinforced-in support of my three Hunter and northern New South Wales coast based regional telecasters, to retain their market share influence-that this debate is beyond the whiz-bang technology; it is all about hardware. The capital expenditure involved is estimated to be $500 to $750 million in the first five years of the simulcast period including all commercial networks, regional affiliates and smaller regional independent operators. The government has taken this all on board, a matter both I and a number of my colleagues have pushed. This is not a debate about a free ride for the free to airs-it is nothing of the sort. As outlined to the minister in its submission and given carriage to me by Prime, NBN, Telecasters Australia, WIN and Southern Cross, 'a digital television policy solution which fails to deliver a substantial equivalent standard of service in regional and metro Australia is no solution at all'. That is food for thought when we marry modem technology with modern financial and commercial reality. As I said, put simply, this is not about a free ride for regional telecasters or any such consideration. This is about delivering quality broadcast services for all Australians, not just those who choose to live in the city. I support this bill, as would all of my constituents in Paterson including those who do not currently receive television broadcasts now but hope to in the future.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: We will call a division on this matter. We reject the amendment proposed by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), the shadow spokesman for communications. I sum up on the Television Broadcasting Services (Digital Conversion) Bill 1998 and the Datacasting Charge (Imposition) Bill 1998 today on behalf of my colleague, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, who is currently overseas. I am acting on his behalf this week. When I introduced this legislation some time ago, I indicated in the second reading speech-and several speakers today have indicated this in their speeches-that we have a record of a very strong free to air terrestrial television broadcasting system in Australia. It started in the 1950s, going through to the introduction of colour television in 1975. We have certainly built a very good and strong free to air system in its publicly funded form-the ABC and the SBS-and also commercial broadcasters. It has a substantial level of Australian quality content. As we move fOlward in the new millennium we do stand on the threshold of new and exciting opportunities and the arrival of new technology. As the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) indicated in his speech-he is always very eloquent-this is a debate about a piece of legislation that is fundamental to the everyday lives of Australians. It is about television, where we get so much of our entertainment and so much of our information. The opportunities that are provided by digital broadcasting are now apparent. We are grappling-and this legislation provides the opportunity to deal with it in a constructive way-to deliver digital broadcasting to this nation, to maintain all the qualities that we have come to expect and have seen in the delivery of the free to air systems in this country. Digital television is a huge quantum leap. Viewers will have the option of viewing high definition pictures of extremely enhanced clarity to what they enjoy now and with CD quality surround sound. Many colleagues today have talked about the impact of that technology.
