I thank honourable members from both sides: the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave), the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the member for North Sydney, the member for Paterson (Mr Baldwin), who has just spoken, who indicated his key concern about regional television and making sure that digitalisation is going to be available to all areas of Australia-and this legislation achieves that-and the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), who was concerned about consumers, as we all are. The fundamental point about this legislation is that it is designed to provide a migration path to the utilisation of this new digital technology to make sure that consumers get the benefit of that new technology regardless of where they might live-and I think that is particularly important. In summing up, there are some amendments that the government will move but we will deal with the opposition's amendment first and then I will make a few brief remarks about the nature of our amendments. They are broadly technical in nature and there is no dispute about them, but I will deal with those after we have dealt with this matter. Given that the shadow minister and former minister for communications is here, it is only right and proper that I should deal with his amendment. Can I say to him, firstly, that we do not accept the amendment. The fundamental point that you are making, as I read your amendment, is that there is some desire on the part of the government-indeed, there is-to enable this legislation to become law at the soonest possible time. We did do a review. The Australian Broadcasting Authority did do a review last year, in July. There was wide public consultation about high definition television, about digital conversions. It recommended simulcasting, which is the very centrepiece of this legislation. This allows for existing analog technology, which is the delivery mechanism of the TV signals, to be simultaneously broadcast with the arrival of digital technology. By its very nature, it is done at the same time. That is what the authority recommended and that is what this legislation does. It sets time periods for that to be able to take place. We are quite concerned, because of the level of investment that is required to establish digital television, that the soonest possible resolution of the legal position by way of the legislation take place, and that is why we would want this matter to proceed at the soonest possible time. To meet the dates that are proposed in the legislation, obviously we would need to get those decisions through the parliament as soon as we can. You will recall that the ABA in its report recommended that the start date be 1 January 2000. In fact, this legislation proposes that for metro areas the start date be 2001 and in regional areas 2004, with some leeway to go a little further out if that is necessary. Of course, that will be subject, in the regional areas, to the completion by the ABA of implementation plans. Implementation plans are extremely important in this legislative package because, broadly speaking, the legislation establishes the legal framework, the policy objectives. It leaves in place the prospect of a flexible scheme. We have statutory reviews, which have been the feature of earlier broadcasting legislation, where the resulting regulations are disallow able within the parliament so there is ongoing opportunity for the community through its representatives to scrutinise this process. But it is absolutely essential, when we look at those implementation plans, look at how many repeaters and installations are required, that we take cognisance of the need in regional areas. We would obviously consider licence rebates but that comes after looking at the overall implementation plans. The concerns that are raised by the opposition on that score are met in the body of the legislation and by statements previously made by my colleague Senator Alston and certainly by me. Another point that is raised in your amendment is about the need for industry plans. Quite frankly, there is a role for Australian industry to participate in the digital provision of hardware and broadcasting equipment and so on, but that is not appropriate for this legislation. That is rightly a matter to be dealt with in broad industry policy. I understand the Senate will give the product of its deliberations on 22 June, and obviously we would take account of those. As we have seen the hearings that have been proceeding, we still believe that we must meet that 2001 date and, as I say, provide legal certainty in the bill to enable investments to proceed. In your final point you said you want more time for public debate. There has been an enormous amount of public debate about these issues. I think you use the word 'disingenuous' in your amendment. I suspect that this second reading amendment is of itself and of its nature somewhat disingenuous. You do know, as a former minister, that we have had in this country endless discussions about how we are going to implement digitisation of television to benefit consumers, to make sure consumers are at the forefront of our considerations. Indeed, this legislation does that. There are obviously other issues that members have raised and I will not be able to do justice to them, other than to make one particular point: as simulcasting takes place and you are sitting there with an analog TV set, you will of course be able to have a down converter on your set for a couple of hundred dollars and convert to digital reception. Then there will be enhancements available and multi-viewing will become available. That is allowable under the arrangements. On balance, the government believes that this is an eminently sensible way to proceed to protect consumers, to give a clear and identifiable migration path for Australia to engage new technologies, to enhance for the viewing audience the clarity of the picture and to extend the sound capacity-and do that in a way in which the existing providers of free to air television, which have done so well for us over so many years, are able to be accommodated and become part of this new exciting industry. Of course, we are dealing with a finite resource. We are dealing with spectrum. This is a finite resource that belongs to the people, and we have a responsibility in public policy terms to use it sensibly, to use it in a way that can enhance the community's enjoyment of that spectrum. And television being the preeminent way so many of us get our entertainment and our information, we believe that the public policy objectives that we have set in this legislation, the legal framework that we have put in place, is the sensible way to go. I suspect that, had you been in government, the package that you would be presenting would be very similar to what is being provided here. This is an enormously interesting and intricate technology. It has public policy clashes, and we have seen plenty of evidence of that. There are competing commercial interests, all of which have to be considered. But in the end, we must make public policy decisions for the needs of all Australians wherever they live, and do it in a fair and reasonable way. We believe that this legislative package does that. Mr Speaker, I indicate again that the government does not accept the member for Dobell' s second reading amendment.

text: With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise briefly ments: just to advise the minister that we will not force the House to a division on the second reading amendment. We will just rely on the voices, but our view is stated quite clearly in the second reading amendment.

(74) Schedule L, item 12, page 45 (line 17), omit "21(2) or (6)", substitute "21(2), (2A) or (6)". I present a supplementary memorandum to the bill. These amendments are detailed in the explanatory memorandum. They relate to a range of technical issues. They bring the planning objective for digital conversion schemes for metropolitan areas into line with the regional areas. They also require the schemes to be directed towards the objective that, as soon as practicable after the start of a simulcast period, the digital transmission of a television broadcasting service in both metropolitan and regional areas achieves the same level of coverage and potential reception quality as is achieved by the analog transmission of that service. Indeed, that point was made during the course of the debate this morning and I assure members that that is an objective of the legislation which I feel sure will be achieved because there is quite a deal of difference technically between an analog mobile phone system as against an analog television system and a digital television system. Some people were surmising that there may be similar difficulties but, in fact, there will not be. lt will enable the digital conversion schemes to allow temporary test transmissions of digital broadcasting services before the commencement of the simulcast period and enable the ABA to formulate and implement a different digital conversion scheme for the transmission of broadcasting services to remote areas, taking into account the special circumstances which apply to the delivery of a television service to these areas. It provides that the simulcast requirements do not apply to advertising, transmission arrangements or individual programs where the ABA is satisfied that the digital version of the broadcasting service will be substantially the same as the analog version of the broadcasting service. It increases consultation provisions on the formulation and implementation of the television conversion schemes and the access regime under the bill. It exempts advertising and sponsorship announcements from the closed captioning obligations. We require digital television transmission standards and datacasting standards to be directed towards the objective of having open conditional access systems. These amendments and other minor technical government amendments have been drafted following industry consultation on the bill as introduced into the House. I take the opportunity to thank all those within the industry for their substantial submissions on this matter. Obviously, many have made submissions to the Senate. The minister has taken account of these matters and those matters are reflected in these amendments. I have taken the opportunity to explain in short form what they are and therefore proceed to commend the amendments to the House.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: These amendments are quite wide ranging so I hope the minister does not mind a few short but wide-ranging questions. The first question I would like to ask the minister is whether he is the same member for Bass who bragged in 1991 that he amended the former Broadcasting Services Act to require an inquiry into whether there was a need for a fourth commercial television network in Australia because he believed there was not enough competition in commercial television in Australia. If he is the same member for Bass who used to brag about that achievement, could he explain to us why he, as acting minister, and the government have not used this legislation as an opportunity to introduce more competition into commercial television broadcasting as appeared to be his view in 1991 ?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: In 1991 we required at that stage to have an inquiry into what we should be asking for. If the inquiry recommended it, then obviously one would consider it. I was in opposition, not in government, and we did not have the inquiry in the terms that I would want it.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Isn't it a fact that your government decided not to proceed with the inquiry that you bragged about putting into the Broadcasting Act in 1991 and it has been your government that has decided not to conduct a public inquiry into whether or not there should be more competition in the broadcasting area? Mr Warwick Smith-There is active competition there now.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: If the minister is conceding that point and he is not prepared to defend himself on that point could heAn honourable member interjecting

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Well, he is saying he is not prepared to defend. He certainly had an opportunity then to get up

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Order! I caution the member for Dobell that the bill before us is the communications bill and the question may have preceded the introduction of this bill.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am perfectly entitled to ask questions of the minister on the detail of the amendments and these amendments are so wide ranging that a question about the level of competition in commercial broadcasting is certainly something that is relevant to this bill. I will give the minister another chance in a minute if he wants to perhaps explain to us why his government has not proceeded to implement the clauses that he bragged about putting into the 1991 Broadcasting Act, that is, the clauses that required the government of the day to have an inquiry as to whether or not there should be a fourth commercial television network. Clearly this legislation prohibits any new entrants into commercial television until 2008. What has changed the government's mind or the mind of the Minister for Family Services, who is at the table?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I see what you are trying to get at. I thought you were just trying to play politics for a moment-and cherish the thought! In 1991 we were dealing with the then existing arrangements of free to air television. We were not looking at the prospect of engaging digitisation. This is about how we bring digital television into Australia, given the high capital cost, protecting the interests of the consumer. How do we have a migration path to enable that to take place? I recall, for the benefit of members, that back in 1991 I was shadow minister. I had a lot of different shadow ministries but at that time it was communications and we were having a new broadcasting act. The issue and legitimate question then was-and you will recall there was a great deal of instability in the arrangements and ownership arrangements of the free to air broadcasting networks at that time-should we be looking at whether or not there needed to be a broadening of that base? There has been a consolidation over the last nearly 10 years but now we have to work out how we are going to move to engage digitisation. At that stage it was appropriate to ask the question and I do not recall whether or not the amendments became part of the act or not. I just do not recall. Mr Lee-They are still part of the act.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: But what we are concerned about - here is providing the migration path. If we do not, as a nation, take the opportunity to engage digitisation, you will have a substandard television system as against what is available in the rest of the world. That is the challenge. You know that is the challenge for us as nation. That is the reason why we are doing what we are doing here now, and you are only seeking to delay it by your second reading amendment. You know that it is essential as a nation that we engage this technology. If I do cast my mind back to 1991, it was a very different environment; it was a different technical argument. This is part of the issue in communications policy. The technology is sometimes running far ahead of our capacity to keep up with it in public policy terms. What we are trying to do here is give some certainty to the investment that is required. I think that is a reasonable and fair answer to the intent of your question.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Cunningham) (1.39 p.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker, this consideration affords me the opportunity to raise a consumer issue associated with the way in which people around Australia can receive television broadcasts now. That consumer issue, of course, is the fact that on 15 June, which is only a short couple of weeks away, the World Cup Soccer will be commencing. The World Cup Soccer rights have been obtained by SBS. Of course, as all members in this place would know, SBS has regrettably still a reasonably limited broadcasting opportunity, particularly in regional Australia. Given that the World Cup is a one in every four years event and it brings to a particular nation-in this case, it is to France-the best soccer nations who have gone through a series of games to find who the finalists will beregrettably, with the absence of Australia, but nevertheless the best soccer nations of the world will be there-and given that soccer is, after all, the world's game, being played in more countries than any other sport, one would have thought that the opportunity could have been taken by other broadcasting networks to afford people, particularly in regional Australia, the opportunity to view the World Cup. As I understand it, SBS offered that opportunity to commercial broadcasters free of charge. They offered to the other networks the right to on-broadcast the World Cup games free of charge. One network which refused it was the WIN Television network. That, of course, greatly concerns me because WIN has its home in Wollongong, in my electorate. It now broadcasts almost entirely up and down the east coast of Australia, from Cape York Peninsula to the very bottom of Tasmania. I would have thought that the opportunity being offered by SBS, particularly in terms of it being on a no-cost basis, might have been embraced. I guess what I am relaying in this debate this afternoon is the fact that there are many people-I will be lucky because we get SBS in W ollongong and we will be able to watch the World Cup-in regional Australia who will not have that same lUxury. As I say, it is a four-yearly event of the world's best nations playing soccer. When excuses about television commitments for other sporting events like tennis and so on are proffered by the commercial television stations, it disturbs me a that perhaps they are not looking at some of their clientele that might be quite desirous of wanting to follow the World Cup Soccer. This is a consumer issue. Not everybody follows sport, I understand that. I know it is a comment that a lot of people in Australia from time to time make. But if we are going to provide an opportunity-and, as I understand it, most of those games would be in the middle of the night anyway-one would think that those commercial stations could probably put to bed their home shopping hours or some of the other things that are broadcast in their 24 hour a day operation to give regional Australia an opportunity to watch what is, as I say, a once in every four years event. With the planning that has gone into the World Cup in France this year, with the stadiums that have been built in Paris and in other parts of France to accommodate the competition, one would have thought the world's game should have been offered to the majority of Australians. I just wonder whether the minister might have any powers of persuasion over those former colleagues of his in the television industry, given, of course, that I well remember the fuss that was made a couple of years ago by the minister in respect of cricket broadcasts coming from the West Indies. Mr Lee-Didn'the say something in Launceston?

Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I think my colleague the member for Dobell is dead right that there were some comments made by the member for Bass, the minister in respect of those issues. So, Minister, I would be most grateful if you might look at this matter because I do think it is worthy of great consideration.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I think I should, out of a sense of nostalgia for matters sport, if nothing else, say that we obviously would be very keen for as many people in Australia to see the World Cup as possible, but these are matters obviously of a commercial nature. I do not believe the government has any direct capacity. There may be discussions taking place with the department and touch my colleague the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) and I just have not been advised about them. But, as I am well known for supporting matters sport, if there are avenues for me to assist in that regard I most certainly will.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The next issue I would like to raise is this question that a number of speakers and the minister picked up in the second reading debate about the quality of the signal that viewers will receive when we move to digital television. I did seek an assurance during the second reading debate that anyone who currently receives analog television will receive a digital television signal presumably of equal quality. We all keep getting told that under digital television you will have a better signal. Excuse us for being a bit sceptical about that, given that past predictions by some technical experts have not been delivered to the public. I would seek from the minister a guarantee that anyone who currently receives an analog television signal will receive a digital signal. If that does not end up being the case, we want an assurance from the minister that the government will take responsibility for fixing that problem. Can we get that guarantee from the minister?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: Just quickly, given the hour of the day, the conversion objective is to achieve the same level of convergence, and that is reflected in the act. The implementation issue is a matter of the ABA implementation plans. There i" a marked difference between the mobile telephony phone systems moving from analog to digital and the television moving from analog to digital. There are qualitative differences, and it hinges on the implementation plans. As I am advised, the same level of concern need not be held about the issues that you raise. We are extremely confident, and we have made that a primary objective of the act in terms of the conversion arrangements.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: They were fine words from the minister but they do not give us that guarantee. It is one thing to say that his advice is that this will not be a problem. I am merely a humble electrical engineer and my understanding of this is that there is no way the government can guarantee that people who currently receive the analog signal will be guaranteed to receive digital television. The question that then flows from that is: who is going to be responsible for the extra cost of putting in the extra translators to make sure that all of the people who are in the gallery today who now receive an analog television signal will still have access to a digital television signal? In the Sydney market in the conversion from analog to digital, for example, if Channel 9 has one digital broadcaster for the Sydney market, I am sure there will be many parts of the wider Sydney area that will not receive the digital Channel 9 signal. Who is going to be responsible for making sure that Channel 9 puts in the extra translators to make sure every person out there who now receives the analog signal will receive the digital signal? Or is the government going to leave that up to Channel 9and Channel 10 and Channel 7: the commercial television channels-to decide who will recei ve a digital television signal?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The centrepiece of the legislation for the conversion objective is to see that there is full coverage. The implementation plans which will flow after and which will be subject to regulation-they will be subject to disallowance, so there will be ongoing scrutiny from the parliament-will become the centrepiece as to what level of technical installations will be required and their location. In other words, we are putting in place a process that will be looking at where those installations will need to be to meet the conversion objective. Sensibly, that is the best one can do, and that is far more than what is normally done, obviously, to ensure that you get to the point where you get a universal conversion without any difficulty. Of course, the more robust signal that is delivered by digital technology gives that better quality, that greater clarity. The centrepiece is the objective of conversionand then the implementation plans. But your point is well made and that is well known by the industry. It is in their interest as well to give that broad coverage.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I suppose that is my concern. What is the conversion objective? Is it that there be a 100 per cent conversion? Mr Warwick Smith-To achieve the same level of coverage.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: If the minister says it is the same level of coverage, what we want to know is whether there is a legal obligation for the commercial broadcasters to lodge a plan which will deliver 100 per cent conversion. If that is the conversion objective, what will happen if the conversion plan does not deliver digital television to everyone who now receives an analog signal? Will there be a legal obligation on the commercial broadcasters to put in the extra equipment that will make sure that everyone who now receives analog TV will receive digital TV? Who is going to be legally responsible if there is not a 100 per cent conversion?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: The prospect of that is not in prospect. The conversion objective is to have the same level of coverage. As you know, we have universal coverage, and they are required under the implementation plans to meet that objective-and they will meet it. They have a market imperative to do so.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: I am sure the minister at the table and the officials know that we do not have universal coverage in Australia at the moment. Just simple swaps from WIN4 on the very high frequency signal to WIN on ultra high frequency has seen some people fall off the table. We have not been able to have 100 per cent conversion from VHF to UHF. If the minister is telling us that there is going to be a miracle solution to make sure that 100 per cent of people who now get analog will get digital, r would like to know about it because I do not think it can be delivered technically. What I then want to know is who is going to spend the money--or will anyone be required to spend the money?-to make sure that the people who would otherwise fall off the table, who will lose access to their television, are going to be looked after? Are we going to require the commercial broadcasters to spend the extra money to make sure there is a 100 per cent conversion or are we going to leave open the possibility that a percentage of Australians will lose access to their television?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: All I can say to you-and I think you are trying to split hairs here-is that the conversion is required to meet the same level of coverage as currently exists, which is very extensive, and that they have a commercial imperative to do so. They need to go through the process of implementation plans, and we will rely on the content of the act to enable us to ensure that we meet that objective. If you want to have a technical brief on what you are trying to get at here, you perhaps should seek that, if you have not done so already. Mr Deputy Speaker, I would urge the shadow minister to allow us to deal with the second act here before 2 o'clock.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: DATACASTING CHARGE
text: This is the last occasion I will raise it but the minister's last answer seemed to be completely at odds with his earlier answer. Earlier he said there would be a 100 per cent requirement for conversion, and that was on the advice of the departmental officials. His last answer was that it would be similar to the current obligation. The current obligation on commercial broadcasters does not require them to make sure that analog TV is delivered to everyone in their service area. It is up to each of the commercial broadcasters to decide how much money they will spend on delivering their signal to all those homes out there. The point I am trying to make is: can you today give us a guarantee that everyone who now gets analog TV will get digital TV and how are you going to implement that? Are you going to require the taxpayer or the broadcasters to put in the extra transmitters, towers and poles to make sure that 100 per cent of people who now get analog TV will get digital TV? Amendments agreed to. Bill, as amended, agreed to. Third Reading Motion (by Mr Warwick Smith)-by leave-proposed: That the bill be now read a third time.

If that requires someone to spend money, who is going to spend the money, the commercial broadcaster or the government, to make sure that everyone out there does get access to their digital TV? Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE
text: Cunningham) (l.56 p.m.)At the outset I indicate to the government that, whilst we have some reservations about increasing the departure tax on passengers leaving Australia, the opposition will not be opposing this particular measure as it has been caught up in the budget process. Also, the way in which this has been introducedincreasing the so-called passenger movement charge, which is a departure tax, by $3 up to $30-is a clear example of this government's breaking yet another promise to the Australian people, that is, in the first term of a Howard government there would be no increases in taxes and no introduction of new taxes. Clearly, this is a promise that has been broken. It has now slumped into the category of a non-core promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Once again, it is going to be the outbound tourists leaving Australia, both Australians travelling overseas for holidays and those tourists that have come from overseas and then are departing to go home, that will be slugged the extra $3. I read with interest that it is proposed that this measure commence on 1 January 1999, so it is some six or so months away, although interestingly, according to the explanatory memorandum, it was actually to start on ] January 1998. That has been conveniently crossed out and somebody has written in '1999'. Whether that was a printer's error or whether the government was again going back on one of its long-cherished beliefs when it comes to legislation and its effects on the Australian people-that is, introducing an element of retrospcctivity-we will not know, because this bill, when it is finally passed, will not come into effect until 1 January 1999. It has been sold also as a measure to reap some benefit for Australia, for the government, in the year 2000 as a result of the Olympic Games. The fact is that Australia stands to benefit from an enormous influx of people, certainly commencing next year in 1999 and in the year 2000, as people come to this nation, both as athletes and also as visitors, to participate in what is clearly every four years one of the premier sporting activities in the world. The Olympics will provide an opportunity for people to see first-hand the world's athletes; they will see at first-hand in Sydney facilities which have been purpose built and which I think will stand the test of time as being amongst the best, if not the best, ever constructed for that purpose. Certainly that was the view of Juan Antonio Samaranch when he was here a few months ago to look at progress on the site. As I have indicated, the departure tax increase that we are discussing today will be implemented by way of a bill. There had been some thought that it would be implemented simply by regulation, but that has proven not to be the case. There is a severe budgetary implication for government with the introduction of this tax increase, not in a negati ve sense but certainly in a positive sense. Based on the budget measures outlined in Budget Paper No. 2 1998-99 and looking into the next four years, you can see that the take by the government from increasing the departure tax alone on visitors leaving this country by air is going to reap at best estimates-and I think these are conservative-$78 million. I will continue my remarks on this issue a little later today because I want to expose some of the hypocrisy of the government in respect of implementing these sorts of measures-breaking, Prime Minister, yet again, that promise.

text: The honourable member for Prospect I warn. Economy Miss JACKIE KELLY-Can the Treasurer inform the House of the March quarter national accounts. Furthermore, are the figures consistent with budget forecasts?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for her question. Today's national accounts confirm that the Australian economy is growing strongly. In the March quarter the national accounts recorded 1.3 per cent growth, and over the course of the year 4.9 per cent growth in the Australian economy. A 4.9 per cent growth in the Australian economy puts Australia probably at the highest of the OECD, with possible exceptions in Finland and Mexico, but certainly higher than of the G-7 economies. Although the national accounts are always subject to revision, and care has to be taken in interpreting any particular quarter, one can see that this is totally consistent. with the budget forecasts of growth in 1997-98 of 3% per cent-indeed, at the moment considerably exceeding those forecasts. On the back of strong growth in this quarter those forecasts will be realised. Although today's national accounts showed that domestic demand was flat, other indicators, such as employment growth, job vacancies, building approvals, credit growth, import growth and continued strength in trading performance and business surveys all support strong domestic demand continuing. Although today's accounts also show a build-up in private stocks allowing for a trend decline in the stock to sales ratio, there was a low stock to sales ratio. Indeed, it appears that the build-up in public marketing authority stocks, particularly by the Australian Wheat Board, indicates that the Wheat Board was holding commodities such as wheat, barley and sugar--commodities which have now been sold and which will become exports in the next quarter and contribute to export growth in the final quarter of 1997-98. More recent building approvals numbers showing growth of 8.3 per cent in April and 19.5 per cent over the year indicate good investment in the economy. Business investment will be underpinned by continuing growth in corporate profits, which grew 3.5 per cent in March to be 7.5 per cent higher than a year earlier. These figures are consistent with an economy which is showing low inflation, enjoying the lowest interest rates in generations and enjoying a government which has put the budget back in the black and is now reducing Commonwealth debt, and which has had remarkably strong growth up until March of this year, at 4.9 per cent. Mr Wilton-What about the current account?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I think most Australians will welcome strong growth in the Australian economy. Even though we hear interjections all from some of the backbench of the Labor Party, complaining about high growth in the Australian economy, I think the front-bench of the Australian Labor Party would be pleased to see growth of 4.9 per cent. I think even the front-bench of the Labor Party would say that the important decisions of getting Australia's budget back in the black, of locking in low inflation and of giving Australia low interest rates were important markers to get to this position. Whilst an external downturn in Asia will affect the Australian economy and mark growth in 1998-99 from the levels that it has been in 1997-98, we can say without qualification that it was the decisions of the govern- long; ment to turn around the haemorrhaging deficit and debt strategy of Labor, to reduce inflation and to bring down interest rates that strengthened the Australian economy at a time of external challenge. No-one would want to running the Australian economy if it were running a $10 billion deficit now in the face of an external challenge of the dimension that we now have. Now is not the time to turn our backs on good economic policy; now is the time to continue it, to continue to strengthen the Australian economy against external challenge and to bring the benefits of low inflation and low interest rates to small businesses and home buyers in this country. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I have seen a summary of that. That particular report was raised with me when I met a group of pig producers in Toowoomba last Saturday and they put their situation to me. I undertook at that meeting to consider what had been put, and in fact I have conducted a number of discussions with colleagues about this matter. Somebody in the government will be having something to say on the subject within the next few days. But I take the opportunity late given to me by the question asked by the honourable member to deal directly with the issue that is raised, and that is whether there is some simplistic solution to this problem by simply chopping off imports, because that is precisely what the honourable member is saying. It is very easy when you have an Australian industry under a bit of economic pressure as a result of imports to run around the country saying, 'The answer to the problem is to choke off imports.' Unfortunately, most of the imports in this particular instanceunfortunately for the honourable member's argument-are coming from Canada. It so happens that we have something like an eight or nine to one trade balance against Canada. If we were to be so short-sighted as to chop off imports from a country in respect of which we have a trade balance of about nine to one, we would in fact be cutting off our nose to spite our face. That would be a very unwise thing to do. The international economic reality is that when it comes to a trading nation like Australia, we need markets. We need people to buy the goods and services we produce. If we do not buy the goods and services other people produce, they will not buy what we produce. That is a constant of international trade. I say this very deliberately because the honourable member has been running around the place saying that it is all very easy to solve these problems by chopping off imports. If you chop off imports in the wrong place, you will chop orf Australian jobs. If you do that you will chop off Australian jobs. I therefore say to those people in the pig industry-and I am sympathetic to their position; r listened very carefully to what they had to say, just as I am sympathetic to any industry that is under import pressure-that, if you chop off imports from one source and there is retaliation, you will end up doing up far more damage to your country, you will destroy more jobs and you will destroy more industry than if you had not taken that action. It is about time that all of us who are interested in a sensible debate and all of us who are interested in the future of Australian industry face the reality of this and stop running around uttering and mouthing populist one-liners offering simplistic solutions that would in fact damage the situation and leave us with fewer jobs, weaker industry and a far more impoverished trade situation. text: The answer to the quesTaxation tion asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is yes, I still do have a great deal of respect for Dr Warren and I regard him as one of the foremost tax experts in Australia. We have business investment running strongly. We have reformed the industrial relations system. We have many other micro-economic reforms under way and the next thing we have to do, not in a revolutionary but in a sensible evolutionary way, is to reform the Australian taxation system. Looking at the indirect taxation system is part of it. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked me a question about speeches made by Dr Warren. The ALP Internet site has a section called 'Speeches and policy statements'. It contains, so it a list of major speeches and policy statements by the leadership group. That sounds impressive. For the years 1997 and 1998 the site lists the following: 48 speeches and statements by Kim Beazley; three by Cheryl Kernot; three by Mark Latham, and a book; two by Simon Crean; one by Paul Keating called 'A prospect of Europe'; one by Martin Ferguson; one by Nick Bolkus; one by Martyn Evans; and one by Bob MCMullan. text: I thank the honourable member for Fadden for his question. We have been trying to clean up this problem which was left for us by, above all, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. As the House knows, I cancelled Mr Skase's last Australian passport on 29 April last year. That passport has now been returned to Australia by the Spanish authorities. They confiscated it when Mr Skase applied to renew his residence permit in Majorca which expired on 13 May this year. On 27 May-that is, last Wednesday-a says, lawyer representing Mr Christopher Skase wrote to the Australian Embassy in Madrid seeking a new Australian passport for Mr Skase. Mr Skase claimed he needed a new passport because he now has no identification documents. I can inform the House that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will not be issuing Mr Skase with a new passport. That is the policy of this government. We have informed Mr Skase's lawyer, through our embassy in Madrid, that his application for a new passport has been rejected and that he will not receive a passport. Immediate]y after question time, I will be meeting with the Spanish Minister for Indus sions, I will be taking the opportunity to ask that the Spanish government not renew Mr Skase's residency in Spain. Whilst the Australian government will not be issuing Mr Skase with a new passport, we are prepared to do one thing for him; that is, to issue him with a travel document to enable him to return to Australia. And that's it. Waterfront

Speaker: Mr DONDAS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I address my question to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Can the minister inform the House what role detention policy has played in maintaining the integrity of Australia's borders? What has the coalition government done to ensure that Australia's detention centres provide an acceptable standard of detention?

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory for his question in relation to the maintenance of the integrity of our borders. It is a particularly relevant issue to the Northern Territory, as in the pa.st it has been one of the places where people have clandestinely attempted to enter Australia. An impOltant aspect of dealing with the issue of the extent to which people seek to circumvent our very reasonable immigration requirements is the issue of how you manage the entry of people who seek to come clandestinely. We know that in the early 1990s hundreds and hundreds of people arrived by boat, and this year we expect something of the order of 1,700 unauthorised arrivals by air. We have seen very significant trafficking and people making large amounts of money out of smuggling people from one country to another and exploiting people's vulnerability. Some of the people who seek to access Australia may have legitimate claims for refugee status for protection. That is a matter for which we have proper regard. We do accept our international obligations and we do allow those people who have proper claims to access Australia promptly. But, in relation to those people who arrive with no authority, often without any identification or documentation, who have deliberately disguised the way in which they are trying to enter Australia, you need to have a framework of law to deal with that situation. The framework of law has to be complemented by a range of measures to deal with those initiatives. That does not seem to be well understood by some members of the human rights bodies that we have, by some well-meaning people there who argue that when people arrive clandestinely they ought to be released into the community immediately or shortly after. The fact is that if you arc going to ensure the integrity of the borders you need to have a system in place in which people are detained and, if they have no claims, are available for removal. You need to have a situation in which you are able to effectively administer that arrangement, and detention complements that regime. It is not an end in itself, but without it our ability to remove people in a timely way would not occur. It is important to know that over a period of time we have been able to effectively reform the way in which this task is being undertaken. Today, protection visa applications are dealt with, for those in detention, in 51 days. The average length of detention for unauthorised boat arrivals in November 1995 was 417 days, compared with the average length of detention for all unauthorised arrivals-that includes boat and air arrivalsof 174 days. There has been a very effective removal of people, such that we have only 13 boat arrivals presently in Australia, and one is seeking to resolve their situation as quickly as possible. Those who refuse to cooperate, those who refuse to pursue their applications, can often be held for times longer than we would like. Finally, in relation to the question of the way in which people are maintained in Australia, let me say that there had been, I think, except for the purchase of the Port Hedland detention centre, no activity by the former government in looking at the way in which accommodation was provided. In the time that we have been in office, some $12.5 million has been spent on upgrading the Port Hedland detention centre, and in the most recent budget provision has been made for a $35 million project to upgrade the Villawood detention centre. They are important developments, ensuring that we do detain people in humane conditions and appropriate conditionsMr Laurie Ferguson-It says something about your government.

Speaker: Mr MAREK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, access to services is a major priority for people living in regional and rural Australia, including those in my electorate of Capricornia. Given that one-third of the veteran community lives outside major metropolitan areas, can you tell the House what the government has done to improve services for veterans and war widows in regional areas? In particular, what has been done to provide veterans with access to information about their entitlements?

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Today is the 56th anniversary of the great naval battle of ' Midway in the Pacific during the Second World War. I acknowledge the great support that the member for Capricornia gives to the veteran community in his electorate. There is no doubt that our veterans and war widows, wherever they live, need access to good services, particularly if they can be found in their home town or region. Since coming to government it has been a priority of the government not only to focus on the needs of our veterans who live in urban areas but also, because one-third of our veterans and war widows live outside urban Australia, it has been important to make sure that those in regional and rural areas have access to information services. This is an area of government service that was not delivered under the Labor Party when they were in government for 13 years. It is important, too, that veterans do not have to rely solely on telephone access for this valuable service or information. Since coming to government less than two and a quarter years ago, we have not only introduced new services for veterans in rural Australia, including psychiatric services, podiatry services and more easily accessed transport services, but one of our most important improvements is that we have made it easier for veterans to gain information about their entitlements. Only recently in Rockhampton, the member for Capricornia's town, the TPI Association through the joint venture scheme was successful in gaining $3,500 for transport services for its TPI members and $4,500 for other services for its association. Since coming to government we have opened up veterans affairs network offices in Bendigo, Maroochydore and Toowoomba. We have also established information services for veterans throughout New South Wales through the New South Wales government access centres in Gilgandra, in Grenfell, in Oberon; and through the Queensland government agents program, in Biloela, Cunnamulla, Blackall and Julia Creek. We have established information services through Centrelink in Orange, in the member for Calare's electorate, in your own electorate, Mr Speaker, in Tamworth; in Wagga Wagga, and in Rockhampton in the member for Capricornia's electorate. Soon we will be doing it in Mount Gambier in South Australia. Contracted information services have also been established at Roma and Emerald, in Queensland. We have contracted community development services in Mildura and in Darwin. We have also assisted the veteran community to establish veteran information centres in Alice Springs, Port Lincoln and Murray Bridge. We are currently negotiating with the Tasmanian state government for information services to be provided in Smithton and also in Queenstown. This is the way the government is acknowledging that one-third of veterans live outside of metropolitan Australia. The information that these offices provide is invaluable to our veteran community. We have established 22 information services locations throughout Australia since coming to government and there are more to come. This is acknowledgment of our veteran community and the very special place they hold not only in urban Australia but also in rural and remote parts of our nation.
