Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The failure of the government to act to ensure the job security of the workers at Burnie. I call upon those members who approve the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number a/members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Hotham) (3.49 p.m.)Today's announcement that the Amcor pulp mill in Burnie will close by the end of the year is yet another savage blow to the econtotally omy of north-west Tasmania. And what do we see? We see the government not only ignoring their plight but also scurrying out the chamber. The closure will mean the loss of at least 200 jobs directly associated with many others in the north-west community. The decision to import pulp rather than to produce it at Burnie is a harsh and callous against the mill workers and their families, who have acted loyally for the company and for their region. Over the last few years people have done everything askcd of them lift the efficiency of the mill-to cooperate with the management, to work as a teamthe and yet they find out about their redundancy by a leak in a newspaper. When they turned up at the meeting today to be given the news directly, they were given no detailed informaforest tion as to what was involved or what their future could hold. The closure of this mill will further worsen our already deteriorating current account. We fixed a regional forest agreement for Tasmania and established that area which could be logged. What this closure does is to move away from processing that which is logged so that more will now go out as woodchips. How can that logic be understood? It is not only a hit to the workers themselves-because they have no futuretalking but also completely contrary to the direction in which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) today said he was trying to head the nationthat is, value added activity. This is reversing the direction. It is going back to woodchip exports. What is the government doing about this? Nothing to date. Today's announcement of the intended closure has seen the government lift not one finger to try to stop it. We now know from the decision today that this closure will of not occur until October. Given that the government has done nothing to date, it at least has the opportunity now to do something between this announcement and October to try to preserve and secure those jobs which otherwise will be lost in Burnie. The Prime Minister must personally intervene. His member of parliament for that seat has been ineffective. The acting minister for industry, Mr Truss, has ended up insulting the workers and blaming them for their own fate. of And where is the real Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore)? He has gone to Paris. There are a few casinos in Paris. But he will not go to Burnie to save the the mill and workers or their future. This requires the Prime Minister to personact ally intervene. He should telephone Amcor's chair, Stan Wallis, and talk about what is needed to safeguard the jobs of the Burnie these workers. He should go himself to Burnie to immediately to sec first-hand the problems facing the region and to meet the workers and management of the mill. His government must develop a comprehensive industry development strategy for that industry based on the forest agreements; not just secure a agreement-which was the legacy that Labor left-but actually intertwine it with an industry development strategy that drives value adding. That is what this government should be doing. He also should be talking to Amcor about alternative investment opportunities in the Burnie region based upon such a strategy. That is what that government should be doing. It is what Labor would have been doing well before now. Again we are saying to the government: we will cooperate in talking with the work force, with the region, about what we can do collectively to secure an expansion, not a decline, in the region. But this is a government that turns its back on any suggestion of bipartisan approaches to industry policy and turns its back on getting involved in any activity that can secure the future of workers. In short, the Prime Minister has to involve himself. He needs to lead. That is what he claims to be: the leader of the nation. But he cannot lead on this issue because he has got no interest in doing so. Yesterday, in question time, the opposition called on the Prime Minister, before this announcement was made today to the Burnie workers, to actually telephone Stan Wallis, the chair of that company. We know that he has the telephone number of Stan Wallis because it is Stan Wallis who is always appearing whenever the Prime Minister needs to be bolstered on the call for tax reform. It is Stan Wallis who says, 'Take the taxes off business and shift them to the punters, shift them to the workers,' and, 'Prime Minister, we are behind you all the way.' But can the Prime Minister have the simple conversation with Stan Wallis about securing the jobs of the workers, the people who without jobs will not be paying any tax because they will be unemployed? That is the question and the issue that the Prime Minister should be engaging himself in. He refused to answer that yesterday in the parliament, so I take it he has not made that call. He refused to say whether he would make it. He refused to say again today whether he would even visit the mill. Who is he sending down? His Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman). Why would you be sending the Minister for Social Security if it was not to look at the circumstances of unemployment benefits? Why not send the minister for industry? Why not send the person sitting at the table deputising for the minister for industry, who has gone to Paris, Minister 'Blackjack' Moore who would not go to Newcastle when the Newcastle works closed but went to the opening of the casino? Now he has gone to Paris. He is putting baguettes before Burnie beca!lse he does not care about them. Where are you as acting minister? You get up and insult the work force in this place. We also had, in the context of the BHP closure, the Prime Minister offering to go to Newcastle 'soon'. Soon? Do you know where he had to go before he went to Newcastle? To the Second Test at Lords! He could not even drag himself to that place he loves to go, that same motel room this ordinary Prime Minister has been going to for the past 15 years at Hawks Nest. Do you know where Newcastle is, Prime Minister? It is the smokestacks a bit further south from Hawks Nest. This is where the Prime Minister was. He could not go to Newcastle, but he could go to the test at Lords. And it was a wash-out! What he is now presiding over is a wipe-out in terms of Burnie. What we have got here is another case of the Newcastle syndrome. He will not confront the workers that he has abandoned. But he has made a call over the dispute, we understand. He has telephoned Premier Rundle with an offer of $3 million from the Natural Heritage Fund. What are we going to do: have parks and walkways created? That is cold comfort for the sacked Burnie workers. Three million dollars-this is the offer out of the Natural Heritage Fund. He is not even prepared to look realistically at a reconstruction package which we forced him to embrace, together with Bob Carr in New South Wales, in relation to the Newcastle closure. This is a Prime Minister who is not even consistent. What we have got, if the Minister for Social Security is going down there and if he has rung Premier Rundle to offer him some funds from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, is an admission of defeat-an admission that he is not prepared to do anything to stop the sackings. All he can do is come in after the event shaking his head, twitching his shoulder and say, 'There is nothing that could have been done.' Do not expect an apology from this Prime Minister. Do not expect an appearance. He does not care. 'Sorry' is not in his dictionary. One look at the Prime Minister's past involvement with the Burnie mill would give you no hope for believing that he was on the workers' side. After all, in the 1992 dispute, he was the one unctuously in this parliament saying that government should keep out of industrial relations but privately telling Peter Wadc of North Broken Hill, who then owned the mill down there, 'Go your hardest.' He even got himself thrown out of the parliament because of his passion and belief in saying that the government should be involved in sacking workers. What about the acting minister at the table, Mr Truss, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, the minister representing the ministcr for industry? The threat of the mill and its closure was raised with him on 30 January this year. He was down there in Burnie and, according to a report in the Advocate at the time, he said 'he did not believe the mills were near closing; if and whcn they were, his only commitment was that the government would look at the situation "in the light of events at that time.'" Those events are now occurring, Minister. What are you doing? Amcor proposes to close this mill in October. It needs more than you looking at the situation; it requires some action-a concrete plan. But, instcad, what did we get from you? You launched a vitriolic attack on the workers at risk of losing their jobs by blaming them. The headline that you got in the paper down there was 'Minister slams doomed workers'. A shameful headline. Let us hear what you said. This is from the Hansard of yesterday. This is what the minister at the table, Mr Truss, said: But let us look at the core of the problem. Many of the problems of that plant and indeed other manufacturing industries in Australia can fairly go back to the relations practices of the Labor government ... Indeed some of the things that were going on in that plant made the MUA look like a work gang. This is what you said. There were people in this chamber who saw the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) nodding and even saying, 'Too right!' in response to that assertion by you. This is what you believe. You believe that the company has untrammelled rights to do what it likes, to keep the workers in the dark and not consult them, then you come along and blame the workers. You did not lift a hand. It would seem from today's answers in the parliament-including those of the Prime Minister-that you are not prepared to lift a hand to do anything for them. The member for Braddon must be one of the most pathetic members in this chamber in terms of rcpresenting his constituency. The Prime Minister boasted yesterday that the member had spent a large part of yesterday morning in Melbourne meeting senior Amcor executives trying to persuade them to delay the closure. He was not trying to safeguard the workers' jobs; he was merely trying to delay the closure. Again, he was simply accepting defeat. He was not fighting for their survival, not fighting for a growth strategy, but running up the white flag. The member for Braddon spoke on ABC radio this morning. This is a beauty-this is how good he is at reprcsenting his constituents. He said: After my meeting with the company yesterday I believe that they are going to go ahead with closing down the pulp mill section. It must have been some fantastic set of representations. Here he is. He makes a special rush to Melbourne. He suggests to them, 'Don't stop closing. Let's sit down and talk, but just delay it,' and they even knock him back on that! What is the point of having him? Why not get someone like Sid Sidebottom down there who can actually represent these workers; someone who has got a commitment to their future and to that of the region? Sid Sidebottom, if you have not heard it before, Ministcr, will be the one hounding you. He will be the one reminding those workers of industrial your callous disregard, your propensity to blame them rather than find solutions. He is the person we need in this chamber to represent the workers of Braddon. They are not getting it from the current member. When the member for Braddon was asked what the company's response was to his request that the closure should only occur within 18 months, he said: Well they were not impressed with that idea. Here he is. He has run up the white flag. He put forward a suggestion for delay and he could not score on either proposition. In those circumstances, if you think you are going to be knocked back you at least go in and have a fight. You go in and represent your constituency. You do not run up the white flag, as this member has done. Chris Miles, the member for Braddon, is not the person we want representing Burnie in this place. The local mayor does not want him-the local mayor whom the Prime Minister wanted to quote today. He said: Well, I think there has been a lot of concern with the member of parliament up here, Chris Miles, that Chris hasn't done very much for the area, considering his position as a parliamentary secretary to the Prime Minister. The Mayor of Burnie wants Chris Miles out. What we want is a government committed to securing these jobs, a government prepared to work in partnership with industry and work force-a work force that has demonsupported strated its willingness and preparedness embrace change. But we want a strategy that gives us value adding, a strategy that gives future for the region, a strategy that a governThose ment should be behind-but this one will not get behind such a strategy. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Wide Bay-Minister for productivity. Customs and Consumer Affairs) (4.04 p.m.)--At last we have the matter of public importof ance-the one that Labor care so passionately about that yesterday they forgot to put it They care so much about the workers of Tastheir company. mania that they forgot to get their MPI in. They forgot about it. They care so little about the situation in Burnie that, when they had opportunity to raise it in the parliament, simply forgot. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) did not get around to it. Today question time we saw the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) bouncing up trying to get a question on this subject to demonstrate Labor's concern. But he was always interruptHobart ed by other people-his mates in the front got in the way because they had other matters that were more important to them. The workers of Tasmania rated last in Labor Party's questions today. They have concern whatever about dealing effectively with these issues or asking questions about the facts. It took this side of the House to have the matter raised in question time today so the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) could respond in a positive and sympathetic way to the concerns of the workers in Burnie. He indicated the government's determination to address the direct and immediate issues that are associated with the lifestyle and the future of the workers at that plant and indeed the people of Burnie. But more comprehensively the government will put in place a plan for the future of northern Tasmania; a plan that we would not have had to put in place had it not been for the neglect of this industry over many years by those opposite. I referred yesterday in the House to unsatisfactory work practices in this plant and indeed in many other workplaces around Australiaworkplaces that were aided, abetted and supported by the member for Hotham when the he was ACTU president. He agreed with and workers in work practices they to knew were unsustainable. Only this morning one of the union representatives acknowa ledged that those days have to be behind us. days must be behind us. In fairness to the workers, the employees at that plant and the management, over the last couple of years they have worked hard to improve their They looked at the sorts of practices that were destroying the profitability their company and therefore also their own jobs, and they were willing to work systematiin. cally towards improving the profitability of I said in my answer yesterday-which I an might add was acknowledged in the Daventhey port Advocate and many other Tasmanian papers but sadly not in the Hobart Mercuryin that the company should acknow ledge the contribution that has been made by workers and seek to find solutions to the problems which would secure their employment. The Mercury called my office today and acknowledged that that headline in the paper was a misrepresentation of the substance of my answer to the question. I find it most the disappointing that a Tasmanian newspaper no would seek to use the jobs of workers of Tasmania in such a political way. If we look back at the root cause of the problems that have been confronting the workers of northern Tasmania, I think the Prime Minister summed up the problems quite admirably on a number of occasions when he referred to the disgraceful deal done by the ALP and the Greens in Tasmania to destroy the Wesley Vale pulp mill project. Had that project proceeded, the workers of Burnie today would be working in one of the most modern state-of-the-art pulp plants in the world. Their jobs would not be at risk. Their jobs would be secure. They would be providing pulp to an expanding Australian paper industry that would have the capacity to export around the world. Instead of our paper industry declining and suffering serious competition, it would have had the opportunity to deliver best practice technology and meaningful and lasting jobs for northern Tasmanian workers. The Labor Party, when confronted with this opportunity for one of the biggest projects in Australian history, preferred to do a deal with Christine Milne and the Greens to secure preferences. The honourable member for Hotham was one of those who wanted the Green preferences because he was about to run for parliament for the first time in Melbourne. He preferred Green preferences to the jobs of the workers of northern Tasmania. In their determination to try to hang onto government, Senator Richardson and Mr Hawke, with the leadership no doubt in support of the member for Hotham and others, did a deal to wreck this project, to destroy the long-term viability of the paper industry of northern Tasmania. The member for Hotham preferred Green preferences in Melbourne to the jobs of the workers of Burnie in northern Tasmania. The member for Hotham a decade ago was prepared to back unsatisfactory work practices which he must have known were putting at risk the jobs of the people in this plant and in other plants around Australia. He preferred to allow those sorts of rorts to continue rather than confront the productivity improvements which were always going to be essential if we were to have a modern and progressive paper industry in this country. The workers of that plant in northern Tasmania know that now. They know they have a contribution to make towards securing their jobs. They know, as do the paper workers in Maryvale, Shoalhaven and a whole stack of other places, that they must work with their management to ensure that their industry is secure, that their jobs remain viable. Sadly, that realisation came far too late for the member for Hotham. It came far too late for the Labor Party. In 13 years they did nothing to address these critical productivity issues, and sadly the workers of that paper mill in Burnie are now paying the price for that indolence. Labor failed to do anything to secure the kind of industrial relations climate that was necessary, the kind of investment climate that would have been essential to secure the necessary investment to keep this plant operating effectively and to secure the future of the paper industry for Australia. Sadly, too much damage was done under 13 years of Labor for the workers of TasPEAC and others to correct that damage in the last couple of years. Sadly, those sorts of things have left the paper mill and the management of Amcor with the view that this mill can no longer continue to operate profitably. I am very disappointed that they have made that decision. I believe that considerable progress was being made to improve the productivity of the plant. It is true, as the company has indicated, that the plant is now quite old. In fact, it is more than 60 years old. It was working with outdated technology. There was a plan to get rid of that outdated technology to build a new mill of world class standard at Wesley Vale. Labor destroyed that possibility. Labor did a deal with the Greens to destroy that possibility. The inevitable consequence of that was that a small, inefficient, old, outdated technology plant at Burnie was put at risk and the jobs of those workers were put at risk. The company has been spending a considerable amount of money at Burnie and Wesley Vale-its other plant-to try to update the technology to make that plant competitive. But, ultimately, I am sure all will acknowledge that the company can only continue to make investments if they believe those investments are likely to be profitable. They also need to protect their investments in other parts of Australia. The big new plant at Maryvale will obviously substantially increase their production capability. They also have a plant at Shoalhaven that produces speciality papers which have a particular place in the market. The key thing is that the company, in making this announcement, has reaffirmed its commitments to producing base paper at Burnie and in other places around Australia. Its coated and film coated offset production at Wesley Vale will continue, and it is investing $49 million to increase the company's 20 per cent share of the coated paper market. So there is still a commitment to paper making in Australia. I think we have that commitment only because of the policies of this government. If Labor's antiquated anti-dumping mechanisms were still in place, if the old measures introduced by the previous government which failed dismally to provide the sort of protection that the Australian paper industry needed from unfair and subsidised products were still in place, if there was not in sight a likelihood that reforming legislation would soon go through the parliament to give us the fastest and fairest anti-dumping mechanisms in the world, if the government had not made that commitment, I doubt whether we would see this long-term involvement by Amcor in the paper making industry in Australia. They sought this protection from me and from the government, and we are providing it. The old measures-the slow cumbersome measures, the anti-dumping measures that Labor left in place, that Labor introduced in the first place but failed to do anything about, that the member for Hotham occasionally goes to Tasmania to criticise but never acknowledges he was a party to putting them in place in the first place and did nothing about correcting in his term in government-left us with the residue of his failed anti-dumping protection measures. We have acted spontaneously and quickly to bring those measures into place. We have responded to the needs of that industry and our action has been warmly appreciated not just by Amcor, the paper investors and the manufacturing industry but also by the workers of northern Tasmania. If you would like me to, I would be happy to produce letters from the unions and the workers of northern Tasmania congratulating me and the government on our actions in introducing these measures. But it is not just that alone. If you look at the kind of economic climate that Labor had left the major investors in which to make decisions about whether they should expand their operations in Australia, you will see where Labor really failed Australian industry for 13 years. Under Labor, business investment declined to its lowest level on record, and that was a clear demonstration of the failure of their policies. Under Labor, Australian productivity improvement was just 0.9 per cent per year-half the world average for this century. Under Labor, business expenditure on R&D as a share of GDP was 25 per cent lower than the OECD average. Under Labor, the manufacturing trade deficit blew out from $7.7 billion in 1982 to $27.5 billion in 1995. Under Labor, the manufacturing sector shed some 200,000 jobs. Contrast that to what has happened under this government: there has been jobs growth-even in northern Tasmania, which we acknowledge has gone through some difficult times. The Prime Minister mentioned in question time today that nearly 3,000 new jobs were created in the Mersey-Lyell region. That is indeed a record of achievement-the unemployment rate substantially lower than when Labor left office. This government has indeed been working hard, in cooperation with the paper manufacturing industry and indeed industry throughout Australia, to try to create the kind of environment which encourages investment and which rewards those who in this country have the imagination to ensure that our industry is able to grow and expand, to provide jobs for Australians, to boost our exports and to replace some of the. products that have been coming into this country. Only under a coalition government would this sort of economic turnaround be possible. Only under a coalition government can you achieve the industrial relations reform, the economic reform. Only under a coalition government can you achieve the sort of measures that are necessary to protect Australian industry from unfair dumping or unfair subsidisation. Only under this government can you have the kind of turnaround that establishes the sort of environment that encourages investment in the paper industry. We will not rush off and do secret deals with the Greens to knock off projects just to gain a few preferences. The Greens, I gather, are at it again. There are a number of major new projects being proposed for northern Tasmania and the Greens are once again threatening to block them. Will Labor once again do a secret deal with the Greens, as they regularly do in Queensland prior to the state elections-secret deals that we learn about months later-to try to extract Green preferences? The Labor Party were prepared to trade the jobs of northern Tasmanians for a few Green preferences. They are now prepared to trade the economic welfare of the people of Burnie in Tasmania for a few cheap political points. The member for Hotham will rush down and criticise and give plenty of advice from the side, but the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has been in there fighting for his industry, effectively representing it and ensuring that this government will respond positively and effectively to the problems confronting Tasmanian workers to ensure that that industry prospers in the future. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is very interesting that the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss), who has just spoken, did not give us one point on what this government is going to do for Burnienot one point on how we can achieve anything to assist Burnie. After being advised that Australian Paper have decided to close the pulp mill, which is a part of the Burnie operation in north-west Tasmania, they have also advised that the two paper machines at Burnie will stay and the Wesley Vale mill will continue its operation. This closure is another terrible blow for Tasmania. Once these jobs go from the pulp works at Amcor, it will take Burnie's unemployment rate from 10.6 per cent to well over 13 per cent. This has been one of the highest in the country and will be extremely difficult for the Burnie people. Burnie already has great difficulty in finding employment for much of its population, since many other businesses in this region have closed since this government has been in power. Not only have 180 jobs been lost here at the mill but there will also be support employees lost, maintenance employees lost and job losses for those who supply the wood to the mill and those in the community whose jobs are tied up with the production of pulp. This is an enormous impact in this very closeknit community--one that has over 35 per cent youth unemployment. Mr Fitzgibbon-How much?

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is over 35 per cent youth unemployment throughout the Burnie municipality. Some of the blame has to lie at the feet of the federal minister for customs, Warren Truss, for taking such an inordinately long time to deal with the anti-dumping legislation. The federal member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has done very little to make sure that the work has been done to cope with the ability of the businesses there to compete. These ministers have the hide to blame the workers for the closures-and that really angers me. They have attacked the workers there for the last 20 years, saying, 'It's your fault. If you are unemployed now, it's your fault.' Blame the victim; it is a typical tactic started by Malcolm Fraser back in the 1970s. It is this government's incompetence that has caused the company to close its doors, and it hangs around this government's neck. The federal government has failed Tasmania. It fails to provide a safety net when these disasters happen and it failed to assist Tasmania in its last budget. The state is suffering enormous difficulties and the federal government has written us off, as it did in its last budget. There are times when decisions need to be made swiftly and this is one of them. The simple fact that Burnie has been under threat for some time from the expense of making paper in an ageing mill versus the new up-todate technology at Maryvale has been too difficult for the company to overcome. Some assistance should have been forthcoming from the government. The loss of research and development funds has made companies look at ways of reducing costs by closing plants rather than ways in which plants could be used in further downstream processing or upgrading of processing. That is a product of this government.The Maryvale mill could have been at Burnie if there had been incentives when the company was making those sorts of decisions. If the member for Braddon had got stuck in there, he might have achieved that. We have had long delays in getting the regional forest agreements signed. The Labor Party had it almost finished in 1995, yet it was only signed off by the federal government late last year. There still has not been the necessary legislation-pointing to the government-to underpin the RFA process. The RFA process allowed us to build an industry plan to utilise forestry in developing value added products, creating more jobs and export from our forest industries. But this government has not sought to develop an industry plan or long-term strategy to ensure that this industry can be one of the leaders in the world. They are more interested in getting the raw product out of the state either as chips or as whole logs and as soon as possible. No value adding has been done-unless you consider chipping to be value adding. The last Labor government had an industry plan-the wood and paper industry strategy. They had an overall philosophy to support the development of a forest industry as a major sunrise industry for Tasmania, to compete on world terms with forest practices and timber development. This has all gone out the window since this government has been in power. The government has failed to drive this agenda. It has said that it would have legisla- Tasmania. tion in parliament by 30 June this year to underpin the RFA. We have not seen any detail of this and 30 June is fast approaching. Will it be like the signing off of the RFA, with a two-year wait and dozens of local people still waiting to receive some sort of assistance because of the terms of the RFA? Legislation is needed to drive the industry development in Australia. We cannot afford this 'quarry and export at all costs' mentality that afflicts this government. We need jobs, we need research and we need a strategy plan to follow in order to build and encourage other industries to develop. Amcor is very conscious of the difficulties this decision will cause Burnie. They have told me that they are accelerating the launch of their new film-coated offset grades to be produced in Tasmania and they are proceeding with the commissioning of the paper coated upgrade at Wesley Vale, supported by the supply of base sheet from Burnie. So there is a need to put in place incentives to make them remain in Tasmania and also to assist in the continuation of the Wesley Vale mill. The further development of the RFA is one way of dealing with this. I call upon this government to take some specific action, not just mouth the words we heard from the minister. I caII upon this government to compensate the people of Burnie by supporting in kind the magnesium site mine being proposed by Crest Resources Australia so that they are assisted to put this processing plant in Burnie rather than on the mainland. The federal government will need to help the state to ensure it can carry out the necessary approvals and environmental studies in the shortest time possible. I call upon them to immediately start negotiations and clear the way for the company to invest in Burnie. I also ask the federal government to keep discussions going with Amcor to ensure that they do not pull out of Burnie. These jobs are vital for the north west and the government's actions should not be put in the way to jeopardise these industries. By this I mean the anti-dumping legislation must be quickly finalised and incentives developed through a long-term strategy for the forestry industry in We also need to know whether there is . anything that can be done to utilise the plant which would otherwise remain idle. Can it be used for something else besides pulp? What are the options for manufacturing pulp besides going into fine paper? What work has been done on this? The federal government ought to be asking those sorts of questions and seeking to look for other avenues. This is what the member for Braddon should have done ages ago and that is what he should do now. It is time to act. Something has to be done. The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Mr Truss, today slammed the workers of the past 20 or 30 years at this mill, the people who are now retired and live in Bumie and surrounding districts. They should all feel pretty well kicked by this minister who said it was their fault that the mill has closed. He ought to apologise to them. He did not mention that the industrial relations environment before 1993 had a little bit to do with management and that that is why there was some disruption taking place-we remember that dispute. He did not bother saying that at the other end of my electorate down on the Derwent River, ANM's management went down a totally different path, had a totally different restructuring process and achieved major results. The workers in this mill have set up a consultative process. They have a health imd safety program which has reduced accidents. Since 1993, 600 jobs have gone, the maintenance contract has been settled and signed, productivity has increased and workers have worked together on the anti-dumping situation. There has been a lot of work done since 1993, but a part of this mill is still going to go. A lot more work could have been done and the member for Braddon stands condemned for not defending the mill workers over the last 20 or 30 years who now live in his electorate. They have been attacked by Warren Truss in a very unfair and unjust way. He should have put a statement out defending those workers. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (4.27 p.m.)-Today is a day of shame for the Labor Party. They stand absolutely naked on this iSllue, and I can tell you they are totally exposed on th-s issue. Political nudity by the Labor Party in this case cuts a very tragic figure in Bumie. Let us go back to the genesis of what is happening in Burnie today. I put this on a very square footing in regard to the situation that occurred in 1989. We have all accepted that the Wesley Vale mill went down the tubeMr Dargavel-We are III 1998 today, Sunshine.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Yes, I will come to that. I suggest you stay and listen. You live in Canberra and you would not understand a worker if you came across him. You would not know what it is to get dirt under your fingernails and you would not know what it is to get grease in your hair. But I understand the Burnie mill workers and I know exactly what it takes to do hard work. Let us go back to the details of this issue. It was the Labor Party which prevented new technology coming into this industry in Tasmania. They prevented it. This is what Graham Richardson said about the mill going down on 8 September 1989 in a letter to me: Therc is absolutely no reason for mc to apologise to anyone over the Government's handling of the Wesley Vale proposal. Rather, J am proud to be part of a Government which is prepared to take . . . decisions when proposed developments clearly threaten the environment. Let us have a look at the record. I quote what the CSIRO scientists said on 1 August 1990. The pre-eminent scientists in Australia said that it was not about the environment; there was not a factor in regard to the environment. I will quote both of them. Chris Fandry said: What the CSIRO report in relation to the Wesley Vale project says is that there is no known scientific evidencenone at all. . . that there will be any long tenn detrimental effect of pulp mills. What did Bob Johannes, a senior CSIRO scientist, say on the same day? He said: ... I reiterate, we have no scientific evidence to suggest that there will be any known environmental impact or effect on fish. Who did we have in here today saying it was going to affect the fish? The former President of the Australian Labor Party-trying to keep that line going. Here we have the top scientists in Australia totally rejecting that there was any scientific evidence to do away with new technology in the pulp mills in Tasmania. Yet Graham Richardson and the Labor Party were proud to do a deal with the Greens to scuttle new technology in Wesley Vale. Therefore, today we have this announcement by Amcor of the loss of 150 jobs, but it will not be that: it will be about 280 and will flow on to about 500. This is in industry that has a history of 60 years. Preparation should have been made fOf investment by companies to make sure there was money there for a new mill. Quite contrary to what the Labor Party is saying here today, I have been in the forefront of people wanting a new technology mill in northern Tasmania. I put it to Amcor even early on Tuesday morning of this week that they should consider building a new quality mill in that area. Again they rejected it. Of course, the unions now are getting on the coat-tails of that comment to say that they are out there fighting for a new industry in this area. Yes--coming after my representation to the mill. There is nobody in this parliament who has fought more for the forest industries through thick and thin so that the workers in Burnie and north-west Tasmania would have jobs. For the Labor Party to come in here and talk about being supportive of the mill workers in Burnie is absolute codswallop. There is no substance to their arguments at all. We have seen the record of their dealing with the Greens to skittle new technology. They did not want new technology. No, they just wanted a few votes in Sydney and Melbourne. That is what they were about. In Tasmania under their administration during their 13 years there were 17 inquiries into Tasmania-and no outcomes at all. There were the Helsham inquiry, the Lemonthyme national estate and the 1986 memorandum of understanding with the state government. What did they do with that? They walked away from that to buy votes from the Greens. What did they do in 1989? We know about the Wesley Vale mi1I debacle. Labor sent that down the tube. Then in I 992 they decided they would actually do something with the regional forestry agreement. By 1996 there was not even one agreement signed-not even one, four years on. Mr Barresi-They were going to do it.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Yes, in the 14th or 15th year. There were 13 years of Labor and nothing was done with the regional forestry agreement. It got into a debate there with Minister Beddall. Keating, of course, opposed what he was doing. Then they said, 'We are going to take certain coupes out of Tasmania.' When I went to the grid and had look at what they were talking about, do you know where those forest coupes were? They were out in Bass Strait. That is how much interest they had in Tasmania and the mill workers. What have we done? This is the record in two years. The degraded-forest licences were put into place. The amount of woodchips now being produced in the region behind Burnie has gone from 450,000 to 700,000 tonnes. That created 30 jobs and saved 110 jobs in the Burnie region. When it comes to the regional forestry agreement, this is going to create 1,000 new jobs. Under Labor we were shedding jobs in the forest industries. Under Labor in 1992 even the Burnie mill shed jobs, going from 1,324 down to less than 500. Seven hundred in one year went under Labor out of the Burnie mill. What have they got to sayÂ· about that? Not one word, of course. They come in here today in such an unctuous mood and do not actually suggest one dollar of support to Burnie-not one dollar, not one proposal. Their idea is to throw money at these projects and that will sort it out. That is what the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) would do, and we would have another DuPont, I suppose. They threw $60 million into Victoria and that project got closed down. They wasted $60 million. Throw money at it and get the political monkey off our back but don't care about the workersthat is Labor's approach. Of course, the DuPont project went down the tube. I am saying to the company in Burnie that they ought to be giving a lot more time for the closure of this mill, and it is outrageous that they are closing it three months before Christmas. How outrageous! They should be making sure that these people have jobs past Christmas.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The Labor Party have done nothing. There is no record whatsoever in regard to the Labor Party on this particular issue. There should be retraining programs for these people, and I am delighted that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has taken up my suggestion about having ministers go down to the electorate. We will listen to the mill workers down there. Remember, the Labor Party did not suggest one dollar of help to the Burnie people today-not one dollar-just unctuous words and yapping about the issue and not really addressing the needs of the Burnie pulp mill. If Labor had been in government, there is no way that they would have been able to do anything. They had a $10 billion deficit and it would have prevented them from doing anything. But our government has got rid of that deficit and we are in a position to do things which will benefit Australia. Mr Martin-Do it then.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: -We will do it in our time, not in the Labor Party's time. Labor's approach is deficit, debt and high interest rates.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Once again we see political grandstanding in this House with neither party having anything to congratulate itself on. I am interested in this debate because I live in the midst of the biggest dry sclerophyll forest in the world, from which we hope we can develop exports to the value of $300 million. I hope that can proceed very shortly, with high value added products. To go back to Wesley Vale, there is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that the Labor Party pandered to the Greens. There was concern about the fisheries but, without the advent of the atomic spectrum analysis machine, it would have been impossible to pick up any of the elements they said were going to be detrimental, because they are in such minute quantities. It simply was a bogus argument from the start, and it is quite clear that the Labor Party was pandering to Richardson, who was in tum pandering to the Greens. It is my view that Richardson is second only to Keating in the damage he has done to the Labor Party. This is an industry of enormous value to Australia. It is an industry that should be exporting $4 billion worth of paper product and not importing. When Labor closed down the industry in this country they drove it off to South-East Asia, where it has been burning ever since. They drove it off to countries where there is no control whatsoever-no semblance of management. The truth is that not one square inch of forest has been lost to forestry in this country. It has overwhelmingly been lost to farming and to rural sprawl. That is where the forests went, and that has to be considered. Mr Adams-There have been no species lost.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: In terms of species lost, that certainly has not occurred in forestry. In fact, in Western Australia they are planting 25,000 hectares a year. Whereas it took 50 years to plant the first 100,000 hectares, it will now be done in four years, and it is going to be very successful. The truth is that the forest agreements between the states and the Commonwealth are a nonsense. This is an area where the Commonwealth should get right out because it has no expertise. It is being driven by zealots with other agendas. The expertise in forests resides with the states, and Tasmania had a very good record in forest management. When the Labor Party was busy pandering to the Greens and closing down those forests in Tasmania, we were assured that workers need not worry because there would be jobs for them in tourism. You simply cannot transfer blue-collar workers to the tourist industry. But, in any case, once they had got rid of that industry, the Greens turned on the tourist industry. Their agenda was simply to stop anything happening in Tasmania and in forests in Australia generally. There was talk of anti-dumping, and it makes me sick. The anti-dumping position of this government is no better than that of the previous government and it is no good at all. We need a much quicker response and we need governments that look after the interests of our people, not after the interests of multinationals. I know this is a digression but it happens everywhere. It happens in the forest industry. In terms of pig imports into Australia, the pig is not coming from Canada; it is coming from ConAgra in the United States. It goes to ConAgra plants in Canada and comes to ConAgra agents in Australia. The government is backing multinationals against the interests of Australians. It is happening in the timber industry too, and for the government to look after the interests of people in Australia is long overdue. But what is to be done? We cannot go on blaming each other. Something has to be done for Tasmania. I think Tasmania has been neglected. The truth is that without a return to a manufacturing industry there is no future for Tasmania, nor is there any future for Melbourne-for a casino-led recovery will not last forever-and there is no future for South Australia. We get a lot of people from Tasmania, particularly from the Burnie area, coming to the electorate of Kalgoorlie seeking work. They are very welcome. If we could somehow reduce the flow of New Zealanders, we could take more Tasmanians. Let us just consider this: if Tasmania were to be given subsidies equal to those provided to the Northern Territory, you could pay for a new mill. There would certainly be more than enough money there to pay off a mill. It is quite clear that the future we are going to be a big player in the paper industry. It would not be a waste of money if the government were to get involved in this. It is long overdue that Tasmania got some of the consideration that is heaped onto and poured into the Northern Territory. The situation will not be helped by what has been said by either party. I think the company has been very neglectful. It clearly has not put much store by the chaos that is going to occur. This problem has not just arisen for the company; it must have seen it coming, and 1 think it should have made provisions beforehand. But governments have to pick up very often where the private sector fails. 1 think the government should give real consideration to doing something constructive for Tasmania. We have had the minister who was previously at the table-the Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles)-babbling about industrial relations and other factors. The truth is they are largely irrelevant. We need a regime where Australian industry can thrive. It will not thrive under a policy of economic rationalism. It simply cannot, because economic rationalism is not an economic policy; it is a political ideology. It is the ideology of big business, mainly American big businesses that control world trade. While the Labor Party and the government are hooked on this myth there can be no real hope. We, as Australians, cannot abide a situation where Tasmania, one of our earliest areas of colonisation, is allowed to wither on the vine. For those of us who have been to Tasmania, it is very sad to see the depressed areas of the state. I think governments have an absolute responsibility to take Tasmania with us, not to abandon it. I believe that every effort should be made by whatever means necessary to get industries into Tasmania. I suspect there is a lot of money to be made by value-adding timber in Tasmania just as there is in the Goldfields. We are looking now at markets in Europe for speciality timbers. There is a big market there for parquetry. I suspect that eucalyptus globulus would fetch far more money as a hardwood in flooring in Europe and North America than it does as pulp. We now have the techniques for drying it satisfactorily. Indeed, we import it into Australia as Chilean oak. If we were to spend money on marketing this, I am sure we could find markets for it in Europe, where there is a preference for lIght-coloured timber. Many of the other Tasmanian timbers would find ready markets in Europe. Just the hobby market alone-the woodturning market-is a vast market. In my looks at the forests in Tasmania I saw many timbers which should be exploited to those ends. Those are the things that we should do. We should be assisting people by very generous help, by whatever means is necessary, to make sure that we can get some value-adding into the timber in Tasmania. In conclusion, it gives me no pleasure to continue to rise in this House to point out that the policies of both sides have the same end consequences for the people.
