Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE
text: Cunningham) (4.51 p.m.)As I was saying some three hours ago in respect of the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998, the opposition will not be opposing the legislation but we do have some concerns about the way in which the government has broken yet another promise in respect of taxation. I just remind the House once again that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), when Leader of the Opposition, said that 'there will be increases in existing taxes' nor would there an introduction of any new taxes under his government. Clearly this is a broken promise because the departure tax is being increased. It is being increased by $3 from $27 to The justification which the government using suggests that it is to meet additional costs associated with the transit of people equipment for the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. The measure, accordingly, is going to take effect from 1 July 1999. This is one of two sneaky issues which were introduced in the course of the budget of a couple of weeks ago. Both go hand in glove. The second was, of course, the introduction of a new visitor visa charge. That is breaking the promise again because a new tax has been introduced to complement this increase in the departure tax. We will be saying more about that particular element when we examine whether a disallowance motion will be introduced into this House in respect of that new visitor visa charge. I foreshadow that the opposition is giving serious consideration to that element now, but as we are concerned about the departure tax I will confine my comments specifically to that. BILL 1998 In the budget of two weeks ago we saw the government stand in this place and triumphantly say that we have given $50 million extra to the Australian Tourism Commission to promote Australia overseas-specifically, $41 million to ATC to promote Australia in new and also tried and true markets for foreign tourists and $9 million to continue promotion for the 2000 Olympics. They stood in this place and said, and the Minister for Sport and Tourism (Mr Andrew Thomson) has been out and about saying, 'We actually listened to what people in the tourist industry were saying and we finally came to this conclusion' - a conclusion which the opposition had been putting forward for a number months, as had been the tourism task force and the Tourism Council of Australia, both peak organisations representing tourism interests in this country. The government have said that finally they listened. Late last year when the Asian economic no crisis was first gathering momentum, it was be suggested by those organisations to which T have referred that the first signs of trouble in Australia were being experienced in the tourist industry. As Christmas rolled around $30. and we saw airlines such as Qantas and is Ansett decide to no longer fly into Korea because there had been a 77 per cent drop in and Korean tourists coming into this country and Asiana Airlines and Malaysian Airlines decide to no longer fly into Cairns, you would have thought that the penny would have dropped with this minister for tourism and with the Prime Minister and they would have found some money to put into the Australian tourism industry to enable it to promote Australia as a destination in new and emerging markets and to try to reinforce it in some of our old tried and true markets. The numbers coming from Asia dropped off. As I have said, in the case of Korea they simply collapsed. In the case of Japan, one of our best tourism markets, the last figures I have seen show something like a 17 per cent drop in the number of tourists coming here. As those markets dropped, the Prime Minister's response was, 'We are not going to have any knee-jerk reaction in the way in which we'll respond to this crisis. And in the case of tourism they can simply switch markets. They can simply get out of Japan or Korea or South-East Asia. We will take the tourism dollars and switch markets and advertise in the UK, Europe or the United States.' Anybody who knows anything about marketing arrangements or the way in which budgets for organisations like the Australian Tourism Commission are set could not help but see the ridiculousness of those sorts of comments. You simply cannot switch the markets just like that. You simply cannot go in and say, 'We'll take our dollars and we'll look at advertising to promote more into Europe and the United States than into our tried and true markets of Asia.' It was an issue that the tourism industry came and saw the minister about and knocked on the Prime Minister's door about, but continued to be rebuffed. If it had not been for pressure from those organisations and, dare I say, modestly, from the opposition, we may not have seen extra funds injected in this last budget to try to overcome those difficulties, because there is, regrettably, a belief in the Australian community-and it is certainly mirrored in the minds of the present minister for tourism and of the Prime Minister-that tourism does not create real jobs in this country. It is an lute disgrace that that view is around and that the people who purport to lead this nation do not accept that one in nine jobs in Australia now is in the tourism and hospitality area. It is a disgrace that people do not recognise that $16 billion annually is raised through export earnings due directly to tourists coming into this country and that $65 billion is contributed to the gross. domestic product of Australia through the tourism and hospitality industry. There is unfortunately a view around that unless somebody is dressed in a blue singlet, safety boots and shorts they are not really a worker and they are not really in an industry that means something. This completely puts to one side the view that small business is dependent on tourism and that many of the organisations and businesses that are in tourism are small businesses. It completely puts to one side our friends in the Australian Customs Service, who play an integral role in the promotion of tourism into this country. It puts to one side all those airline employees, people who do the maintenance, bus drivers, chefs, front office receptionists, cleaners in hotels and people who run bungie jumping operations, yachts up on the Whitsunday Islands, cruises out to the Great Barrier Reef and operations at Uluru National Park. All of those people are contributing to the tourism infrastructure and employment of this nation. Therefore, it smacks somewhat strange to some of us that the government that would purport to say that it finally recognised that tourism is in a little bit of trouble is going to put $50 million-or more properly $41 million-into extra funding for the ATC. Members with a little bit of a memory can go back to the budget of two years ago, the first budget brought down by Peter Costello. He cut $18 million out of the budget for the Australian Tourism Commission. This is an industry which, as I have said, plays a significant role as an employer in this nation. Yet, $18 million was offered up as savings to the bottom line in the budget of two years ago. And belatedly we have seen $41 million being put back. As I have said, the Labor opposition and me specifically, as our spokesabsoperson on tourism, absolutely welcome the fact that money is being put back. But there are, as ever, a couple of hooks in this. When you go to the budget papers-and I was making some mention of this a little earlier-and specifically Budget Paper No.2, the 1998-99 budget measures, and look over the four years commencing with this financial year and going forward, you see that in 199899 it is expected that there will be a $10 million increase in the passenger movement charge, and for that read 'departure tax', generated for the government. In 1999-2000, a $21 million increase in the departure tax will be generated and in the year 2000-0 I a $23 mi Ilion increase, climbing in the year 2001-02 to $24 million. This makes a grand total of $78 million extra that will be generated by this $3 increase in the departure tax. You reconcile these figures and you see that the government is saying: 'We are going to put $4 I million extra into promoting over those four years Australia as a tourist destination in new and emerging markets and to rein force that view in other markets,' but the government is making $78 million over that same time. So clearly an additional contribution is being made by this increase in the departure tax. That increase is being offered up to the coffers of the government. And it gets worse. As I said a little earlier, the other side of this insidious approach to the Australian tourism industry is that the imposition of a new visitor visa charge of $50 per head in those countries where there is no electronic travel authority processing system is going to impact on our new and emerging markets. We had the Minister for Tourism, after he had been to Nagano, head into China, then on to India and then come home. When he came back, having met with tourism officials in those countries, he proudly announced to the Australian community, and particularly those in tourism, some very welcome news. He announced that China had granted Australia preferred destination status in terms of tourists. In a still fairly heavily planned economy, nations seek out that status, particularly from a tourism perspective. We went in and were aclively lobbying to get that slatus so that we could take advantage of that new market, with the increasing affluence of China, particularly southern China, where the economy is booming. As China was prepared to let Chinese tourists come into overseas destinations we were actively out there seeking that status as a nation. And we got it. So what did we do to say thanks to the Chinese for that? We said: 'When you come you are going to have to pay $50 now for a visa charge which was not there previously.' Then we said to them: 'Oh, and by the way, when you go it is now going to cost you $30 instead of $27.' Some thanks to the Chinese government for giving us the status that we had been actively lobbying for. Some thanks it was to say to them: 'Thanks very much, but by the way it is going to cost all of those people coming here.' If there is one thing this country does not need in times of economic crisis it is more disincentives in the tourism industry. It is bad enough that this government has imposed a 400 per cent increase in the reef tax in tropical Far North Queensland. It is bad enough that now we are going to see a $3 increase in the departure tax. But to also slug tourists coming into the place out of the new and emerging markets that we are trying to cultivate, like China and India, $50 a time for a visa fee which had never been there in the past is absolute nonsense. Is it any wonder that people like Bruce Baird, the Managing Director of the Tourism Council of Australia, is jumping up and down on behalf of his organisation about this, and has made representations to the minister? Is it any wonder that Mr Baird rightly is a touch put out because his mate in government, the Minister for Tourism, forgot to tell him about it? The Minister for Immigration (Mr Ruddock) forgot to tell him about it. They have dressed it up as a way they are supposedly keeping illegals out of Australia. To be fair, has anyone ever heard of anything more ridiculous than saying that putting a $50 visa charge on somebody who has the intention of coming here and then staying illegally is going to keep them away? How nonsensical is that! It is a straight out revenue raising measure. Whilst I said that the measure we are debating today to increase the departure tax will raise an additional $78 million over four years, the proposal to increase by $50 per head the visa charges will raise $167 million extra. That brings it to a grand total of $245 million that will be raised by this government over the next four years by charging $50 for visas and by increasing the departure tax-breaking two promises of John Howard's. The sum of $245 million and what are they going to spend?-$41 million. Even the economic geniuses on the other side would have to recognise that this means they will have a little bit left over. And wouldn't we all like to think that the money is going to be spent on some of the projects that are necessary, such as boosting the Australian Customs Service, providing it with a few more sniffer dogs and other equipment to detect some of the less important items people try to bring into this country, drugs or anything else. But it is not. It is just going come straight off the bottom line of this government. That is where the money is going to go. So that Peter Costello can stand up in here and say: 'Isn't it wonderful that we have delivered some sort of a surplus?' Yet it is being delivered off the back of the very industry that we are trying to encourage. It was also interesting, when looking at this issue, that on 1 August 1996 the Australian National Audit Office provided some information and also tabled an audit report on the passenger movement charge and the way in which the departure tax was administered, because two things emerged from that. Firstly, legal advice which was provided to Customs and to the Australian National Audit Office indicated that, in legal terms, that passenger movement charge was a tax. We all knew it was, but there were a few smartypants around trying to say, 'No, it is a passenger movement charge. That is code for "tax" but we are not allowed to say "tax".' Secondly, as I have repeated in here on a number of occasions this afternoon, the Prime Minister was very positive and very 'core' in his promise that there would be no increases in existing taxes and no introduction of new taxes. Both of those are out the window when we are talking about these two measures here. So it was established that it was a tax. Based on estimates that were provided by agencies, the National Audit Office assessed that departure tax collections in 1995-96 exceeded by approximately $19.1 million customs, immigration and quarantine processing costs and short-term visa issuing costs. What does that mean? It means that the National Audit Office did a check and found out that there was overcharging, if you like, or certainly that what it was costing these organisations to carry out these processes was giving a net benefit in revenue terms to the government even then. This overrecovery arose for two reasons. One was that the customs, immigration and quarantine costs and the passenger processing cost of issuing short-term visas actually were lower than the $27 per departure originally estimated, and that was back in 1996. It is not me saying this, it is the audit office, which carried out to this particular inquiry. The second reason was that the rate of growth and the number of departures had been higher than expected, adding more to the departure tax collections than to the passenger processing costs. If anyone doubts that, go and have a look at the audit office report entitled Passenger movement charge: Australian Customs Service published on 1 August 1996 and, for references, have a look at pages 8 and xiv. That will give you the references to those. Here we have, even in 1996, the audit office saying that what it costs to process the departure tax in Australia was giving the government a net revenue boost. What we are seeing now is that that departure tax has been increased by $3 a head for the reason that the government wants to pick up all of those additional people coming in for the year 2000 games and beyond. So they are going to get even more money. As we have established already, just on Treasurer Costello's own budget figures, the departure tax alone will give this government an extra $78 million. I think that is underestimating it, quite frankly. I know that the member for Fadden e Mr lull), who has a continuing and substantial interest and knowledge in the tourism industry, will substantiate those views-that there are likely to be increased numbers of people coming, certainly in the lead-up to 2000 and, we would all hope, beyond. We would all hope that the year 2000 Olympic Games and Paralympic Games will showcase this nation like never before and that we will see an enormous increase in visitors coming to this country in subsequent years. Whilst that will be great for employment opportunities in this country, it is also going to be great for the government because, on their own estimates, not only will they make that $245 million but r suspect they will be making a lot more. Whilst we find it a little sneaky to have done this and whilst it is disturbing that government has gone about reaping more money from Australia's important industry tourism, what we find even more staggering is the fact that they have hamstrung the Australian Tourist Commission. Why do I say this? It is interesting. In the Senate estimates committee hearing yesterday, the Australian Tourist Commission were there giving evipaid dence. I had asked Senator Cook to ask a few questions of the ATC as to how this increased funding that they had been given and that government had made so much of a fuss about was going to be spent. As r said to you, they are getting an extra $41 million over four years and in next year's terms I think the appropriation was to be $14.1 million. When questioned as to how that might be spent, in what markets and what value would there be for spending that money, it came to pass that the Australian Tourist Commission measured and estimated that the number of bangs they were going to get for their bucks in the United States was on the basis that the Australian dollar was worth 68 cents to the United States dollar. I do not know about you but I cannot remember the last time the Australian dollar was actually at 68 cents. r think at the minute it is something like 61 cents. Some of the estimates I have seen from economists in the papers today suggest it might go to 55 cents. If the Australian Tourist Commission in the United States is given, in Australian dollar terms, $14 million to spend and they are basing their advertising campaigns on a value of 68 cents in the dollar, they are going to be mightily short-changed. If they are talking about advertising in Europe or, specifically, in the United Kingdom, I think the UK currency is down to about 38 or 39 pence at the minute to the Australian dollar. So that is not going to buy you too much in terms of advertising either. I had the opportunity a few weeks ago to meet with the Australian Tourist Commission's managing director for Europe and the United Kingdom. We talked about this very problem and he said to me, 'We keep on getting the funds that the ATC makes available to us for advertising in Australian dollars and the when you convert it down you simply lose that advertising ability.' I think this is an of issue the government needs to consider. Unlike our people who work in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, for example, or in Immigration, who are in outposts overseas and get compensation for the cost of living in those particular locations, they are their salary in Australian dollars. When they convert it to the currency of the country in which they are living they simply do not the get an equivalent amount of money which enables them to live appropriately. Maybe the same sort of factor for correction needs to be put in here because, sadly, as was pointed out yesterday in the Senate estimates committee hearing that was looking at the Australian Tourist Commission, what it means is that that $14.1 million, based on the value of the dollar at the minute, is probably going to buy about $10 million or maybe even less than $10 million worth of advertising. r think that is sad. Simply because of currency fluctuations, the opportunity for us to advertise overseas is going to be lost. I hope the member for Fadden will have a few comments to make about that as well because he does have a great knowledge of the Australian tourist industry and would have made a great minister for tourism. It is unfortunate that he never got that opportunity. r think it is rather sad that when we come into this place to debate a broken promise by the government-an increase in the departure tax-we find that they have not been entirely honest with the Australian people and the Australian tourist industry when they did not tell them that even at the present rates, according to the Australian National Audit Office, they are actually covering their costs and having some left over already. Why couldn't that be put towards improving the advertising of the Australian tourist industry in other destinations? I think it is rather sad as well that, by increasing this, they are making a large slab of money which will not be directed at tourism but will simply come off the bottom line of Peter Costello's budget. I again put on the record, to quote directly from Labor's platform, that: Labor acknowledges that tourism is the fastest growing employment sector in Australia, particularly for young people. It is Australia's second highest export income earner and generates immense goodwill for Australia with overseas visitors. The advent of the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000 will add further emphasis to the important role tourism will play in promoting Australia internationgo ally. What the Australian tourism industry need is continuing assistance through these difficult times. They are not asking for handouts; they are just asking for a fair go. Unfortunately, the money that has been injected, whilst welcome, will not meet that objective, and the way in which it is to be collected-by the broken promise that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made with respect to increasing taxes-will not be welcomed by those people in the tourism i,ndustry. Nevertheless, it is a budget measure. For that reason-and for that sole reason-the opposition will not delay passage of this legislation.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE
text: I am not quite sure on how many occasions during my time in this place I have spoken about passenger movement charge amendment bills or departure tax amendment bills. I always feel somewhat guilty because the introduction of the departure tax came as a result of one of the first recommendations of the House of Representatives select committee in 1978, which I chaired. That first recommendation was that we introduce a departure tax and the money raised be used in the promotion of tourism. The then government were very enthusiastic about that recommendation, and it was the very first one they instituted. Going back over the years, we have quite an interesting history on this particular charge. There was great trauma and drama within the industry in the early 1980s when the departure tax, which was then $10, went to $20. A few years later, it was dropped back to $10. The amount has varied since that time. At $30, which the passenger movement charge will be after the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998 comes into force, it is in about the middle range of passenger movement charges around the world. In that respect, I would remind the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) that, when you look at the on-charges for the tourists coming to Australia and leaving Australia, it is far more expensive for a Japanese tourist to go to the United Kingdom where the passenger handling charge at Heathrow airport is, I understand, Â£45. If you to an airport like Denver in the United States the effective tax there is around $US40. These things get lost a little bit in the haze. I do not think that that is necessarily going to be the thing that turns people off coming to Australia. I do not disagree with him saying that the tourist industry is very price sensitive in that international market, and it is price sensitive in terms of developing some of those new emerging markets. But, at the end of the day, it is not always these charges that make the difference. You usually find it is the key components of what the airfare charges might be and, indeed, what the accommodation charges might be that determine whether or not people come to Australia. I would suggest that the member for Cunningham might look at some of the core fares-the tour basing fares-that presently exist between Tokyo and Australia and Tokyo and Honolulu. If you check the mileage of the distance between Tokyo and Cairns, it is 15 miles shorter than the distance between Tokyo and Honolulu. Mr Martin-And the same time zone.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE
text: And the same time zone. The last time. I checked, the tour basing fare-and I have not checked this for some time-from Australia was about $990. The tour basing fare that was operating into Honolulu was about $530. That is where the real difficulty is. While we can talk about these things and the disincentives that are there, in actual fact there are a number of components that make up the cost of a holiday and determine whether or not Australia is going to benefit from the visits that people are going to make. The member for Cunningham mentioned the tremendous impact that tourism has had on Australian employment, and that is true, with more than 600,000 people now employed in the industry. He mentioned the impressions that people have of Australia as a result of their visits and how that helps us around the world. But the tourism industry has more than that-we have a new export industry. In debates like this, we fail to mention not only the investment that has been made in hotels and the infrastructure of Australia but also the investments that have been made in education and the tremendous quality of the graduates of our TAFEs and our tourism and hospitality colleges-both in the private and public sectors-and what that is doing. I read an article just the other day which said that it is now estimated that there is in excess of 350 Australian chefs who are working in London. We have, in fact, developed an export market. Take the hotel chains like Ramada and Sheraton. Years ago, I used to get up here in the House and complain that every hotel manager in Australia seemed to have the name of Fritz or Heinz. In actual fact, if you go overseas now you find that the hotel managers have the name of Blue or Jack or Bill or Dick. The Australian impression that has been made in the international hotel industry has been enormous. I had some experience of this a couple of years ago when I was in the United States and stayed at a hotel in Washington. The young lass behind the desk was an Australian and I started chatting to her. She told me that the food and beverage manager of that hotel was an Australian, the general manager was an Australian, and her other friend on the reception desk was an Australian. One of the real difficulties we have is that a number of these international operators are sitting outside the doors of Australian education establishments. They are waiting to take these young people out and put them in the world. That is fine-I think it is wonderfulbut it does not necessarily mean that we are always getting the best out of our investment in terms of what is happening within Australia. I will get back to this bill and the money that is going to be raised. It is true that a lot of money will be raised. I agree with the honourable member for Cunningham-the fact that we have the Olympic Games coming up means that the revenue we are going to get in will probably be far in excess of expectations. It is also fair to say that investments have to be made in looking after the Olympic Games and in looking at the increased flow of traffic coming in. I have taken a particular interest in airport security in recent times. I know-obviously I am not going to mention it here in any technical sense-that the investment for airport security for the Olympic Games will be very extensive and very good. We are looking at some of the great state-of-the-art material-the post-Lockerbie material-that is available overseas now. We are going to make these investments and they are not going to be cheap. There is going to have to be a very real investment in the employment of further staff in areas such as Customs and the rest of it. I am not totally convinced that the money that we have indicated will be raised-and some of the extra-will benefit Australia in the long term and, most importantly, benefit the Australian image overseas. It is exciting when we talk about the increased flow of tourism at the Olympic Games that we are not talking about any significant numbers in the two weeks of the games. We are already seeing-two years out-the start of the movement as the advance parties move in. As more and more teams establish themselves here-and they will be established in Australia for quite some time leading up to the games-friends and families will start to move in and out of the country, building to an ultimate crescendo during the two weeks of the games. The great thing about the investment in the Olympic Games is that it is a long-term investment in tourism; we are going to get that build-up in tourism before the two weeks of the games. If we have half a brain, we will do exactly what overseas countries have done. It always amuses me that visitors to Munich on package tours have almost a compulsory visit to the 1972 Olympic Games site. Munich still attracts that attention. It still uses it 25 or 26 years later as a major tourism stimulus. That is where Australia has got this chance. Although I am a parochial Queenslander, I believe the decision to take it to Sydney was ideal. I hope that people realise the real potential for the promotion of Australia that that is going to bring. Can you just imagine the opening credits of the telecasts every day? If I had the rights to the telecast, I would make sure that I had a camera up in a helicopter and a camera out at the Heads somewhere. I reckon that the opening scene every day should be a big zoom-in straight down the harbour, through the bridge and into the Olympic site. That is going to do absolute marvels in bringing this image of Australia to millions of people around the world. That is where the real investment of the Olympic Games is going to play such a tremendous role in the future and provide so much wealth for Australia, and indeed long-term jobs. Another thing which has been raised in this debate and which was raised yesterday in the Main Committee in another debate is the decline of Asian tourist numbers. The member for Cunningham was quite right. I followed the figures leaoing up to the end of the year and I think I am right in saying that for December last year the arrivals figures were only down about 21/2 per cent on the figures of the year before. They were about 17 per cent higher than the December figures for 1995. It did come as a rush, as the numbers dropped out of Seoul and Bangkok. They declined a little out of Hong Kong. Japan stayed there. What concerns me now is that in recent months we are starting to see a decline in the Japanese figures. I understand that the latest figures would indicate that we are down about 14 or 15 per cent. They were pretty stable until the early months of this year but now they are starting to move down. I do not say this as any great criticism of the industry, or indeed the Australian Tourist Commission or governments of any administration, but a lot of time and effort were put into the development of the Asian tourist markets, and rightly so. For the period I was with the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation, we concentrated very heavily on Japan. We made that infrastructure and it built quite well. The pilots dispute came along in 1989 and the market wcnt bad. We went in again and we put tremendous concentration into that Asian market. In the 1980s we had some interest out of the United States, and those figures were quite good. We also saw the emergence of some quite unlikely markets out of Europe. For a while we were the flavour of the month out of Denmark and Sweden; that has gone down a little. The French started to pick us up as an international destination. We had some quite good figures out of Italy, and Spain was starting to develop. Since the recovery after the pilots dispute we have got a bit lazy in the intelligence we were gathering and the efforts we were making in developing new markets. Those new markets were not just China. I think we are fortunate that China has made us a preferred destination. Frankly, I do not think that we are going to make piles of money out of the Chinese market. It is pretty basic tourism and in terms of yield I do not think it is going to be as great as some people indicate. I think the Indian market certainly has potential. We have never really focused much beyond Asia, except for a couple of those traditional areas. One of the interesting markets that has been emerging for the last decade has been the South American market. It was interesting that during the time of the apartheid regime in South Africa, the Argentinians, and to a degree the Brazilians, were moving into South Africa in big numbers. They then switched into Europe and then started moving to the United States. The next move was obviously into Asia or into Australasia. We have never really seriously looked at trying to develop that market. Part of the problem was that there were no air links and, as far as the old Qantas regime is concerned, enough said. We just could not get them interested in looking at developing new markets at all. I think we have missed the boat to a degree on that South American market-they have started to look at going to other places. There might still be some hope, I think, with the tremendous relationship between Australia and Chile, for example, but we can build that up. That is an emerging market that is quite exciting. The other market that is really just starting to move is the market out of the Middle East, and that Middle East market is high yield. The stories we hear about the sheikh coming on board and taking over the entire first-class section of an aircraft with a cast of thousands behind him and taking over a couple of floors in a luxury hotel are quite correct. It does happen. I would hope that whoever may be in charge of the tourism portfolio and whoever may be in charge of the Australian Tourist Commission would look at developing markets such as that; not to get our focus away from Asia, but so that we do not become quite as complacent as we were about the way the Asian market started to develop and come forward. So there are some great challenges to the industry at the moment. It is good that the numbers from the United States and Europe have increased. Unfortunately, those numbers do not necessarily go into the places that need the help. We are feeling a bit of hurt in Surfers Parade and in Cairns in particular because of the downturns in the Asian numbers, and the European and the American markets are not necessarily going there in force. So it is going to be a challenge to make sure that we know what we are doing there. But it is a challenge that the industry have faced before; they have had their downturns in the past. I think it is a magnificent challenge. I just hope that the extra funds that will be raised from the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998 will go some way toward developing those new markets and making sure tourism remains one of our great export industries and the greatest generator of employment in Australia.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: PASSENGER MOVEMENT CHARGE
text: Wide Bay-Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs) (5.32 p.m.)in reply-I begin by thanking the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) and the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) for their contributions to the debate on the Passenger Movement Charge Amendment Bill 1998. It is always interesting to listen to the member for Fadden talk about travel issues and tourism issues. I am sure he is without peer in this place as a member with an understanding of these issues and the airline industry in particular. I have enjoyed his company on travels from time to time and his knowledge is truly outstanding. I also thank the member for Cunningham for his contribution and for the indication that the opposition will be supporting this legislation. This legislation implements the decision announced by the government in the 1998 budget to increase the existing passenger movement charge from $27 to $30 with a date of effect from 1 January 1999. The increase was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and will help to meet the additional costs associated with the transit of people during the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. The rate of the charge is fixed at an amount that covers the overall cost of customs, immigration and quarantine processing of international travellers. I noted the comments of the member for Cunningham when he queried, as a result of an audit report, whether or not there had been an over-collection of moneys. Subsequent discussions in relation to that audit report suggest that the system used to calculate the figures is open to question. The accounting system was not the usual one used for these sorts of circumstances, and that figure is, to put it mildly, open to question. The charge is imposed on the departure of a person from Australia. It is collected by airlines and shipping companies at the time of ticket sales and remitted to the Commonwealth in accordance with the arrangements entered into under the Passenger Movement Charge Collection Act. I think these arrangements have worked very well for all stakeholders and passengers have appreciated the fact that they no longer have to line up in a queue to buy departure stamps. The cost of their departure is covered by means of this new mechanism. The current arrangements with the airlines are due to expire on 30 June 1998, and the government is finalising negotiations with interested parties for new arrangements to apply from 1 July 1998 to 30 June 2001. The reason the bill is being brought forward at this time is so that these negotiations can proceed smoothly and also so that clear notice can be given to the industry of the increased charges to avoid the embarrassment of trying to collect additional amounts at a later time. I thank the House for the smooth passage of this matter and commend the bill to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Third Reading Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith. Bill (on motion by Mr Truss) read a third time. NA Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I have been saying for a while now that, as sure as night follows day, if this government is re-elected the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Howard) will axe Medicare. Tonight the axe hits another part of Medicare. Mr Bartlett-How can you say that with a straight face?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) interjects and says, 'How can you say that?' Tonight an axe wielded with David Foster like power will smash into the trunk of Medicare because in the next 90 minutes we will debate the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998, a bill which I believe is the beginning of the end of Medicare. It is the beginning of the end of Medicare because this bill means that, for the first time in Australia since Medicare was established, we will not have the five-year Medicare agreements with each of the states-the five-year guarantee that Medicare in public hospitals is there as the safety net for every public patient, wherever they may live, whatever their circumstances. This is a $29 billion bill which pays for hospital services, and it represents the complete failure of the Howard government to reach Medicare agreements with the states. Apparently the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) can negotiate health care agreements with New Zealand and Ireland but cannot negotiate health care agreements with his own Liberal and National Committee party colleagues in the states. He certainly Membership cannot negotiate a Medicare agreement with the state of New South Wales. The acting minister gave us a 20-line second reading speech for a bill that is to allocate $29 billion to the states. It is clear to anyone that this government does not care about public hospitals; public hospitals that serve two out of three Australians for most BILL 1998 surgery and almost every Australian for emergency care. As we pointed out in the last couple of weeks, the budget provided not one extra dollar for public hospitals that was not on the table when the Premiers walked out of the Premiers Conference two months ago. It seems that this government has come to the conclusion that it does not want Medicare agreements. It hates Medicare so much that it cannot even stand to have the name 'Medicare' in the title of this legislation. That is why we know that, if this government is re-elected, as sure as night follows day, this mob will axe Medicare. It wants to go to the election without having signed any Medicare agreements, and it wants to have a free hand afterwards. That should send a chill down the spine of every member of this House. We have had a few indications lately about what the government really thinks about Medicare and public hospitals. On 21 May the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said that he thought people getting treatment in public hospitals was a problem. The Treasurer said that he thought a good public hospital system is some place where people who cannot afford to get medical care should go. That is not what we on this side of the House think of public hospitals. We think public hospitals are the safety net for Australians, no matter what their circumstances. It is the safety net that twoÂ·-thirds of Australians arc placing their faith in. Mr Bartlett-It was one-third before you guys got into power.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: It is the government of which you are a member that has cut the federal funding for public hospitals by $800 million. Mr Bartlett-That is rubbish.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: You go and talk to the people at the Blue Mountains hospital or the Nepean hospital or the Hawkesbury River hospital about the pressure that their hospital is under because of the federal cutbacks that your government has made. You come into this House and vote for cuts that have affected the hospitals in your own electorate, and you cannot walk away from your own personal responsibility for supporting these cuts in fcderal funding for public hospitals. That is why Maggie Deahm will be the next member for Macquarie. She will be re-elected as the member for Macquarie at the next election because you have failed in your responsibility to speak up for your constituents.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Mr Mossfield}-Order! I ask the member to direct his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: We on this side of the House believe that the government has a responsibility to make sure that the public hospital system is looking after those public patients. The Howard government wants to leave the way clear to impose up-front hospital charges at public hospitals if they get re-eleeted, this bill allows them to do it. We are not prepared to let that happen, and we do not trust this minister to stop it. We will be moving an amendment to the bill in the consideration in detail stage to ensure that that cannot happen. I am quite happy for copies of that amendment to now be circulated in the chamber. 1 foreshadow that that amendment will be moved when we get to the consideration in detail stage. If the government is not prepared to accept the amendment, they will have made it clear that their intention is to allow are-elected Howard government to introduce compulsory charges for public patients in public hospitals. We know that the Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong, has always hated Medicare. We know it is something that he has always opposed. Let me remind the House of some of his most famous utterances on Medicare: Medicare has been an unmitigated disaster ... Radical surgery will be perfonned on Medicare ... The second thing we'll do is get rid of the bulk-billing system. It's an absolute rort ... We'll pull it right apart. That is what the member for Bennelong said about Medicare. Mr Truss-Was that 19857

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: It was only two weeks ago that Peter Costello said that he intends to reengineer the health care system. We have the Prime Minister saying that he wants to pull it right apart

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Hon. N.M. Dondas}-Order! I would ask the honourable member for Dobell to direct his remarks through the chair, and I would ask the minister not to aggravate the honourable member for Dobell.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Thank you for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker. As recently as two weeks ago, we had the Treasurer saying that he would re-engineer the entire health care system. We had the Treasurer saying that he wants to introduce a system of no claim bonuses in private health insurance. In some way he thinks that human being's bodies are the same as motor vehicles. The elderly and the chronically ill are the greatest users of the and health care system. They will be the ones hardest hit by the Treasurer's intention to introduce no claim bonuses into private health insurance. At the end of the day this bill, in allocating $29 billion, is providing inadequate funding for the Australian public hospital system. It is not just the Labor Party that is saying that; the states in their submissions to the Senate inquiry into the Medicare agreement stated that 1.4 million patients are not funded over the five-year agreement of the offer. We have the AMA stating that it is quite clear that there will be a doubling in the waiting lists. Let me remind the House of what the AMA had to say. According to Dr Robert Hodge, one of the AMA's federal councillors: Public hospital waiting lists will double in a few short years unless the Commonwealth dramatically lifts its funding offer ... He further stated: If no more money is offered, hospital waiting lists will blowout and the quality of care doctors are able to provide will be compromised. Some 116,000 Australians are on hospital waiting Iiststhis is likely to double over the next few years unless a better deal is struck. Consultations with colleagues in all states over the past few weeks has demonstrated a deep and unprecedented level of concern among surgeons working in public hospitals. People arc waiting in corridors to get access to hospital beds, less and less elective surgery is being undertaken and teaching and research is being lost, particularly in out-patient departments. So it is quite clear that the AMA has very serious concerns about the government's inadequate offer. We have a former leader of the Liberal Party, Dr John Hewson, completely dismissing the government's claims that this offer represents a 15 per cent increase in hospital funding. Dr Hewson was quoted on The World Today on 13 Mayas saying: Well it's true, on the numbers there's a 15 per cent increase, but if you allow for things like population, if you allow for the aging of the population, if you allow for the service delivery considerations, that 15 per cent shrinks to 1 per cent, and that is why the states are screaming. That is why public patients are going to be hurt by this government's inadequate federal funding for public hospitals. On the Face to Face program of 17 May we have the minister for health stating: If you take age out; if you take population out; if you take any drop in private health insurance out; the is 1.5% per year, so that's 7.5% over 5 years ... We have the minister for health disputing the Prime Minister's claims that it is a 15 per cent increase. The minister for health pulls the rug out from underneath his own claims that this is a 15 per cent real offer. It is clear that the minister's press secretary winds the minister for health up every day and then sends him out for his doorstops. Is it any wonder that the minister is getting into so much trouble when we have comments such as this one reported by the ABC, who ran a story on Tuesday,S May, which stated: The office of Federal Health Minister Michael Wooldridge now says that Government's patience may run out and it could change its offer of payment. We have the health minister making it clear that one of the weapons he intends to use to bludgeon the states, to take the axe to Medicare, is to actually cut the amount which is currently out there on offer to each of the states. This is despite the fact that on 23 March the Prime Minister said: ... I make it very clear to the patients of Australia and to the public of Australia: you will not suffer because of the petulance of the Premiersthis is when they walked out. He continued: Every single dollar contained in the offer that we made will be delivered in full and on time. The minister for health's press secretary winds him up like a sort of clockwork toy and sends him out. The minister for health and his office is out there saying that the offer to the states is going to be cut because this minister for health has lost patience with the states. So we have the press secretary to the minister for health overruling the Prime Minister's guarantee that every single dollar of the offer would be provided to the states. One of our concerns is that this very bill does not comply with the Prime Minister's undertakings. We had the Prime Minister stating that every single dollar of that offer would be delivered. This bill does not meet the Prime Minister's offer. The Prime Minister said that the payments to the states would be indexed according to a whole number of factors, including declines in private health insurance. This bill is a lump sum each year. There is no indexation; the increase offer that the Prime Minister made that every single dollar would be provided to the states in full and on time is not provided for in this piece of legislation. Someone is misleading the Australian people and someone is misleading the health ministers of each of the states and the ies. We know who that person is: it is the Prime Minister, John Howard, the member for Bennelong, who at the Premiers Conference said that every single dollar would be delivered. But the hill that has been introduced into the House does not comply with the undertaking that the Prime Minister has given. If you look in detail at the offer, it is ludicrous for the government to claim that there is a massive increase in funding. They have got dodgy figures all through this package. They have double counted the funding for mental health and palliative care; they know that there is $479 million for mental health and palliative care in this offer and they know that this area was not included in the last Medicare agreement. They claim that there is a substantial increase in the new Medicare agreement hecause they have brought mental health and palliative care funding into the tent. It is a clear demonstration of that old saying that there are lies, damned lies and statistics. This government's claim that there is a 15 per cent real increase in federal funding for public hospitals is worse than a damned lie; it is quite clear that they have doubled counted the funding for mental health and palliative care. Veterans' Affairs funding has also not been in the Medicare agreements before, and only 45 per cent of veterans currently usc public hospitals. We have had the massive cuts to federal funding of public hospitals in the last two budgets-$800 million in 1996 from the forward estimates, and another $400 million from the state health budgets and the aholition of the Commonwealth dental health program. It is very clear that the government has abandoned the Medicare agreements to give it the flexibility to take the axe to Medicare if it is re-elected. The real concern is that this government's inability to sign agreements with each of the states and territories before I July leaves Medicare and the protection for public patients in public hospitals completely at risk. Because there is no hinding agreement with the states, there is no certainty whatsoever. The only limit in the bill is in the maximum amount the Commonwealth can pay the states. territorThere is no minimum amount which this minister can provide each of the states and territories under the legislation before the House. Every year, each of the state health ministers will be at the whim of the federal minister for health. He has already shown he has no intention of keeping the Prime Minister's promise about making sure every dollar is delivered on time. So every year we will get the same round of bickering and acrimonious negotiations, which are not just bad for the public health system but disastrous for planning for public hospitals and a nightmare for patients, who are the ones that really suffer at the end of the day. This minister has run the length and breadth of the country claiming that this package is about reform in health, but there is no reform in this bill at all. One part of the minister's reform plan was the national development plan. This was supposed to be capital funding for structural reform, but the minister sold out his own plan when he gave Queensland a pre-election bribe and turned this money into recurrent funding-completely contradicting his own guidelines for submission based project funding. Because this minister has been unable to negotiate, his fancy talk about reform has come to nothing. He cannot bring about change in health unilaterally. The minister should soon start to learn that you can only negotiate these things in a rational and trusting way, not in a way that seeks to bludgeon the states to the negotiating table. I would now like to turn to the three Medicare principles which have been put into this piece of legislation. They have been rewritten in such a way that a strict literal reading of them would make it impossible for any state to comply with any of them, ever. For example, principle I states: Eligible persons are to be given the choice to receive, free of charge as public patients, health and emergency services of a kind or kinds that are currently, or were historically, provided by hospitals. What is an example of a service which was never so provided? I would like the minister to tell us when he sums up. Give me an example of some medical service that has never been provided at some stage by hospitals. There is no time limit on this. How far back are we going to go to look at the role of hospitals in each of the states and territorics? If you compare it with the previous principle in the former Medicare agreement, it states much more simply: Eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients. Turning to the second principle, the ministcr's new version in the bill states: Access to such services by public patients free of charge is to be on the basis of clinical need and within a clinically appropriate period. I do not think anyone has met that particular principle yet. The new version of principle 3 states: Arrangements are to be in place to ensure equitable access to such services for all eligible persons, regardless of their geographic location. That is also so wide ranging that I doubt any state health system meets that principle cither. Compare that with the old principle 3, which stated as follows: To the maximum practicable extent, a state will ensure the provision of public hospital services equitably to all eligible persons regardless of their geographic location. What they have deliberately done is to broaden the principles in such a manner as to make them meaningless. The effcct of these new principles is that the minister can choosc himself whether (jf not to pay who he likes and when he likes. This legislation thcreforc has no meaning whatsoever. It is no guarantee to the states or to the people who are out there working in the public hospital system that federal funding will be maintained. It leaves the way completely open, if this government is re-elected, for the radical surgery that the Prime Ministcr proposed for Medicare back in 1987. The old Medicare principles were less general and less open to ministerial fiat and ministerial interpretation. The government has deliberately broadened the principles to such a ridiculous extent that, as I say, thcy are trying to render them meaningless. Once again, this applies to up-front hospital charges as well and we believe that there is no guarantee whatsoever on that. That is why we will be moving our amendments in the consideration in detail stage, to try to ensure that public patients have a guarantee that they will not bc hit by compulsory charges no matter what this government se-ks to do. For those reasons, we believe that this legislation is an outrage. The future of Medicare is to be decided in a 90-minute debate in the House of Representatives, a 90minute debate that is going to commit the Australian taxpayer to spend $29 billion. For all the people out there who know that their local public hospital is under pressure, this is what this government thinks of you and your local hospital: 90 minutes on a Wednesday night; 90 minutes to allow all of those concerns to be dealt with by the national parliament; 90 minutes to determine whether or not their inadequate and measly $29 billion is going to address the pressures and concerns that are out there due to the crisis in the Australian public hospital system. Come the next election, members of the government will each individually be held accountable for their neglect of public hospitals, for their attacks on the public hospital system, for their obsession with private health insurance, for wasting $1.7 billion on private health insurance while the public hospital system lurches from crisis to crisis. They are the people who will be held responsible for the fact that the Australian public hospital system is not going to receive the funding that it so desperately needs.

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Macquarie) (5.57 p.m.)The hypocrisy and deceit of the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) is astounding, even by Labor Party standards. I think he spent too long reading the Labor Party campaign manual and not enough time researching the facts. I suggest the member for Dobell might take a look at the budget papers to correct some of the rubbish he has just sprouted about supposed cuts in health care funding. Let me inform him of these facts. In the last year of the Labor government, Commonwealth government funding on hospitals was $5.49 billion. In the first year of the coalition government, it rose to $5.61 billion, in the second year to $6 billion and in this recent budget to $6.7 billion. That is an increase of $600 million over the first two years or, counting this next year, an increase of $1,244 million in Commonwealth government funding to public hospitals. If you look at the total health care budget, the rise is even more significant. In Labor's last year, Labor spent $18,633 million. In the coalition's first year, it was raised to $19,294 million, in the second year to $20,734 million and in this year's budget to $22,273 million. That is an increase over those three years of $3.6 billion. Even the member for Dobell should know the difference between an increase and a decrease. If it rises in three years by $3.6 billion, it goes up, not down. That, for the member for Dobell, is an increase, not a decrease; it is an addition, not a cut. I am sure even the member for Dobell would understand that an increase of $3.6 billion is a significant increase in government funding for the health care system. The Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 is necessary because of the Premiers' refusal earlier in the year to accept the Commonwealth's five-year health care agreement. It delivers in full the health funding offer madc at the Premiers Conference in March. As the Commonwealth is unwilling to wait any longer to ensure the continuity of funding for state hospitals, it is necessary to introduce this supplementary legislation. In other words, the government has to introduce extra legislation to overcome the petulance of the state Premiers and to ensure adequate funding for public hospitals, in spite of the stunt of the Premiers and in spite of the stunt of the member for Dobell. Two main points need to be made in this context. Firstly, contrary to the deceit of the opposition, this government is committed to maintaining the integrity of the health care system and of the public health system. This involves both maintaining Medicare and ensuring a workable private health system. It is imperative that all Australians, regardless of means and regardless of circumstances, have access to quality hospital services. The coalition is committed to exactly that. It is committed to maintaining Medicare. I say again for the members of the opposition: the government is committed to maintaining Medicare. The government is committed to ensuring universally available acute health care services. This supplementary legislation before the house demonstrates that commitment, in spite of the lack of cooperation of most of the state governments and in spite of the posturing of the opposition. The bill includes a prerequisite, for the states to receive funding under this bill, that they adhere to the principles of ensuring universal access to health and emergency services free of charge on the hasis of clinical need and within clinically appropriate periods, regardless of the patient's location. It is worth again noting the details of the five-ycar Medicare offer that was rejected by the Premiers and that was just criticised inaccurately and incorrectly by the member for Dobell. This offer was a very fair and very reasonable one. The offer was for $30.17 billion over the next five years, up from $24.99 billion in the previous agreement. That is an increase of 15 per cent in real terms over Labor's forward estimates. This is a significant point: not only was it an increase over the past agreement, not only was it an increase over what Labor last negotiated, but also it was an increase over Labor's own forward estimates. Those were estimates they could not have met themselves, but they are cstimates which we are not only meeting but in fact exceeding. The offer includes an II per cent increase in the base level funding. It also includes significantly an indexation factor to covel' increasing costs. This is important in light of the distortions by the member for Dobell. This indexation covers factors such as the growth and ageing of the population, the increasing costs of hospital services and, importantly, any reductions in private health insurance. It also includes, on top of that increase in the base level of funding, $500 million for mental health and palliative care. In addition to that, it includes another $750 million to fund veteran health care at full cost over the next five years. Not only is this a great boost to the veteran community, including the extension of the gold health card to another 50,000 World War II veterans, but also it takes some of the pressure off the public hospital system. The package also included $500 million for projects aimed at restructuring the health care system. I note that the Queensland and ACT governments have accepted the $23 million offered under the critical and urgent treatment waiting list scheme of the $120 million offered. The needy in the other states are missing out. Yet the member for Dobell would encourage the other Premiers to stand firm and encourage them not to accept that offer and encourage them to maintain the lengthy waiting lists and encourage them not to accept this extra $120 million that the Commonwealth government is offering to immediately reduce the waiting lists in state public hospitals. The second point that needs to be made is that a quality and affordable health care system requires also a viable private health care system. I am sure that even the member for Dobell would accept that without it there is an unsustainable burden on the public health care system. Before Labor came into office in 1983, Australia had a good health system, a workable combination of private health insurance and free public hospitals. It was based on the right principle: if you can look after yourself then you take some responsibility to do so; if you cannot then the public hospital system is there. Both the private and the public system were of high quality-high quality public hospital care and affordable private health insurance. Then the Labor vandals and wreckers got their hands on Australia's health care system. Thirteen years of Labor saw a steady assault on the quality of our health system. In 1983, over 63 per cent of Australians had private health insurance. By 1996, when Labor was thrown out of office, that figure had declined to close to 32 per cent. This disastrous decline was a result of a number of policy disasters, enacted either out of sheer ignorance by the Labor Party or else in a premeditated desire to destroy the private health system. Early in its time in government, Labor removed the tax rebate on private health insurance premiums, thereby significantly increasing the real cost of premiums and causing an exodus from private health insurance. I note Labor's desire to remove the current $450 private health insurance rebate and thereby accelerate the decline in private health insurance numbers. Other decisions in those disastrous 13 years, such as a withdrawal of the bed day subsidy and the withdrawal of the reinsurance pool contribution, also added to the cost of private health cover and hastened its decline. The ideologically blinkered approach may have warmed the hearts of the Labor Left but put growing pressure on the public health care system. There is an estimated rise of $100 million a year on' the cost of running the public hospital system for each one per cent drop-out in private health insurance cover. Thus, Labor's failure over their 13 years-in spite of the warnings by their former health minister, Graham Richardson, that something had to be done to address that decline-to halt the decline in membership from 63 per cent to 32 per cent has added $3.1 billion a year to the cost of running the public hospital system. Because of the ideological obsession of the Labor Party, they have added such an unsustainable burden on the public system that it is costing the public system an extra $3.1 billion a year to cater for the extra numbers in the public health care system. A number of state health ministersincluding, significantly, Dr Refshauge-have admitted in recent weeks that this decline in private health insurance has been one of the problems. They acknowledge that the decline in private health membership has placed an intolerable strain on the public system. We have Dr Refshauge on one hand admitting that we need to prop up the private health system to reduce the strain on the public system and we have the member for Dobell on the other hand trying to tear it up. This is typical of the member for Dobell and his colleagues. They are out to destroy the private health system completely and to exacerbate the growing pressures on the public hospital system. They are more interested in ideological purity than in the health care of the Australian community. This is a demonstration of their shameful ignorance and incompetence. On this issue, as with many others, Labor is driven more by point scoring than by genuine policy debate; driven more by ideological obsession than by sound policy; driven more by political ambition than by any concern for the common good. This government is committed to Medicare. It is committed to ensuring health care for all the needy and it is committed to building a health care system that is workable. This government's commitment stands in sharp contrast to the hypocrisy and nonsense that we have heard from the other side.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Jagajaga) (6.07 p.m.}-We now know the truth about this government's commitment to Medicare. It does not exist. As the previous speaker, the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett), has quite clearly indicated to the House, he wants to go back to the system we had pre-Medicare-pre-1983when two million Australians were without any health insurance coverage whatsoever. The member for Macquarie has made it quite plain to the House that the government wants to go back to a system where we had to rely on private health insurance, and public care was available only for the needy. I think that is how he put it at the end of his statement: public hospital care should be available only for the needy. We on this side of the House do not think that is the sort of health system we should have in this country. That is the system they have in the United States, and what is the situation there? They have 40 million people without any health insurance coverage, and it costs that country twice as much for health care as it does here in Australia. Labor is committed to Medicare and we want to s.ee it strengthened; we do not want tOe see it, whittled away. We do not share this government's obsession-and I would have to say that there is no other word for it-.. - with private health insurance. The job of the health minister should be to make sure that Medicare works and that people can get hospital care when they need it-not have an obsession with private health insurance. That is not the main game. The main game is making sure that there is sufficient funding for patient care, wasting taxpayers' money on private health insurance subsidies, which their very own Jeff Kennett has called 'money down the drain'. This is the question the member for Macquarie should be able to answer: why is it that every previous Medicare agreement has been signed but this time the Premiers know that the amount of money being put forward is just not enough to make public hospitals pay? With all previous Medicare agreements, the states signed up, but not this time. It is not by any means the case that all the state Premiers are Labor. It is the Victorian Premier who has been very outspoken, along with his Liberal colleagues. I do not want to let the state governments off the hook, because the states do carry a significant responsibility to fund their public hospitals properly. The Kennett government did significantly cut public hospital funding in Victoria when it first came into office, but that does not mean that we should have a situation which leads us to debating this bill tonight. We are debating this bill because this government is incapable of getting the states to sign Medicare agreements. For hospitals like the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre, which was technically bankrupt earlier this year because of the cuts of the Howard and Kennett governments, in my electorate, it will mean that they have no security about their future funding. There are two things I would say to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) in the context of this legislation. If it is the case that we are not going to have Medicare agreements but just have hospital funding paid directly to the states without the states signing agreements, what is this government going to do to stop the massive privatisation of public hospitals that is going on around the country? Let us have a look at the real impacts of the privatisation of these hospitals. In Western Australia we saw the privatisation of a public hospital, the Joondalup Hospital. Less than two weeks after it was officially opened, it was decided to cancel elective surgery for public patients. What did this government, which says it is so committed to public patients, do to the Western not Australian government to make sure that this closure did not affect public patients? Absolutely nothing. As the memo from this hospital shows, the closure of wards was to affect only public patients. The government did absolutely nothing to make sure that public patients would retain their access to this hospital. This is the first indication of the development of a two-tiered health system in this country. This move is going ahead in leaps and bounds in my own state of Victoria. An article in the Age on 7 May this year reported that doctors from Sale, Maffra and Heyfield hospitals were writing to the state minister saying that they are very concerned about those hospitals having to reduce medical services so that the privatised Latrobe Regional Hospital could make enough money. The state government has given the private owner of the Latrobe hospital-Australian Hospital Care Pty Ltd-a 20-year monopoly on public health services in this area. The doctors in Sale, Mafti'a and Heyfie1d are very concerned that public hospital access to essential services in those towns is going to be reduced. In my own electorate, the biggest privatisation of all is taking place. The Victorian government recently advertised for a registration of capability for the privatisation of the Austin and Repatriation Hospital-the proposed basis of private sector involvement to build, own and operate that hospital. We in the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne are very concerned at that change. What I would like to know from the minister is how he intends to stop the privatisation of the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre so that the people of the north-eastern suburbsMs Worth- Mr Deputy Speaker, I move that the question be now put. Mr Lee-You can't do it in the middle of a speech. It is customary to let someone finish their speech first.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I will put two questions to the minister. What is the minister going to do to stop the privatisation of the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre so that the people of the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne can continue to get public hospital care when they need it? I would like to call on the minister to make a decent offer to the states so that the Medicare agreements can in fact be signed, so that public patients in all of our hospitals, particularly those public hospitals that are being privatised in Western Australia and in Victoria, will know that they will not be charged for essential health care. Without Medicare agreements no public patient can be guaranteed that they will not face charges. This government seems as if it is just going to sit on its hands and watch major teaching hospitals being privatised around this country to the absolute detriment of essential health care.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: COMMITTEES
