Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The 1998 aEeD Economic Surveys report into the well-being of the Australian economy made two important observations about the state of our domestic health care system. The report indicated that the two factors which had brought about persistent increases in health expenditure over the past decade were the lack of incentives for public hospitals to improve the efficiency of service delivery and the steep decline in the number of Australians covered by private health insurance. It is in the context of these issues that I wish to discuss the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998. This bill seeks to earmark more than $29.5 billion over the next five years towards the cost of health and emergency services in the states and territories. This represents an increase of 15 per cent in real funding over the life of the yet to be renegotiated Medicare agreement. Given the coalition's current fiscal consolidatio- program, this should be judged to be both fair and an attractive offer. Despite this, state government leaders in attendance at the March 1998 Premiers Conference deemed it appropriate to walk out on discussions with the Commonwealth government because they were not satisfied with the amount on offer. They did so believing their bargaining power to be at a peak, owing to the imminent federal election, and they demonstrated that they intend to behave no differently from their predecessors when it comes to haggling over the terms of Medicare agreements. The states variously profess an aversion to tied grants and yet, whenever these grants come up for renewal, state leaders always argue for more than is being proposed. This is possibly in some cases because previously the offers were always less than was actually available. It is my view that we live in a federal system that has many of the disadvantages and few of the benefits normally attributed to a federal system of government. Despite the fact that we are gearing up to celebrate the centenary of Federation, we are no closer than we were nearly 100 years ago to enjoying the benefits of responsibility and accountability that should flow from having three distinct and competitive levels of government. Motion (by Mr Truss) agreed to: That the question be now put. Original question resolved in the affirmative. Bil1 read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Dobell) (6.21 p.m.}-by leave-I move opposition amendments Nos 1 and 2: (1) Clause 6, page 3, at the end of subclause (1), add: and is observing the condition set out in subsection (3). (2) Clause 6, page 4 (after line 12), at the end of the clause, add: (3) It shall be a condition of the grant that a State not impose compulsory hospital charges for inpatient care on eligible persons who elect to be treated as public patients. I will not spend a lot of time speaking in the debate so that other colleagues will get a chance to speak. I simply make the point that the amendments that we are proposing seek to make it absolutely clear-cut that any state that receives funding under the Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 will not be able to impose compUlsory hospital charges for inpatient care on eligible persons-that is, anyone who has a Medicare card-who elect to be treated as public patients. This is the belt and braces protection for public patients that state governments do not impose new compulsory charges on public patients in public hospitals.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The amendments of the opposition go to the heart of my perspective that the now highly centralised system of revenue raising in Australia means that successive Commonwealth governments have been able to increasingly impose their will on other levels of government. What is proposed by the opposition is merely an extension of that. The states have played their part in this fiscal centralisation process by failing to take responsibility for raising their own revenues over the years. The lack of economic discipline that has characterised so many recent state government administrations is a direct consequence of their inability to implement adequate and efficient taxing measures. The analysis of our health care system by the OECD in the report I mentioned earlier found that: Efforts to contain spending pressures through a cap on budgets for public-sector hospitals had undermined efficiency as restraint has been imposed where capped budgets made it possible, not necessarily where resources (are) being used least effectively. What an indictment of the manner in which our state and territory governments run their hospital systems. This observation also reflects badly on the Commonwealth, which perpetuates arrangements that allow this to happen. If the state leaders were to be held politically accountable by their electors for the way in which they administer their public hospitals, it is certain they would manage their affairs in a much more efficient and accountable way. The only reason they can get away with inefficient and redundant practices in the public hospital system is that these can be easily masked by way of cost shifting. The fact that the majority of state and territory leaders refused the Commonwealth offer, which I referred to earlier in the second reading debate, which would have given the former more tlexibility but fewer opportunities for cost shifting, revealed their continued reluctance to be truly responsible managers of our public hospitals. Until such time as both the consumers and the providers of our health system have reason to be directly concerned with the cost of health care, I cannot see there being much change in the status quo. As I have already indicated, the OECD survey noted the correlation between declining private health membership numbers and rising costs in the public health system. Despite increases in the Medicare levy on supposed high income earners who fail to take out private health cover and the extension of incentive payments to low and middle income earners who do not maintain private health insurance, the coalition has not been able to stem the flow out of private health insurance facilities. The new Medicare agreement recognises this and intends to automatically compensate the states for increased hospital costs resulting from falling private health insurance levels. Despite this, the states continue to assert that the agreement is not generous enough. The haemorrhaging from private health insurance is: ... the creation of a compulsory tax-financed public system (which) has limited private insurance to (little more than) a top up role. These are not my words. I have quoted directly from the 1998 OECD report, which correctly lays the responsibility for the scheme at the feet of the government which introduced an almost open-ended system of unlimited access to so-called 'free' medical care, otherwise known as Medicare. I am referring, of course, to a former Labor government. From the start, the Medicare levy misrepresented the true cost of funding our public health care system. Instead of injecting a degree of honesty into the Medicare levy by setting it at a rate that reflected the real costs of Medicare, the Hawke government created and perpetuated an arrangement in which taxpayers received subsidised health care in return for what looks like a nominal levy on their income. Despite a 24 per cent increase in the Medicare levy from around $3.3 billion in 1995-96 to an estimated $4.1 billion in 1998-99, the revenue raised from this impost continues to fall far short of the cost of federal funding for our public health system. According to the 1998-99 budget, the cost to the Commonwealth to fund hospital services for the coming financial year is somewhere in the vicinity of $6.7 billion. (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (6.27 p.m.)These amendments are completely unnecessary and shows that the Labor Party and the two shadow ministers have not bothered to read the legislation that we have put into the parliament. The Health Care (Appropriation) Bill 1998 states very clearly on page 3, clause 6(1): A grant of financial assistance under section 4 is not payable to a State unless the Minister is satisfied that the State is adhering to the principles set out in subsection (2). Clause 6(2) then goes on to say: Eligible persons are to be given the choice to receive. free of charge as public patients, health and emergency services of a kind or kinds that arc currently, or were historically, provided by hospitals. So that is totally provided for in the legislation. The second point is that not only is it redundant but it is destructive and shows again that the opposition does not understand health. The section in the amendments which refers to clause 6, page 4 says: It shall be a condition of the grant that a State not impose compulsory hospital charges for inpatient care on eligible persons ... That totally is counter to everything that is happening in the health system at the moment. The fact is that there is a shift from inhospital to out-of-hospital services, there is increased use of hospital in the home, and this clause has been put in so that people who in the future have services in the community that are currently being provided in the home are not disadvantaged. To limit this amendment, as the opposition does, to just in-patient services leaves the way open for people in the future who are having community based services to be charged, which is completely the opposite of what it is intending to do. There is only one reason for this amendand ment: the opposition wants to put out tawdry little press release at the end of this saying, 'The government voted against ruling out charges for hospitals.' We will vote against it for two reasons. Firstly, it is already in the legislation. Secondly, these amendments are positively hannfuI. We have actually beaten you to it. We have put a press release out around the gallery saying that you are a goose, that you do not understand the legislation, that you have not read it, that it is already in there and that you do not undercharges stand what is happening in hospitals. Along with your confusion the other day over what happened with the PBS and its demand this effects, this is another example showing that you do not understand the health system. I could reply to each and every one of inaccuracies that exist in this legislation, the suspension for dinner is coming up and it would take far more time than I have. In terms of the opposition's misrepresentation, no amount of scaring, no amount of misquoting the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and no amount of misrepresenting the situation will allow you to scare people because the fact is we have covered the bases. We have no desire to see people charged. We have covered it completely by having it in the legislation. Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Canberra) (8.00 p.m.)The Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 is not the sort of bill that should be being rammed through in the last days of the sitting. This is a very bad bill. It is the sort of bill that is the root cause of the loss of faith in the party political system and in the two major parties that is feeding the growth of increased support for minor parties and Independents-the flight to the minor parties. The most recent Morgan poll showed the two major parties' vote at 83 per cent. That flight is much more stark in other countries, so we ought not over-interpret the significance of it, but we know that it is happening. You can see it in this House. You * can certainly see it in the Senate. You can see it in the results in almost all the states. You can see it in the opinion polls and you can hear it in the attitude and discussion of people. It is not just that the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are losing support amongst Australians. At the end of the day that does not matter. We live in a democracy. If someone else comes up and takes the support, that is what happens. That is the electoral outcome. But if people lose faith in the capacity of the political process properly to resolve their problems, at the end of the day it is very bad for the whole democratic process. We have a bill here which is about putting PAIRS $45 million over three years into the coffers of political parties from taxpayers. If it were passed, some of that money would go to my party-probably not a very big proportion, but some. We would be better off. We would have some more money for fighting elections. We would have some more money for the administration of the party. But the body politic would be worse off. When I say $45 million, that is not the amount of extra money the political parties will have; that is the cost to the taxpayer of this bill according to the explanatory memorandum. There would be a slight variation from year to year, which I assume is based on some assumption about when the elections are going to be, but over the three years the cost to the taxpayers of extending this political donation tax deductibility will be $45 million. Some of that money will be from corporate donations, some from private donations. You assume that somewhere between $100 million and $130 million of donations will be going to political parties through this system-a minority of that sum to the Labor Party, most to the Liberal Party and the National Party. The one thing I agree with about the bill is that it would extend to Independents the opportunity to have tax deductible donations made to them. If there are going to be such donations, it is proper that they should be extended to those people. But why the urgency of dealing with this bill? We have a serious problem in our electoral laws, a serious loophole, which to its credit the government has said it is going to close, but we are not seeing any urgency about that. That is the so-called Greenfields loophole through which donations are made to the Liberal Party without any disclosure. That is very serious. That loophole does require closing before the next election because it is a major loophole. I welcome the fact that the government is committed to closing it. That is a good thing. It should have closed it already. You could say there is some urgency; we should move to close this loophole before the election. But we see no action on that. Here, where we see that there is massive financial advantage, we suddenly see urgency. Wc are being pressed to make special arrangements to ensure that this bill will be passed, but it will not be passed with our support. With only a month between the introduction of this bill into the House of Representatives and when it is proposed to commence you wonder what the urgency is. I did not realise the Liberal Party was in such financial difficulties, myself. It is a fundamentally flawed proposal. I know and I understand why-I disagreed but understood at the time-the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters supported this proposal. I did not criticise them then, although I disagreed, and I do not criticise them now, although I disagree. You can understand why at first glance the idea of extending this $100 to $1,500 does not look terrible. For some individuals it will be perfectly reasonable. I am not suggesting that it is about dishonesty. I am very critical-and I have been critical in here before-about Greenfields. I thought and think that is a rort. I do not think there is anything of that avoidance of the law, of that impropriety, here. I just think it is wrong in principle. Here we are in parliament-148 here, 76 up theresaying: 'We think the organisations that send us here ought to get more support from the taxpayer.' I would like to go out in the street and ask people what they think, and say: 'We have here a proposal to spend an extra $15 million a year of your money. What is the most important way you would like to spend it? You have a few options. One of them is you could help out the Labor Party and the Liberal Party with some big tax deductibility.' I have to say, I do not think that is a winner. I am not talking about a winner in terms of votes on either side because if it is passed we both benefit. What I mean is in terms of the respect people have for the way we as politicians and parliamentarians conduct ourselves and the democratic process; the priorities we set-whether we are a government for their interests or for ours. That is the issue that I think is in contention here. How is this in the public interest? I can see how it is in the Liberal Party's interest, I can see how it is in the National Party's and I can even see-and no-one knowing my background will be surprised-how it is in the Labor Party's interest. What I cannot see is how it is in the national interest and, at the end of the day, that is what we are here for. That is our fundamental obligation. What this bill does is increase the maximum annual tax deductibility threshold for donations to political parties from $100 to $1,500. I never agreed with $100, but there is no mischief in it. It costs almost nothing and, by definition, there are no big donations and there are no big cashflows under it. In principle, I never agreed with it and I am not normally a thin end of the wedge person. People criticised it at the time as thin end of the wedge and I did not think it was, so I did not say much about it. Perhaps I should have and I am as guilty as anybody. But what we have is just in time for the next election, from 1 July this year-a major change to the tax laws with a cost to the revenue of $45 million over three years, and the only beneficiaries are the political parties and Independent candidates. I repeat that, if it is going to happen, I agree with the extension of it to Independents. If we are going to do it, that should be a part of it. I do not think we should do it at all but, certainly, if we are going to do it we should do it in that way. But we are rushing this through and there has been no public scrutiny. I know there was a joint select committee and that is the proper way to go about changing these laws. I support that process. The previous Labor government started it, this government continues it and that is good. A lot of very good agreed changes to the electoral laws come out of that and it does put the process of each election under the sort of scrutiny that it should have. I support all that. I know that the committee and my Labor colleagues supported this. As I said, neither they nor the Liberal Party and other party people on that committee-I do not any longer know the detail of the composition; I do not reflect on those individuals-are going to get any money in their pockets out of this. Whether Labor, National, Independent or whoever, they are not going to be personally advantaged by this. They are not acting in wrongful self-interest, but I think that they have made a mistake which is serious and should not be allowed to recur. This is also going to extend the right of tax deductibility to corporations from individuals, and I do not agree with that either. Of course, it did not apply when the limit was $100 but it did not matter. It matters now and it should not happen. If this has any rationale-and I think I understand the rationale people put for it-it is about an attempt to empower individuals to say, 'What we want is a large number of more small donations instead of a small number of large donations as a diffusion of political power and influence.' I think that is the honest rationale. The secondary rationale is, 'Boy, isn't this a lot of money that is going to come into our party coffers.' But underlying that is that legitimate argument and that is why members of the committee-from all parties-supported it. I understand that but I think that gets swamped by the secondary motivation about the dollar signs ringing over there in Blackall Street at the Liberal Party headquarters, about $45 million of tax deductibility and more than $100 million of' donations flowing through this tax deductibility, predominantly going to the conservative parties but, I repeat, not only to them. . We are not literally changing the electoral laws we are changing the tax act, but we are changing the laws that relate to the way we conduct our political system and our elections rather than closing the egregious loophole that has been pointed out. That is a serious reflection on the priorities of the government. It is a very sad day but, more importantly, it is a very sad day for our political process. We all not only have the national interest to defend but we also come here with an obligation to speak for, act for and defend the standing of the legitimacy of the political process. We all do things that do not help that, most often at question time. I am as gUilty as anybody and I do not want to stand here and pretend it is everybody else and not me. Of course we are all here and we are all shouting and doing things. Mr Kelvin Thomson-Not as gUilty as everybody-after all, Duncan's here!

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Maybe not as guilty as everybody but I am in there anyway. If you this want to have a competition about who is the most guilty, I am prepared to enter it. I probably would not win it but I would not come last. We are all into that and, afterwards, are we sometimes proud of it? No. Does it happen in the theatre of the place every day? Yes, it does and it is a very contagious event. I do not want to pretend everybody is in here every day doing everything with high principles about the long-term impact on people's views about the standing of the parliament, et cetera. We know that sometimes kids come in here. The teachers must have a hell of a hard time keeping discipline in the school after they have all seen us in here. But a lot of times a lot of really great things happen in here too. People get up and make really important speeches about little things and big things that they care passionately about and the cut and thrust of debate takes place. The arguments that are raging in our society are reflected in our parliament and we are able to bring about political, social and economic change peacefully through the democratic process. That is the great thing about our society. Most members, most of the time, apply most of their activity to doing those things and that is good. This bill, if it becomes a part of our taxation laws and part of our structure of funding political parties, will undermine all that good effort by all the members on all sides. It is not a Labor, a Liberal, an Independent or a National thing; we will all suffer. The system will be the worse for all of us if that is to be the case. The public are not stupid. They are much better informed these days. One of the achievements of the previous government of which it was proud was that it made a very significant increase in year 12 retention Why do I mention that in this context? While we were proud of that achievement, we underestimated some of the corollaries of itmany of them not relevant here-with respect to the types of jobs people want and all those sorts of things about aspirations. It changed our society. The constituencies are different. The expectations of young Australians about the political process, their politicians, their government and their governance are very different. They have more access to information. They have more information and they have more education to help them assess and analyse that information. They are not smarter than previous generations, but they are better informed, better educated and they have better access to information. All those things are healthy, but they are a bit demanding sometimes when you are out on the hustings, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, relaxed as you look about this forthcoming election-more than previous ones, if I judge correctly. Nevertheless, having held a marginal seat for a long time, you would know that the voters are getting more demanding. I am sure that is not why you are leaving, Mr Deputy Speaker. Mr Abbott-You're not leaving, are you, Mr Deputy Speaker?

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I was not reflecting on his chances of being re-elected. I do not think my facts are inaccurate there, Mr Deputy Speaker, are they? I did not mean in any way to reflect that. We are all facing that, and they will want to know when it becomes public, as it inevitably will, that we saw this as a priority, that we gathered here together at their expense and decided that this was the thing that we particularly wanted to do-so much so that we had a special sitting to deal with it. We would not normally be sitting now, but this bill is listed because it is so important. Some others that the government listed originally that it wanted to pass have dropped off the list

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The ones that would have saved Burnie.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Some that are very important for reasons to do with the city of Burnie, according to my colleague the memrates. ber for Denison. All sorts of bills have dropped off the list, and that always happens. We all make comments about how badly the other side administers the program, but it always happens that there are more bills you want to pass than there is time for, and at the end of the day you have to set some priorities. You have to say, 'We wanted to pass X number of bills. We now realise we can only have something less than X, and we therefore have to set some priorities.' Amongst all the bills, the government has chosen the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998. We have not chosen it, and if we had been asked-and it would not be a surprise to know that we never arewe would have said that this is not something that we give priority to. This is not one that we would have put at the top of the list, but it is the government's right to determine what comes into this show. The government has the powers of executive government. It has the right to introduce legislation and to set priorities about what is introduced. We have the right to debate it, to try to change it and, where the numbers give us the opportunity, to try to defeat it if we are opposed to it. But it is a reflection of the government's priorities that they chose this bill. My concern is that, if this bill is passed, there will be a profound adverse reaction in the community. Maybe I should not worry about it, because it will probably be mainly targeted at the government, but that is not my point. No, the election is not going to be won or lost on this bill. No-one is going to change their vote-whenever the election is-because of this, but I think the process will suffer. party political system will be adversely affected. The standing of the major parties will suffer a setback. The flight to the minors will be enhanced and exaggerated, and that will not be a good thing. If the voters choose to vote for minor parties, that is of course their democratic right, but it is not a healthy sign if they do it because of disillusionment and protest. Those are the things that cause me concern about this bill. The opposition will be opposing this legislation. My colleagues can put their own arguments and express their own approach to this. Many of them have given it a lot of consideration. Many of them served on the committee that made the recommendations, and they will wish to get up and espouse their own case. This is an important bill that we need to deal with. I regard it as an important bill. Therefore, on behalf of the opposition, I make it clear that we will be opposing this bill when, as I assume, we formally vote on it tomorrow morning.

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I must admit that listening to the member for Canberra (Mr MCMullan) was an interesting exercise. He traversed through a heap of stuff which I did not even know was relevant. I am sure he meant well. Even though he was being very vague, and they tell me he is a very nice fellow when you get to know himMr Laurie Ferguson-That's very patronising.

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: He was a Western Australian originally, so there is a chance of him being half decent. There is a little bit of hope for him. The speech by the member for Canberra was very waffly. I know he was trying to fill in his whole 25 or 30 minutes, but thank God he didn't! I am pleased to speak on this Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998, but I am going to be brief, because I am not going to cover that vast territory. That is not necessary. The aim of this bill is to expand the existing tax deductibility provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The first aspect of the expansion of the provisions of the act, reflected in this bill, that The I will talk about will enable tax deductible donations to be made to Independent candidates and all other members on a similar basis. As the member for Canberra said, he is sure that this has made it even fairerIndependent and minor party candidates can be party to this bill. Under this bill Independent candidates and members will be able to receive, for the first time, small to medium tax deductible donations from the public. We do know that $100 was just a farce. This is more realistic. We know that there are many people who donate small amounts of money to candidates and political parties, but we also know that there are people who would like to donate more, and the carrot is that there.is some form of defraying the cost of doing so. Deductibility is one aspect which demonstrates that this government is serious about transparency. That is the whole key to this issue: the transparency, the accountability and the honesty which this government gives through this bill. Because Independents will benefit enormously from this bill, it also demonstrates that the government is being fair and demonstrates the equity with which it treats all parties-not just its own, not just the major parties, but smaller parties and Independents. It represents equality of opportunity. Another aspect of this bill is the provision to raise the tax deductibility ceiling, as I have also mentioned, to a sensible level. I am sure that even the member for Canberra, in his sadness about the message that it will will say that the general public will realise that this is sensible compared with the which was just a token gesture, because we know that people are willing to donate a lot more. I will move on to that shortly. This a significant amendment. Clearly, lower tax deductibility did not encourage individuals to donate financially to their political party of choice. But the ability donate was always open to unions and in particular to the corporate sector-so we are being balanced-which is larger and has more funds. We are not saying that either party has a mortgage on who donates. We do know that the corporate sector is, by and large, the supporter of the conservative side of governnational ment, and we do know that the unions prothing vide enormous amounts of money to the ent Labor Party. It is a fact of life. But for the individual to donate money to a political party simply was not a viable option, except haps for the more comfortably off who were not going to miss large amounts of money. This is where the public gets the perception that donating to political parties is somehow an activity which is not completely desirable or above board because it is almost limited to the larger sectors or the wealthier sectors. individual was almost left out. It is little wonder that a large section of the public thinks that political donations are the province of the unions and the wealthy-that they a monopoly and somehow get an advantage out of this. The fact that an individual will now receive more attractive tax treatment with this bill should not be seen as an attempt to buy votes from either side or buy favour from anybody involved but an attempt to level off the playing field. That is the point made: it does produce this more level situation for all involved. By creating more of an incentive, or, rather, by removing a disincentive to donate, the bill spreads donations by the community far wider amongst individuals, corporations and, do not forget, as I said, the unions-the great collectors on behalf of those sitting opposite. It will also stop the reliance upon unions and busisend, ness for money. This can only be a good thing for the perception of the pUblic. We are $100 talking about the member for Canberra's perception, so it is not just going to be in the province of those two people; it will encouris age and involve more people in the public in the past, and the community. This bill is a demonstration of the government's commitment to honesty in government, to as we have seen before in the charter of budget honesty. You might recall that the opposition opposed this bill some time ago as they do not appear to be very supportive of bills which give credibility to the government's activities and restore the public's faith in the government's accountability. The member for Canberra said this is not in the interest. I would have thought anythat was more open and more transparwas in the national interest. It was in that interest to see that fair play and equality were being displayed. I am quite surprised-I must persay I am very surprised in fact-and the member for Reid (Mr Lauric Ferguson) is not paying attention. He is a member of the joint committee which examined this matter and brought forward this recommendation. The unbelievable thing is that this was a unanimous decision from that committee and The now the member for Reid and his fellow members of the Labor Party have been rolled by the echelons of the Labor Party on this. They have been done. I think it is highly have unusual for a committee to come up with recommendations, to support them unanimously and to walk into this chamber and get rolled. It just shows you where the power is in the party, and it is certainly not with the member for Reid. I am sure he would prefer to be down at the Grange tonight rather than here, but I am sure he is going to stand up and support his people who have told him that needs to which way to vote. Anyway, what I find quite unusual is that the Labor candidate for Swan and Labor candidates all around Australia have been putting out in their mail: 'Please donate to us to hclp us fight these elections.' What the opposition are now going to do is to say to the people who may donate to their candidates, 'Look, sorry old son, we Were going to support you to help ease the burden of you donating to this particular person, but because the member for Reid and his mates got rolled we cannot help you anymore, because we do not agree with the principle for some reason.' The principle that was being espoused by the member for Canberra was quite fallacious. There was not any substance to it, and he was talking about messages being sent to the public. I think the message being sent to the public is that the opposition flip-flop on these issues, depending on who is in charge-who has got to them at the last moment. In this case, it seems to be an absolutely crazy sort of situation in that the opposition had one position a month or two ago, but we find out here tonight from the member for Canberra that they are not going to support it. The rest of the community will soon be able to decide who is being transparent and sensible here. What I find interesting-and I oppose this-is that I believe that the Labor Party is going around at the moment asking for $200 donations on behalf of their members, putting the money into the Labor Party and then giving it back to the wharfies. I ask the member for Reid: is that right? Are you collecting money on behalf of the wharfies? Will this be tax deductible? Will the opposition be ruling out the. tax deductibility of money? They are collecting money on behalf of the wharfies to prop up these poor people on $70,000 to $90,000 a year. Now they are saying, 'Oh, this might not be able to be claimed because we are channelling it through the Labor Party and it might not be tax deductible now.' I am sure that the constituents of the member for Reid will not appreciate that. Mr Laurie Ferguson-It's not deductible for that; you know that.

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: You are donating it to the Labor Party

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Order! The honourable member for Swan should make his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Through the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, they are donating these $200 donations to the Labor Party, and we know that they actually want to give it to the wharfies. I am a bit worried about the tax deductibility of the money they are talking about. As I said, by putting it through the taxation system it is transparent because it has an audit route and people can see what is happening to their funds. This government will not be targeting this practice because, as the member for Canberra said, all members, including opposition members, were supportive of it. The minor parties and the Independents were also supportive of it. They will be interested in receiving the funds that follow. I find it unusual that the Labor Party now say that they are not going to support something that is decent and open to' the Australian public. Naturally, I support the bill because it is something that had all-party support. I believe it is something that we could take to the people of Australia and say, 'This is open and transparent. You can see that it is a sensible graduation in terms of time moving on and the amounts of money being collected in political campaigns these days.'

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I rise, as a member of the Labor opposition, to oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998. In doing so, I suggest to the House that this this bill is about making it even easier for the Liberal Party to line their own pockets and get money from business. It is being pushed through now to give the Liberal Party an eVen bigger and more unfair advantage in the coming election campaign than it already has. Mr Abbott- Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I am very reluctant to do this hut the suggestion has been made that members of the Liberal Party, which presumably includes people in this House, propose to line their pockets with this bill. This is obviously not the intention of the bill. I suspect that, if the member for Batman thought through his remarks, that would not be the intention of his comments. But that is what he said, and I really do take some objection to it. I think it should be rephrased.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: From the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Batman, I did not read that into it. But I will listen very carefully to the honourable member for Batman.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I appreciate that you are following the debate, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I think it is a very important debate. I understand why the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) is a bit sensitive about these issues. The recent disclosures to the Australian Electoral Commission by political parties of the donations which they have received makes for very interesting reading. The disclosures show that the coalition received $13.4 million in donations in the financial year 1996-1997. This is nearly 50 per cent more than the ALP received. What is interesting about the list of top donors to the coalition is that the source of this money is deliberately hidden. I must say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I think it is about time we had a bit of accountability with respect to donations by big business to the coalition government. When you are in government you have to make decisions that affect the community and, more often than not, have an impact on the business activities of a range of companies both within Australia and beyond. I think in any normal democracy it is more than appropriate that transparency apply to donations to political parties. Otherwise, suggestions can be made that all is not above board and that particular companies are being given a rails run on some government decisions and, more importantly, not only might they potentially be given a rails run, but they may have made a secret donation in a clandestine way to the political coffers of the government of the day. These issues are, I believe, the crux of the debate this evening. In that context, I refer to the fact that the three biggest donors to the coalition are associated entities. There are clandestine ways of hiding the donations which are given hand over fist by some in the business community, encouraged and supported-doors opened in the process-by the Liberal Party's Treasurer, one Mr Ron Walker of Hudson Conway.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Order! The honourable member for Batman is straying from the text of the bill, which relates to tax deductibility of donations and the limit of $1,500.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The issues I raise go straight to the crux of the bill: the question of tax deductibility, accountability and transparency. I think that is more than abundantly clear to anyone who is listening to the debate in an objective way. In that context, can I say that the clubs and foundations to which some of these donations might be made are being set up by the Liberal Party explicitly to enable individuals and companies to channel money to the Liberal Party in secret. This is the nature of the fundraising regime operating under so-called Honest John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia. The Liberal Party is deliberately and deceitfully exploiting loopholes in the Electoral Act. I can understand why the parliamentary secretary has tried so much to shut me up in respect of these issues. Mr Abbott- Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the matters of which the member for Batman complains took place under the regime established by the former government. For him to bring in the Prime Minister and to make such allegations about conduct, firstly, I think offends standing orders 75 and 76 and, secondly, as you suggested earlier, seems to be quite outside the scope of this bill and, therefore, irrelevant to the debate and out of order.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I ask the honourable member for Batman to direct his attention to the bill.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I am, very much so, Mr Deputy Speaker. I remind the House that, when the Labor Party developed legislation aimed at ensuring such accountability, the coalition was found wanting when it came to supporting such initiatives. The current Prime Minister was part of the coalition government that made those treacherous decisions with respect to the Australian public. In that context, I believe the real intent of the government with respect to some potential changes and watering down of some of the current provisions is to try to assist in the laundering of funds. I suggest that it is deliberately setting out to thwart that act's intentions to make political donations transparent and subject to tight disclosure laws. Mr Abbott- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The standing orders prevent offensive statements. They prevent the casting of aspersions on motivations of members and so on. The member has suggested that this is about money laundering. Money laundering is a very serious accusation to make. It is a criminal offence under all sorts of statutes. This is what he is accusing the government of. I think it is quite out of order and should not be allowed.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I did note the use of the word 'laundering'. I am not quite certain which member that was directed at, but I ask the member for Batman to direct his attention specifically to the bill.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I do not think what I said was directed at any member of the House. I talked about the Liberal Party as an entity being engaged in trying to facilitate laundering of funds, not individual members. I would ask that the parliamentary secretary listen to what is being said rather than imagine that I am in other than a proper way trying to expose potentially what might have gone on in the past or what they want to facilitate in the future. As I have said, the Liberal Party ncver has had and continues not to have any interest in keeping Australia's national government above a sense of accountability and removing it from any potential accusations of corruption with respect to the funding of elections. Its deceit does not end with the $500 club, the Cormack Foundation and the Free Enterprise Foundation. There is now a new body on the scene. Maybe the problem with the parliamentary secretary is that he has not been invited into the inner realms of that new body. I refer to the mysterious so-called Greenfields Foundation. Maybe the parliamentary secretary can enlighten me by making a contribution as to the background and the intent of the Greenfields Foundation. Or maybe you can enlighten me, Mr Deputy Speaker, as a member of the Liberal Party, even though you are a member of the Liberal Party on the way out. The Greenfields Foundation is closely intertwined with known Liberal Party identities. The Greenfields Foundation has very generously given a massive $4.65 million loan to the Liberal Party in 1996-97. I would like to know what the going interest rate is with respect to that loan. The Australian public does not know the true source of this huge sum of money. It is quite a considerable amount of money-$4.65 million, perhaps on the never never-to the Liberal Party from a so-called Greenfields Foundation. They do, however, know that the loan enabled the Liberal Party to pay off its debts to the National Australia Bank for the cost of the 1996 election campaign. I wonder what other pay-offs have been involved in these transactions, with the Greenfields Foundation, the clubs and the other foundations because of the unwillingness of the Liberal Party to ensure transparency, accountability and public scrutiny of these secret operations. The disclosure of this $4.65 million loan from unknown donors certainly caused a public scandal, with a range of newspapers reporting on it. For example, the Australian Financial Review had a range of articles entitled 'Secret foundation look at taking donations'; 'Liberals receive a $4.6 million secret loan'; 'Liberals use $4.6 million loan to pay off NAB debt'. In the Canberra Times the headlines read 'Minister won't detail Greenfields Foundation $4.6 million loan to Libs' and 'Beazley slates Libs on use of donations loopholes'. I could go on, but the real intent of the media and the Australian public

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Order! I do not think it would be within the standing orders to pursue that line. The bill, as is quite rightly addressed on the front of the bill, is a bill for an act to amend the law relating to taxation. The honourable member for Batman should speak to the bill.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, it does go to the question of taxation, but it is also in the context of a broader debate which occurred with respect to accountability of donations to political parties.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: And its tax deductibility.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: And its tax deductibility, which is the point I made following your request to make sure that I focus on thosc issues. It was the very point I made in responding to you: the all important point of tax deductibility. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have thought in that context that the next piece of legislation concerning electoral donations and tax deductibility would have tried to reduce the potential for hidden private donations. Tax deductibility potentially means a loss of revenue for other government activities. We should not lose sight of that. It is not just a question of donations and of whether or not they are publicly accountable; tax deductibility also means that we are losing potential revenue for other government activities, such as employment services, health, education, the building of roads and railways, our international standing, our capacity to represent Australia overseas in important World Trade Organisation debates and negotiations about access to companies. I would not have thought that the next piece of legislation would increase the scope for business to unduly influence the democratic process even more. Sadly, increasing the power of private interests to unduly influence the public process is exactly what the bill before the House does. The bill proposes amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. It would increase the maximum annual tax deductibility thresholds for donations to political parties from $100 to $1,500. That I suppose pales into insignificance when you compare it with the Joan by the Greenfields Foundation of $4.65 million to the Liberal Party in 1996-1997. But, for a lot of ordinary Australians, $1,500 is a considerable amount of money, especially for those on the growing queue of the long-term unemployed or the growing queue of unemployed youth in Australia at the moment. The changes would allow companies to make tax deductible donations and would broaden the definition of donations to cover contributions as well as gifts. I assume that the parliamentary secretary understands the importance of that. Yesterday in this place, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) ranted and raved about the fact that some trade unions make donations to the Australian Labor Party. The problem was that, in making that contribution, he failed to point out that these donations are up-front, fully, honestly and frankly disclosed under some of the most rigorous accounting requirements in place throughout the length and breadth of Australia-very rigorous accountability requirements and accounting processes set in place by legislation of this parliament. That is in contrast, despite the debate about tax deductibility, to the much larger hidden sums paid by shadowy sources into the parliamentary secretary's party's coffers. The minister also failed to point out that no trade union contributes large enough funds to make the top 50 donors to Australian political parties. The ALP-and it is fairly important when you consider the potential impact of this change with respect to the tax deductibility of donations-attracted only 10 per cent of the largest financial contributions made to political parties in 1996-97. It is clear who the big winners are from unaccountable, undemocratic loopholes in the laws governing political donations. I do not think the changes with respect to the tax deductibility embodied in the bill before us this night are actually going to facilitate overcoming those hidden opportunities. I suppose that is why the Liberal Party is, as it has always been, the party overwhelmingly supported by capital. It is certainly no friend to the battler. It is beholden to big business, as its support of the GST shows. I wonder about the impact of tax deductibility, for example, on a major company such as Amcor, whose chairman, one Mr Stan Wallis, is currently very intimately involved with the federal government.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Order! I do not know that the member is speaking to the bill in this respect.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I am going to some of the donations and the potential impact of this change in tax deductibility on these corporate donations-totally in order. Mr Abbott- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This bill gives tax deductibility on donations up to $1,500. How can the statement that we anticipate the member for Batman will make on this subject possibly be within the standing orders? It has nothing to do with the $1,500 tax deductibility limit that is under consideration.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I will be directing my attention to the remarks that the honourable member for Batman makes in respect of the statement he just made. I will be listening carefully to it.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: As I understand it, there is some concern in the corporate world that the $1,500 tax deductibility limit is not as high as they wanted. That is evident when you actually look at some of those donations. For example, with respect to Amcor-of which Mr Stan Wallis is out there currently rallying up big business support to back financially the GST campaign of the Prime Minister-$l ,500 would be a bit short when you consider the following donations. In 1992-93, for example, Amcor donated $ I 00,000 to the coalition, and to the Australian Labor Party it donated $30,000.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The member for Batman is going we]] outside the limit of the bill, which speaks of a $1,500 limit on deductions.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It must be in order to argue whether or not a measure in a blll is appropriate. It may be inappropriate because of its being set at too high or too Iowa level. What the member is doing is exploring why this particular proposal does not deserve the support of this House and giving instances of issues that are relevant to it.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The honourable member for Batman should direct his attention to the content of the bill, which is very precise in its undertaking and its administration.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I want to explore the potential impact of this bill in a wide-ranging way because the Australian public is listening to this debate and they are concerned about the potential impact of the bill. They know that there is nothing whatsoever wrong with supporting a demand that the opposition actually demand accountability with respect to donations to the government of the day. That is why I suggest to the House that this bill clearly proves that the coalition parties have made no commitment to cleaning up the Electoral Act. I can assure the House that the Labor Party has this commitment. We will continue our campaign to close the loopholes in the law which are now being exploited by the unscrupulous coalition government. For example, take Amcor's 1996-97 donation to the coalition of $135,000 against its donation to the Australian Labor Party of $40,000. I think the coalition ought to properly explain whether or not any other donations by a company such as Amcor are given through some of those other secret arrangements they have in place such as the Greenfie1ds Foundation. For that very reason, we will continue our campaign to close the loopholes. We will endeavour to stop the Liberal Party flouting the electoral disclosure laws. We will ensure tight and transparent laws regulating disclosure of political donations rather than opening the floodgates further, as this bill seeks to do. I understand the need for accountability. It is not just donations to political parties that concern the Australian public but also, I suppose, discounts given to politicians and whether or not those discounts are potentially tax deductible. J refer to an interesting article on page 6 of the Herald Sun of 7 May 1996 which reports on a $43,000 discount given by Hudson Conway to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. It also reports that not long after that discount was given the actual apartment was worth $75,000 more

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Order! The member for Batman is straying well outside the terms of this legislation.

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Thank you for drawing my attention to ensuring that there is full accountability and disclosure in this House, the people's house, with respect not only to tax deductibility of donations but also to secret discounts given to ministers of the government. As I said, the bill is attracting a lot of public attention. It is not just about tax deductibility; it is about accountability. It is about ensuring that secret donations become fully accountable and transparent to the Australian public. The Australian public has had enough of secret arrangements in foundations such as the Greenfields Foundation or the free enterprise club. They want to know that what is on the table is there for the public to see, that there are no secret donations and secret arrangements-nods and winks-by which people will benefit. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Warringah-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (8.52 p.m.)-The member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) made a curious speech, but it had nothing to do with the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998 and it certainly had almost nothing to do with the reality of donations to political parties in country. I am reminded of Bob Menzies' final press conference where he was asked by a cheeky journalist, 'What do you have to say, Prime Minister, about the powerful interests which have controlled you through your political career?' and he said, 'How dare you bring my wife into this.' Listening to the member for Batman, one would think that the Liberal Party was being manipulated by some kind of shadowy business interests. It is not true, it never has been true and it certainly is not going to be true whilst ever I have anything to do with the Liberal Party. This bill is about increasing the tax deductibility of political donations from $100 a year to $1,500. It is not about vast corporate donations, absolutely not, and it is not about non-disclosure. The Liberal Party-this government-perfectly supports the disclosure principle and we are not seeking at all to increase the tax deductibility beyond $1,500. Sure, as the member for Canberra (Mr MCMullan) said, this measure will have the effect of increasing, in a sense, public subsidy towards political parties, but it will have the effect of supporting all political parties, as the member for Canberra had the grace and decency to accept in his speech. What the member for Canberra neglected to point out was that it was the former Hawke Labor government which first brought in public funding for political parties. It was the Hawke Labor government which brought in a public funding regime which now, I think, ensures that about $40 million per election campaign go to the various political parties. What we have here is a serious attempt at double standards by members opposite. The member for Canberra said with a degree of sincerity that measures like this bring the parliament and politicians into disrepute. I do not think measures like this bring the parliament into disrepute. I think what brings the parliament into disrepute is the kind of cheap smear that we have just had from the member for Batman. The member for Batman tried to suggest that politiciansmembers of this parliament, ministers in this government and presumably ministers in this governments generally-are susceptible to improper influence from people who buy that influence by making donations to political parties. That simply is not true. Members opposite who have been members of governments know that donations are made from all sorts of sources.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: You live in cloud cuckoo land.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The honourable member for Banks shall cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: And it does not, in any way, compromise the integrity of governmental processes. The member for Batman pointed out that Amcor donated $135,000 to the Liberal Party in the last electoral cycle and he also pointed out that that self-same company donated $40,000 to the Labor Party-the Labor government. Is the member for Batman suggesting that that $40,000 bought government decisions? I hope he is not. I do not suggest that it did, but if the $40,000 which Amcor gave to the Labor Party did not buy government decisions, why is the member for Batman degrading and debasing this House and his colleagues in this House by suggesting that $135,000 does buy the Liberal Party? It just is not true. The member for Batman knows it and he demeans himself by making these sorts of statements. As the member for Banks has been interjecting across the table, democracy does not come cheap. Any of us who have been involved in election campaigns know just how dearly bought democracy is these days. It probably costs upwards of $20 million for the major political parties to run their campaigns. In a marginal seat, it probably costs something like $100,000 to $200,000 to run a campaign. It is an enormous amount of money which has to be raised from somewhere. Let's face it, healthy political parties are the muscle and sinew of an effective Westminster style democracy. This bill is designed to ensure that all political parties have the wherewithal with which to continue. Let us consider for a moment what may well be the real motivation behind some of the contributions of members opposite. Why are they so hostile to this whole idea of tax deductibility of donations to political parties? The simple truth is that the Labor Party receives vast amounts of money from the trade union movement. The trade union movement, as far as I am aware, is essentially organised on a not for profit basis and therefore the union movement does not pay tax. In other words, the Labor Party's donors do not pay tax; the Liberal Party's donors, by and large, do pay tax. This is a simple measure on the part of members opposite to try to hamstring one side of politics. It is quite transparand ent in that sense. If members opposite want to object to this bill, by all means let them do so, but let them be open and up front. Let them be as transparent about their motivations as they wish donations to political parties to be. ALP members of the standing committee that made this recommendation got it right. They understand how politics really works. They know the need for incentives .to be given to people to donate to political parties. They understand that this measure is something which is necessary to benefit the political process generally. They got it right. Why are members opposite now getting it so wrong? Why have members opposite abandoned the decency and the conscientious convictions of their colleagues on this committee? I can only assume that with an election imminent they are getting desperate.

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: At the outset, I express my strong support for one ingredient of this legislation, and that is the funding for independent candidates. Unfortunately, as we are quite aware at the moment, the public is distrustful of politicians in general. Whilst I do not condone people leaving major parties out of self interest rather than because of ideological or very fundamental policy differences, it has been inequitable and it has been unfair that funding has been allocated to the major political parties alone. If we are talking about democracy, if we are talking about the representation of people and giving them options in regard to democracy, it is more than reasonable that those candidates who are Independents receive funding. We know we have had some representatives, like the previous member for North Sydney, who have made fairly major contributions both at a federal and a state level in regard to the public knowledge of politicians and the exposure of some of the things that actually do concern the public. I want to very strongly support that ingredient of the legislation, because it is something that not only is necessary but also will give confidence to the Australian electorate that the system is not totally controlled by power brokers at the top that funding is not totally at the behest of the self-interest of the major political parties. In regard to the overall thrust of this legislation, I think there is a very fundamental flaw in it. The nearest thing I can remember to this attempt is collusion between the Liberal, National and Labor parties in the state parliament of New South Wales in regard to increased superannuation payments when that was debated in the middle of the night. This legislation comes through at the end of the budget process, with a total focus upon that and the Queensland elections. It is being put in here today in the last days of this particular session and, quite frankly, it is of concern in a very real sense. I for one am very pleased, as a member of the relevant committee, that the party has been persuaded to oppose this legislation. We should have opposed it from the beginning. What has changed the focus in our party has been the revelations in regard to the Greenfields Foundation, which certainly became very public after the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I should put on the public record that the figure of $1,500 was essentially a compromise. There has not been too much coverage by government speakers tonight of the original proposal of the government parties. They were not looking for $1,500; they looking for $10,000. That was the proposal of the parties opposite. Tonight when they say to us, 'Oh well, $1,500 is not too much,' this is only the foot in the door. Mr Abbott-You guys made it $100.

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I am not disputing $100; I think it is quite reasonable. Mr Abbott-That was the first foot in the door.

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The smart comment over here is that there is some analogy, some comparison, between a person in this country giving $100 and a person in Granville, Guildford or Merrylands giving $10,000. There would not be a person in my electorate who would think about giving $1,000, let alone $10,000. To say that that $100 was basically a big step towards what the Liberal Party proposed is wrong. They proposed that corporations-we are extending it to companies here-should be able to deduct $10,000. I think that gives the lie to this thrust tonight that this is only a minor gradation or a minor increase, that you really do not have to be disturbed; it is not aimed at the corporate sector, it is not aimed at allowing heavy corporate inputs. Let us look at the pattern of donations. In an article entitled 'The Big Tilt' in the zine The American Prospect of May-June 1997 we see the reality of campaign funding. This applies to Australia as well as to the United States. It reads: The 3 percent of the sample with family incomes over $125,000 are responsible for 4 percent of the votes, 5 percent of the protest, 6 percent of the contacts with members, 8 percent of the hours devoted to campaigning and fully 35 percent of the money contributed. In other words, the wealthiest three per cent contribute 35 percent of election donations. It continues: At the other end of the income scale are the 19 percent of the sample with family incomes under $15,000. They are responsible for only 14 percent of the votes, 13 percent of the hours volunteered in the campaigns and 12 percent each of the contacts and protests. And when it comes to making electoral contributions, they are barely visible, donating only 2 percent of campaign dollars. So the fact of life is that the average person really does find it a struggle to make any contribution. I have not seen any comparative figures in this country-I do not think they have been constructed-but the poorest 19 per cent in America, a big percentage of the population, are giving two per cent of donations. I referred in a previous contribution to an article in the Economist which says that a fundamental problem in regard to electoral funding is that it is always catch-up politics. Quite clearly, in this country we always have a problem of catch-up politics, catching up to the last conspiracy of the coalition parties. We know that we have constantly had to adjust electoral funding laws in this country. We had to go through the process of associated entities. We had to tackle the legislation, look at it again, because what they were doing was basically having a company or a foundation, call it what you will, over in left field that supposedly had nothing to do with the Liberal Party, regardless of how close the personnel were, how close the post office boxes were, how close the phone numbers were and regardless of people's careers previously in the Liberal Party. It was said to be just a coincidence that all these connections were there, that they had nothing to do with the Liberal Party, yet we find them making very substantial massive donations to the coalition maga- and more particularly the Liberal Party. There had to be reform of the legislation, there had to be changes and there had to be catch-up politics. This is the constant story in this country's electoral funding legislationonce you close one loophole, they have found another way through. The latest thing is that they say that someone walked up to them and gave the Liberal Party a $4.6 million loan.!t was nothing to do with Liberal Party, no connections-someone just gave them a loan. Let's be serious. The Australian public knows that this is just the latest method-the latest manoeuvre, the latest subterfuge-to undermine public scrutiny of electoral funding in this country. This is a situation where the public wants to know if a party has a philosophy of subcontracting out or wants to sell out large sectors of government. This is supposedly driven by ideology, and when you get to these funding laws you question whether it is really ideology rather than an IOU. We hear about those kinds of government practices in the defence area every second day, where they want to basically sack people in the Australian defence forces and subcontract, sublet or contract out. One has to question whether part of this is driven by these unknown donors. The only reason ever heard for this-and it is quite surprising that there are not a few other reasons-is that people are too scared to be madepublic. Supposedly they are going to be somehow victimised by the union movement or whatever. I do not know of any other reasons why it has to be so secretive. We have a minister here-he is a bit down in the dumps these days-who said that he changed the laws of this country on industrial relations so that industrial disputation would be reduced. Essentially it was all solved, everyone could have individual contracts and the power of the unions was broken. One has to question why, in the context of his major successes and his ability to clamp down on the union movement, they are still trying to have constant secrecy by setting up foundations and manoeuvres in a way that the Australian public can have no knowledge of who is donating to them. Why is there such secrecy? Why can't we say if there is a decision about the Australian mineral industry or if parts of are going to be contracted out and the private operators brought in? Why can't we say that the labour hire companies are going to come in? Patrick Stevedores and the National Farmers Federation are going to basically come into the waterfront. Why can't the public know, in their consideration of this policy, this legislation and this government position, that there is a possibility--even though it may be erroneous-that there was some influence brought to bear in relation to that decision making? We are seeing a widening of the availability of people to donate very substantial amounts of money. We could see a scenario whereby large corporations allow a number of executives or people intimately connected with their company to go to dinners or other fundraising events and to claim it individually. Essentially we are talking about a series of indirect donations by the same entity. They are getting to a situation, with 10 of them, where they can deduct $15,000-even more than what the Liberal Party intended in the first place. This is a sham attempt to get $10,000 deductible. This legislation is very much a concern. If the government is losing too much sleep about the fact that some Labor Party members on this committee have got a different point of view as to when the matter was discussed, I put to you that the $1,500 was a compromise at that stage in regard to a government thrust for a preposterous level of $10,000. The decision has to be seen in the context of the very public revelations about the Greenfields Foundation: that the opposition cannot trust this government in relation to electoral funding in this country. It is something that we should be able to sort out together. We should be able to say that the public has a right to know. It is going to further undermine public confidence, it is going to make people ask why this legislation was brought in, it is going to allow corporate donors to have a bigger say about policy and it is going to let them have a bigger impact in relation to both political parties. Let's be honest about it. There is a possibility they are going to be encouraged to give greater donasocial security tions in this way. Also, $15 million is going towards this, and this is in the context of the constant whingeing complaints of the government that they do not do this or that in this country any longer because they were left such a mess by the previous government. Here is a chance to avoid wasting $15 million on an exercise that is designed to increase the possibility of corporations calling the tune in a variety of policy areas. This money could be spent elsewhere. It is an undesirable move; it was part of a broader government thrust. When they bemoan the fact that Labor has moved off about this position, I want to remind the government members of this committee that, if we go back through the committee's proceedings, there are a lot of other very popular recommendations in regard to voluntary voting and other radical changes to our voting system which are aimed to cushion the government's electoral possibilities that they have abandoned in the light of day.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Before I make my remarks on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998, I would like to advise the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) that, if the government really wanted to save money, it would abandon public funding of elections. If you added that to the $15 million, there would be something there.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Public funding is about honesty and integrity in office.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: In that case, tax deductibility is another way of going about it and it might be said to be the same. This bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to allow taxpayers to make tax deductible contributions of $2 or more to registered political parties-including those registered under state or territory legislationtime up to a maximum level of $1,500 annually; to allow taxpayers to make tax deductible gifts to Independent candidates and members-also up to maximum level of $1,500 annuallyand to allow deductibility for donations made by companies. These amendments will implement part of the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the JSCEM, on the 1996 federal election. The amendments are proposed to apply to contributions and gifts made from I July 1998. As an Independent member of this House and an Independent candidate at the next election, l--or, more accurately, donors to my campaigns--clearly have an interest in this bill. As the law stands, donations to my campaigns and to the campaigns of my Independent colleagues cannot be deducted for tax purposes. The same also applies to Independent members in state parliaments. They along with all other candidates at an election must surely, as a matter of justice and equity, be in the same position as their main opponents, who are usually drawn from the ranks of the major parties. I have submitted to this House during other debates that it is a matter of simple equity that any donors to my campaign-provided the donations do not exceed the limit stipulated for registered political parties, which is currently $100-should benefit from tax deductibility. The present situation is something of an anachronism. It is understandable that, prior to the recommendation of the JSCEM and the introduction of this bill, it has not been in the minds of the major parties to ensure that donations to the campaigns of Independents should benefit from tax deductibility. I believe that, if the issue had not been pressed by me or by one of my Independent colleagues, it is likely that--even though what my colleagues and I submitted to the JSCEM and have urged before this House is fair and just-it would never have been dealt with in this place. The present government certainly recognised the inequity, even though it took its about rectifying it. On 20 October 1997, during question time. I asked the Treasurer (Mr Costello) whether he agreed that an inequity existed in the treatment of tax deductibility for political donations. I then asked the Treasurer whether he concurred with the recommendation of the JSCEM that the inequity be rectified. The response of the honourable gentleman was to concede that I had what he described as a 'conceptual point'. I differ with him on that it is far from conceptual. He said: I suppose you could say at a conceptual level that there should be an equivalence of treatment. I am pleased to see that the government's inprinciple agreement has now taken solid form. But a further inequity regarding Independent candidates persists. It is indistinguishable in the underlying logic from tax deductibility for donations to Independent candidates' campaign funds. Section 304A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 provides that each candidate in an election shall disclose details of all gifts above a value of $200 that he or she has received-and substitute 'campaigns' for that if you wish-during the disclosure period for an election. For House of Representatives elections the same rules apply to all candidates, regardless of whether they are endorsed by a registered political party. So far, so fair. However, gifts may of course also be made to registered political parties and not to individual candidates. At the end of a financial year, a registered political party must lodge a return setting out amounts received by the party during the previous year.
