However, if the total of all gifts received by the party from one person or organisation is less than $1,500, the party is not required to include the particulars of that donation in its return. Clearly, a candidate who is endorsed by a registered political party does not really need to receive and account for campaign gifts in the same way that an Independent candidate does. Indeed, if a patty candidate does receive a qualifying donation, the amount is usually not declarable because almost invariably the obligation to do that accrues to the relevant political party. Also, endorsed candidates will have money spent on their behalf by their party. So it is that donations to Independents are required to be identifiable as heing to individnoticing ual campaigns whercas thosc who donate to the campaign funds of individual endorsed party candidates are not so identifiable, because the sums received are included in a consolidated return lodged by the respective party headquarters. Therefore, the source of a donation to an endorsed party candidate of up to $1,499 will not be identifiable as such and not even declared, but donations to Independent campaigns of $200 or more must be declared. Since the government has shown, through the words of the Treasurer and by its action in introducing this bill, that it is concerned about equivalence of treatment of endorsed and Independent candidates, I trust that it will take steps necessary to rectify this other anomaly. It must be assumed that disclosure rules are there for a good reason. However, the source of a donation to an endorsed party candidate of up to $1,499 will not have to be declared, but donations of $200 or more to Independent campaigns must be. There is no reason why all candidates should not be treated equally in terms of the disclosure requirements. I suggest that either the threshold above which all candidates are required to disclose gifts should be raised from $200 to the $1,500 limit applying to political parties or the threshold for political parties should be lowered to the level imposed on donations to the campaign funds of Independent candidates. I suspect the latter would not find favour with the parties, but they cannot refute the equity of the principle involved. In closing, I congratulate the government on the introduction of these changes to the tax deductibility for donations to the campaigns of Independents and I urge that very same government to consider commensurate measures to rectify the other inequities in the electoral 1aws to which I have referred. To that end, tax legislation is not the appropriate instrument. It would indeed be an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I rise to oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998. But before I get into the detail of the bill I cannot help that in this experiment with putting the Hansard reporters around the place they are in the far back row of the press gallery tonight. Frankly, Hansard are in a different position to the press-they report accurately. And they fix our mistakes; they do not amplify them. I look forward to the day when Hansard are in their proper place on the floor of the House, at the table where they should always be-where history and convention dictate they should be. I say that for the benefit of listeners. I come to this debate as someone who served on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters during my first six years in the parliament-from 1990 to 1996. I enjoyed my time on that committee. I am not on the current parliamentary committee; I am on three other parliamentary committees and as shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs I have my hands full. But this debate is important and that is why I feel compelled to speak. The bill that we are debating is a scam. It is a scam on the taxpayers. It is a scam that was introduced very late into this parliamentary session-on 28 May 1998. If this bill goes through it is going to cost the taxpayers some $45 million dollars in the space of three years-$18 million in 1999-2000, $12 million in 2000-01 and $15 million in 2001-02. Those figures are on page 1 of the explanatory memorandum in relation to this bill. I can think of many better things to do with $45 million over three years. The money could certainly be spent in the area of indigenous health or education instead of lining the pockets of donors to political parties. I was on the parliamentary committee that recommended the current position, which is a vastly different position. It allows tax deductions to an annual level of $100. Some of us had reservations back when we were debating that, but one of the reasons we relented was that $100 is not a large amount. A $100 deduction may encourage people to join political parties. The membership of political parties can be tax deductible. That part of the political process and it can be done at little cost to the public. But this is a scam allowing tax deductibility to the amount of $1,500. It is interesting to note that before the parliamentary committee the Liberal Party recommended an amount of $10,000 be tax deductible. Frankly, this is a fundraising scam on the part of the government for their corporate mates. They have the Freedom Foundation and the 500 Club. We cannot even find out where the $4.5 million loan to pay off the NAB debt came from. Under this proposal they can get their corporate mates to pay $1,500 a head for dinner and not only do they get their feed and their speech from our ever diminishing Prime Minister (Mr Howard), but their $1,500 fee for the fundraiser is tax deductible. That is red hot. I do not want the best politicians money can buy. I do not want to go down the American path or the Japanese road. There is corruption in those systems. Some might argue that this is an anti-corruption measure. It is not an anti-corruption measure. It is putting the weights on particular sections of the community to come along and cough up at taxpayers' expense. It is an arm twisting exercise for the apparatchiks and the bagmen. Senator Minchin, the Special Minister of State, who has carriage of this matter, is one of the few competent ministers in this government. It is his ideology that worries me. In terms of the republic, he is the minister against the republic. In tcrms of native title, he is the minister to tear down native title. In this area he is the minister to get them re-elected. That is what this is about. It is a scam to apply from 1 July 1998 to allow the Liberal Party to get involved in a fund raising venture with their business mates at taxpayers' expense. A better and more transparent way of doing it is in relation to what is happening at the moment. In the last parliament there were recommendations and the various political parties got funding to the level of the votes they received-not only in the House of is Representatives but also in the Senate-and it was equitable. Lest it be thought this is a bean counting measure, I have no problem with the public funding of political campaigns provided there is transparency in the campaigns, consistency and principles. Donating to political parties is fine, but there should be disclosure mechanisms, not tax deductibility mechanisms. I have no problem with people donating whatever amount of money it is for political parties to follow their political philosophy. But those donations should not be made tax deductible to the extent that this government seeks to make them. I note with regard to my friend the member for Reid e Mr Laurie Ferguson) that I was disappointed that even the ALP members had recommended this $1,500. But it was a compromise because the government was seeking $10,000 tax deductibility. If you have a problem with funds let us have some transparency and uniformity. This is the way to do it: if you want to increase the amount by the price of a postage stamp, that is a more principled way of doing it. I do not want it said that we started this by allowing that figure of $100 to be a tax deduction. That is in a different league. In relation to membership fees it is a minuscule sort of amount that does allow Independents and other minor parties to do some fundraising. But this is a scam. You could have a bit of intimidation of employees of large companies, your SES service and a whole range of things. In relation to this campaign you have whole levels of staffers, consultants and SES officers that you can exploit. In goes the $1,500 and it is tax deductible. So you have the whiparound. The party apparatchiks, by putting a levy of $1,500 on staffers, or whatever, can create a whole new scam that is underwritten by the taxpayer. That is how they do it. When they increase the size of donations before it is allowed to be disclosed, you spread the money . You get companies purchasing a series of tickets for their employees. That is why this is not the proper way to do it. I do not think there is a shortfall for this government, because it attracts every spiv and carpetbagger and the white shoe brigade with its policies. We are flogging off our assets. Who is getting them? The poor old NAB helped the government write off its debt and what was going to happen? They were going to get access to the super funds but that hit the fence in the Senate the other week. That is what worries me about this-the self interest of it. It is the best backed horse in race for this government. It is about downsizing. It is the same here; it is for their mates. This is about tax deductibility for the mates of the tories. There will be a whip-around at the Melbourne Club and all the others. Frankly, if they have a commitment to the tories, then they can donate their fifteen hundred bucks without getting tax deductibility. I would rather that money go to the unemployed or to maintain child care. I repeat: $45 million over three years, an average of $15 million a year of taxpayers' money, and that is just an estimate. It is untenable. That is why a bit of sanity prevailed here. When this matter came before the parliamentary party and the caucus we did not have any trouble saying: 'We are not going to go along with this scam.' On a number of occasions there has been cross-party support in relation to electoral matters and we have copped criticism from the press-some right, some wrong. I think we probably have one of the better electoral systems in this country, with compulsory voting, public funding and a whole range of things. The Australian Electoral Commission is probably second to none. But there comes a time when enough is enough. This is the area where a line has to be drawn in the sand because it is pretty obvious that there is incrementalism with this government. We will go to $1,500, then it will be $10,000 or whatever. If people want to kick in fifteen hundred bucks to the Liberal Party or the Labor Party, then let them do it at their expense-no strings attached. The taxpayer already underwrites our electoral system in terms of funding. That is worked out on a proper formula and the Democrats, Independents and others are looked after. I support that system. I do not want to have to go cap in hand as a member of parliament around the labour movement or anywhere else to put the weights on to get the $1,500 for a special dinner or whatever. It is wrong. It is not necessary. Indeed, that is what worries me about this government. They talk about transparency, they talk about value for the dollar, a whole range of things, but not when it comes to selfthe interest. And that is what this is about, self interest for the big end of town, so they can have the whip-around with their mates because only their mates can come across with the $1,500. The labour movement is struggling to keep the jobs of its constituency at the moment. Those on the factory floor are losing their jobs. It is middle and senior management and the senior executive service whose salaries are going through the roofthe bosses. This is a bosses' clause. It is a clause for the rich, who are so mean-spirited that they cannot kick in fifteen hundred bucks for the tories without the taxpayer turning it into a tax deduction. That is the problem with our tax system. All the spivs and carpetbaggers and family trusts are in there right up to their necks with this government-tax minimisation, tax avoidance. This is consistent with the philosophy of the tories. Mr Miles-What's this about? R&D syndication?

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The minister at the table-or the parliamentary secretary, I am sorry; he is not a real minister, he is a parliamentary secretary, who is entitled to the position as he is a pen pusher and signs his name-talks about R&D. I will tell you what R&D did. It encouraged investment. They are not the mates of the Labor Party. R&D is about jobs. There is no incentive. The government do not need tax deductibility if their policies are working for their side of town. They would be lining up to give them fifteen hundred bucks without tax deductibility. It shows how bad this government and this Prime Minister are going when they need the incentive of tax deductibility to get fifteen hundred bucks out of their mates. Because that is what this is about. Their mates are so mean-spirited and always looking to minimise tax that they are not prepared to kick in the fifteen hundred bucks. They want the taxpayer to underwrite it-socialise your losses, the agrarian socialists in the National Party. It is just not consistent that a conservative government, worried about taxpayers' dollars, worried about transparency, says one thing and does another. Mr Miles-This was a unanimous report.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The parliamentary secretary at the table talks about a unanimous report. What is the position? Are we as a parliamentary party and as a caucus supposed to accept all the parliamentary reports? I listened to my good friend the member for Reid and he says it was basically a compromise. I know his views. I know my views. When I was on the parliamentary committee this would not have got past first base. The decision of the parliamentary party, which is the right one, is that we are not going along with this scam. And it is a scam. If you want your mates to donate $1,500 for your next election, then do not worry about getting the taxpayer to underwrite it-go out and do the hard yards. If you go out there and tell them how good your policies are and do it on a policy basis, you will not need tax deductibility. But they need it because they have nothing to offer the electorate or their constituencies, except another scam to minimise tax. Mr Miles-Low interest rates, no debt.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Again, I will respond to the parliamentary secretary because he talks about low interest rates. They are a vote of no confidence in this government because they have comatosed the economy. Interest rates now have to go down because they have to breathe life into the corpse that this government has created. It is not about saying, 'Look how great interest rates are.' You have to have a job to be able to have a mortgage to pay off a house. I would have thought unemployment would have been the big one. We have this feigned indignation by those on the other side of the House. This is $45 million of taxpayers' money. We had a scam of a special auditor for ATSIC because we had all of these allegations of indigenous organisations wasting the money or whatever. The Federal Court threw the special auditor out three-nil. But what did it show? That the overwhelming majority of those organisations were honest; there was no corruption there. They needed some assistance in training. There was a problem with red tape. But there is always a scam in it in terms of this government. You do not look at it on its merits. The parliamentary secretary is so effective that the Burnie workers lost their jobs today! That is how much the bosses listen to him. It is a pleasure to get up and oppose this because this typifies the choice at the next election. Only a conservative government could bring this sort of stuff into the parliament with a straight face. We are engaged in a struggle, and it is a class struggle at the moment. It is only their supporters who can afford the $1,500 to kick in for the tax deduction. That is what it is about-their mates. This is a bill for their mates. This country has a big choice at the next election and it really is about which direction we are taking our country in. We have an ever-diminishing Prime Minister. This is about this government using the advantage of office, attempting to use the tax system for their benefit. I say: if you want transparency in the arrangement then do it on a per voter basis. If you want to increase the level of donation to a political parties, do it. Test your strength in terms of the votes that you can attract. That is transparent, it is principled and it is uniform. But this backroom deal where we are going to give tax deductibility so that the party apparatchiks can go out and bend everyone's elbow to get them to kick in the $1,500 is all this will encourage. That is not transparent and that is not good for the system because it makes us, as parliamentary representatives, prisoners. That is why I believe in the principle of public funding because, as parliamentarians, we do not want the best parliamentarians that money can buy, and that is what this is about. Senator Minchin has been the architect of this. He is a competent minister but a party apparatchik whose brief is to get the government re-elected at minimum cost to the tories. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill is a sinister try-on and follows an ambit claim in the committee which considered it in the first place. I thought that the member for Banks (Mr Melham) covered the issues extremely well and set out in a very stark way the sorts of choices that are in front of us. But I did want to take issue with one of the points he was making. He was expressing the view that this shows that the rich are mean-spirited and too lousy to make a donation to the Liberal Party without the incentive of a tax deduction. I would suggest that it is really not so much a reflection on those who are well to do but rather a reflection on the Liberal Party that it is unable to attract donations on any other basis. Indeed, why would you? Why would you give them even a hundred dollars? But why would you give them $1,500 without the tax deductibility when you have a government which has been so incompetent and has made such a mess of the major issues confronting this nation that it has become a laughing stock? We have seen the nursing home accommodation fiasco, we have seen the way they have handled waterfront reform, we have seen the superannuation debacle with the government in there ringbarking the superannuation tree that Labor planted, we have seen a cabinet in disarray, we have seen the travel rorts, and we have seen more ministers go and more cabinet attrition than we have seen since the Stalin cabinet in the 1920s. So if you are a well-to do person you might be excused, without the incentive of tax deductibility, for saying, 'No, r do not think I will make a contrihution to this government. I really do not think that it represents money well spent.' This bill proposes a number of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. Ii is intending to increase the maximum annual tax deductibility threshold for donations to political parties from $100 to $1,500, a IS-fold increase-a major increase by any yardstick. Secondly, and just as importantly, it proposes to allow companies to make tax deductible donations. You might think that it is no bad thing for individuals to make donations and to contribute to the democratic process, but the idea that companies contribute to the democratic process and that they have some interest which ought to be reflected by according them tax deductibility is not something that I can support. The bill proposes to broaden the definition of 'donation' to cover contributions as well as gifts. It proposes to bring donations to independent candidates in line with political parties and it proposes to allow for tax deductible donations to be made to political parties registered under state or territory electoral legislation. It is proposed to come into effect from 1 July this year-very soon, v-ry quickly and very conveniently, one mlght suspect, from the point of view of a government which seems all too intent on a dash for the polls before too long. As earlier speakers in the debate have made plain, this is an essentially political issue. The considerations which are at stake here are political ones. We have a government which is seeking to gain political advantage for itself. The bill has been introduced on the eve of an election. The government is endeavouring to ram it through on that election eve to assist it in its election efforts and for no other reason. Indeed, the government's second reading speech sums up why we ought to be opposing this bill. It makes reference to: . . . an increase in the threshold will encourage small to medium donations, thereby increasing the number of Australians-including companies-involved in the democratic process and reducing a political party's reliance on a small number of large donations. So the government's intention is absolutely plain. The government's intention is that the Liberal and National parties ought to be advantaged in the coming election. The budget figures also give the game away. There are indications in the budget figures that this measure will cost $15 million. On a rough and ready assessment of that, the government is looking to have some $45 million donated via this process-via the donations loophole which has opened through this process-at the expense of the taxpayer. It is always interesting to come in here and hear the government say, 'Look, the tax system has had it. It's full of holes, so we've got to bring in a GST. Too bad for the poor old retired people who are going to have to pay more on their food and more on the essentials of life, but the tax system has had it. There are too many leaks; we can't plug them all,' and here it is opening up the loophole for tax deductibility for donations by companies. Let us have a look at where the donations from companies, aided by a tax deductibility, might go. I refer to evidence brought forward for the 1996-97 financial year concerning donations. These were reported in a couple of places, including the Herald Sun and the Financial Review. The report in the Herald Sun was clear enough-'Corporate Australia has thrown its financial weight behind the Liberal Party'. Official figures released showed that the coalition attracted nearly $27 million in 1996-97 compared to the Labor Party's $19 million. When you look at a lot of the companies and trusts involved, the difference is very severe indeed. For example, the ANZ Bank donated $125,000 to the Liberal Party and $20,000 to the Labor Party. Amcor donated $130,000 to the Liberal Party and $40,000 to the Labor Party. Hoyts donated $51,000 to the Liberal Party and $12,5000 to the Labor Party. They were modest compared to Village Roadshow. Village Roadshow donated $202,850 to the Liberal Party and around 10 per cent of that, $23,000, to the Labor Party . There were other companies that did not bother to engage in even token balancing. Santos donated $153,000 to the Liberal Party and nothing to the Labor Party. HIH Insurance donated $126,000 to the Liberal Party and nothing to the Labor Party. Coles Myer donated $110,000 to the Liberal Party. They made an offsetting donation to the Labor Party. Pratt Holdings donated $105,000 to the Liberal Party. Western Mining donated $103,000 to the Liberal Party. Grollo Australia donated $100,000 to the Liberal Party. None of them bothered to make offsetting donations to the Labor Party. It is pretty clear what the Liberal Party believes it will achieve through putting this bill through the House. The Liberal Party believes that it will be able to secure the financial benefit of that tax deductibility-certainly at the expense of Labor and also at the expense of the taxpayer. The member for Banks and other speakers were right to point to many of the attractive and desirable features of Australia's political and electoral system, but I think it is also fair to say that we have some problems in the way that our electoral system functions and, in particular, in the way that political donations function, particularly this prospect of secret foundations and trusts receiving donations, passing them on to the Liberal Party and not being accountable for them so that we do not know who the ultimate donors are. For example, earlier this year it was reported that the Liberal Party had received a $4,650,000 loan from a secret foundation. The lender-the Greenfields Foundation-has strong links to the Liberal Party's former secret funding vehicle-the Free Enterprise Foundation, which was caught through a 1995 crackdown on disclosure law. Up until that time, the Free Enterprise Foundation had donated large sums to the coalition but was not required to reveal the donations it received. So that circumvented the intent of the funding disclosure laws. When we endeavoured to close that hole, we found that the Greenfields Foundaincluding tion was loaning rather than donating to the Liberal Party and thereby maintaining that it was not obJiged to provide any mation to the Australian Electoral Commismisleading sion. But, revealingly, the address that use is the same Canberra post office box used by the Free Enterprise Foundation, and inquiries that the Electoral Commission has campaign'. made to the Greenfields Foundation have been answered by Mr Tony Bandle, who has been a trustee of the Free Enterprise tion since 1981. Indeed, when the Liberal deductibility, Party was challenged on this, its federal director said, 'Under the Electoral Act, one can lend money to a political party. All we are required to provide is a name and address. You can write to them.' So it was pretty clear that the Liberal Party had no intention of bringing the public into the know on where this money had come from and the purposes to which it was being put. We see a circumstance where the main bankrollers of the Liberal Party are private trusts. We have things like the Cormack Foundation, Add Lib, the 500 Club, and I have already mentioned the Free Enterprise Foundation. We have seen high profile busiI ness people including John Elliott, Richard Pratt, Hugh Morgan from Santos, WMC, Coles Myer, Lion Nathan and Southcorp all pitching heavy donations in the direction the coalition, but not Labor. We had aviator Dick Smith donating more than $10,000 to the Liberal Party, including a special contribution for Prime Minister If Howard's electorate of Bennelong. Dick three Smith has done pretty well, let me say, from the change of government. All of this occurs against a backdrop this government had said it was going to raise political standards, but in fact it has taken action to do that whatsoever. My feeling that out there in the community there is sense that political standards have been damaged and are progressively being diminscribe ished. For example, prior to the election had a parliamentary inquiry talking about ban on inaccurate and misleading political advertising, and all the inquiry's coalition loopmembers regarded this as a good thing, the Special Minister of State (Senamoney tor Minchin). But we now learn that the federal government has opposed or at least inforpostponed plans to ban inaccurate or political advertising so, in the they colourful words of the Adelaide Advertiser, 'politicians are likely to be free to tell blatant any lies during the next federal election You can tell that the idea of greater election Foundaspending, more donations based on tax very little in the way of restrictions on what can be said in the course of the anyelection campaign, and all this advertising, mean that the coalition is intending to swamp the electorate with a glitzy campaign. There will be very little in the way of truth, very little in the way of detail, certainly on the big issues like GST, and very little in the way of detail on any of the other things on which the electorate will need to make up its mind on the election outcome. I regret to say that there is no doubt that in any political system influence can be bought and donations do have some effect. There is no getting around that; influence can be bought. We have seen, think regrettably, some suggestion of that already in the last couple of years. Interestingly, we had a quite spectacular of outburst from Mr John Sweeney, the Chairthe man of the Trust Company of Australia, which had made a very substantial donation to the Liberal Party during the 1996 election. I recall it correctly, they had donated some floors of their offices for use as a campaign headquarters, so by any yardstick this was a very handsome donation in kind. Mr Sweeney, we understand, was approached by where Ron Walker, the Liberal Party's federal treasurer about using their headquarters again. no He said, 'Let's do it again-the same as we is did last time.' We understand that Mr a Sweeney replied, 'Over my dead body' or words to that effect and he went on to dethe Liberal Party's actions over the we Managed Investments Bill 1997 as 'treachera ous as Pearl Harbour' . Mr Sweeney cited the statements of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the board of the Trust Company in front of Andrew Robb that they would not support the Managed Investments Bill. Of course, this government has proceeded with the Managed Investments Bill, so you do not need to be Einstein to work out what has happened here. John Sweeney and co were done in. I think one thing that we do need to say is, 'Let the Liberal donor beware' - you might not get what you think you are getting. It is often suggested that an honest politician is one who, when he is bought, stays bought. That apparently cannot be said of the Treasurer. Mr Sweeney has made it clear, on the record in a public fashion, that he is not prepared to support the Liberal Party because of the way they have behaved over the Managed Investments Bill. We have also seen concerns expressed about the fundraising of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), who was unable to explain here or anywhere else just how it was that a donation from Ramsay Health was described as being care of his electorate office post box. We have had some queries about what has been occurring there. I think, quite seriously, we have been seeing examples of the banks, which are unquestionably supporters of this government, being given rather privileged treatment in the way this government has gone about its conduct of government. For example, we have recently seen reported that the big banks' fee income has risen some $657 million in the past 12 months, yet we have had absolutely nothing coming from this government by way of criticism of those fees and charges; nothing of the sort of criticism that the previous Treasurer used to do to contain banks' fee and charges. We have seen a situation where, during the half year to March, the big four banks earned nearly $3.5 billion in fee income. Last October and November all the banks restructured their fees and charges. The National Australia Bank doubled some of their over-the-counter fees to $2, Westpac reduced the number of fee free transactions, while the Commonwealth Bank introduced phone and Internet banking fees. Last September the federal government accepted the recommendations of the Wallis inquiry to allow banks to set their own fees and charges. As soon as that occurred the fees rose, but what did you get from this government? Absolutely nothing in the way of comment concerning that or any action to monitor those fees and charges. It is interesting that this government has been taking the credit for lower mortgage interest rates, but the Westpac Chief Executive, Bob Joss, has stated on record that the trade-off for lower mortgage rates is higher bank fees and charges. So you have got to ask the government: do you also accept responsibility for the big four banks earning that $3.5 billion in fee income during the half year to March-the $657 million increase over last year's figure? In relation to these issues, this government has been running absolutely dead. The same applies to the issue of choice of superannuation fund. The member for Banks earlier referred to the fact that the banks, in supporting this government in the way they have, in bankrolling this government in the way they have, have an expectation that they will be able to get their hands on the superannuation income of ordinary workers. The government's choice of superannuation fund legislation is designed to give banks and other vested interests that advantage. Otherwise, why would it be before the parliament? There is no support for this coming from employees. There is no call for this. No-one is coming into our electorate offices demanding to have what is described as 'choice of superannuation fund'. There is no support for this from employers, for whom this is a royal pain in the neck and will simply result in more red tape, more paper work, for them. There is no call for this from other areas of the superannuation industry. There is certainly no call for this from the industry funds and the likewhich have been doing a very good job, let me say, in looking after workers' superannuation. The government's changes are designed to give the banks and other vested interests a leg-up into that superannuation area. There is a suspicion in my mind and in the minds of others that this represents a pretty crude tradeoff for campaign donations. This is not the kind of influence which we want in this nation and in this parliament. Regrettably, if this bill-the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998-is passed, we will see more of this sort of thing rather than less. We will see donations go up to $1,500 on the back of tax deductibility and a lot more in the way of corporate donations. That will be at the expense of the taxpayer and it will also be at the expense of good government, of decent, clean and honest government, in this country. We in the Labor opposition will be opposing this bill, and we will be urging others to do likewise in the Senate.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (10.01 p.m.)-in reply-We have heard a fair bit of grandstanding in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Political Donations) Bill 1998. Ijust want to go through this very simply for those people who are listening to this debate. Somebody who, for example, donates $100 would, if they are a company, get back $36. If they donate $1,500, they would get $540 back. If they donate $10,000, they would get $540 back.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: No, for $2,000 they get a third.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: No, they get $540. If they go to $20,000, they would get $540. If they go up to $100,000, what do they get? They get $540. The member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) came in here and indicated that a number of people ann companies had donated substantial amour.iS of money to political parties. The implication of course was that these guys were going to get great tax deductions. But on $100,000 they would get a $540 tax deduction. That is a great incentive, isn't it? Somebody who has got $100,000 will really be swayed by the fact that he will get back $540 in tax deductibility. That is the first thing to say about the sort of grandstanding that we have had going on here by the Labor Party. It is so much nonsense. That is the simple reality of it. I do not believe that, if those people contribute $30,000, $50,000 or $100,000 to a political party, they are going to be moved by tax deductibility. Of course, there are unions who donate to the Labor Party. They do not have to pay tax. The unions do not pay tax. They take money off Liberal Party voters and then filter' it through to the Labor Party-that is how they do it. They take the dues from Liberal voters, National Party voters, Independent voters and Democrat voters and then, of course, they just siphon it through into the unions and back to the Labor Party. That is how the Labor Party do it. The other thing about this piece of legislation which has been totally ignored by the Labor Party is the fact that it will give tax deductibility to Independents and anybody else who wants to put up their hand and participate in the democratic process without being involved in a big party. This legislation really does extend equity and fairness in this area. Of course, the Labor Party do not like that. They like to hunt in packs and just keep in groups. They are not individual or independently motivated people. They just hunt in packs. They hate people who are independent thinkers. They hate people who choose things, people of conscience or anyone like that. They are opposed to this. They do not want an individual to be able to put up their hand and say, 'Look, if anybody donates to me I'm going to have a run in the seat of Banks, just to stand, to participate in the election which is coming up.' The Labor Party do not want these people to be able to get tax deductibility. That is one of the reasons they are opposing this-or the reason some of them are opposing it. I am not quite sure if they all oppose it or not. Some on the committee supported it. Was it Senator Conroy? The opposition shadow spokesman for veterans' affairs supported this to begin with, but obviously he must have been rolled in the party room or he has changed his view. But, then again, the Labor Party will do anything or say anything to get into government, so we can expect these sorts of things to happen. There has been a lot of grandstanding here. The Labor Party do not want Independents or small parties to be able to participate and get a fair go. They just want to keep other taxpayer funded sorts of things for large parties and not allow individual people to get the same sorts of benefits. The Labor Party totally ignored that, and yet it is a major part of this legislation. I just want to go over a few other points in this summing up speech. This bill implements the government's response to the tax related recommendations in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1996 election. The recommendations of the joint standing committee were unanimous. In other words, the committee included members of the Labor Party, the National Party and the Liberal Party, and the recommendations were totally unanimous. In the committee the people sat back and looked at the matters. They all believed that this was the best way to go, and of course that is what we are doing: we are implementing this unanimous decision by the joint standing committee. Recommendation 61 provides that the tax law be amended so that the donations to a political party of up to $1,500 annually, whether from an individual or a corporation, are tax deductible. Currently the tax law allows contributions of $2 or more up to a maximum ceiling of $100 per annum to registered political parties under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to be tax deductible by individuals. The government agrees with the joint standing committee that an increase in the tax deductible threshold from $100 to $1,500 per annum will encourage small to medium donations. This will increase the number of Australians, including companies, involved in the democratic process and will reduce a political party's reliance on a small number of large donations. Recommendation 62 provides that the tax laws be amended to provide that donations to an Independent candidate at a federal or state election are tax deductible at the same level as donations to registered parties. Currently such donations are not tax deductible. The bill also implements this recommendation. This provides an equivalence of treatment between Independent candidates and members and Labor political parties. The bill also implements government's decision to allow taxpayers to make tax deductible contributions to political parties that are registered under state territory electoral legislation. This expansion complements the tax concession afforded to Independent candidates and members. The members for Canberra (Mr MCMullan) and Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) indicated that the Labor Party will oppose the bill. The effect of that is to retain the status quo. This means that Independent candidates and members do not receive equal treatment with registered political parties. That is clearly unfair and clearly inequitable. We did not hear anything about that from the Labor Party. They are not about equity. I have not heard any justification by the Labor Party in regard to this issue. More importantly, it demonstrates that the Labor members of the committee-Senator Conroy, the deputy chair of committee, and Laurie Ferguson, the shadow minister for veterans affairs-have been rolled totally and completely on this issue in the party. After full consideration in committee stages, listening and looking at the 1996 election, they decided in their judgment that this recommendation of $1,500 was a good, wise and sensible decision. Then they got to the party room and, as the Labor Party will do anything to get back into power, they were rolled, probably by the chiefs of the Labor Party such as their national secretary or somebody like that. The bill has been given priority as the proposed amendments are to take effect from I July 1998. Australians wishing to make tax deductible donations to political parties and Independents under the new proposed arrangements will remain uncertain until the proposed legislation has been passed by the parliament. The Labor Party's justification for their stance on the bill simply does not add up. This bill very simply changes the tax law to do two things: to increase the threshold for tax deductibility-as simple as that-and to give equivalence of treatment between Independent candidates and members and political parties. It does no more than that. They are two very simple changes to the tax law. The Party would like to make a lot of these the changes but they are essentially two very simple changes: to increase the threshold for tax deductibility from $100 to $1,500 and to or give equivalent treatment to allow more Australians to participate in the democratic processes in this country. I seek leave to continue my remarks later. Leave granted; debate adjourned. NA (LANDCARE AND WATER FACILITY TAX OFFSET) BILL 1998 Second Reading Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Given the fact that this parliament seems to be coming to its end, I wish Mr Miles well, the former member for Braddon to be, in his future career. I begin the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Landcare and Water Facility Tax O--set) B-ll 1998 by indicating that the oppos1tlOn will be supporting this legislation but wishes to raise a number of matters which go to how effective it may be in its application. The first point is that there is truth in the proposition that low income farmers do not benefit equally from the opportunity to take advantage of tax deductions under section 387A and 387B of the tax act for Landcare activities. What that means is that there may be some disincentive for them relative to their more affluent counterparts to invest in repairs of rural lands. Both the former Labor government and the current government have put in place measures designed to facilitate and assist activities to address the terrible backlog of environmental damage that has been caused through bad planning and poor farming practices, often through no fault other than a lack of knowledge as to appropriate methods but nonetheless very significant damage that has been caused in the past. The mechanisms that have been used include the tax system, the Natural Heritage Trust and direct expenditures through programs such as the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. This particular measure fits in by giving a rebate to low income farmers whose incomes are less than $20,700. So the effective benefit for their expenditure on Landcare activities is worth to them 34c in the dollar. The difficulty that we have with this proposition is not the principle of it but some of the estimates of how far it will be applicable and the degree to which it will be effective in reaching its intended beneficiaries. To begin with, I think it has to be said that farmers who do have taxable incomes below $20 700 are. certainly not flush with cash. If you have an lUcome below that, most of your expenditure is .going to be committed to the struggle to surVIve and your capacity to find additional capital expenditure may be quite low. To the extent to which that is the fact, the capacity of farmers to draw down even on this rebate is to be severely doubted. The government will finance this measure by appropriating some $80 million which it would have otherwise expended directly on landcare projects under the Natural Heritage Trust. So this, in a sense, does not represent new dollars committed to this sector but rather, a different vehicle for its application: But, if you think through the mathematics of that application, the only way that $80 million can be drawn down is if there is additional expenditure on farm related landcare in aggregate of about $240 million. The reason for that is you only get the 34c in the dollar and, if the value in the estimates is $80 million, in order to access that $80 million there must be a mUltiple investment which adds up to $240 million. It seems to me, at least on first sight, somewhat improbable that farmers whose incomes must be less than $20,700 are sufficiently numerous on the ground to be able to make investments collectively of that order. What this presages is the same kind of slow retreat from reality that we saw with the farm retirement package, where originally the government said it was putting forward a major initiative that would benefit some 10,000 Australian farmers to enable them to retire from sub economic land. They revised that figure down some little while later to 4,000, or perhaps 5,000, and they now estimate that the uptake of that will actually be 1,500 farmers. Of course, no-one hears much about the retreat. They hear the announcement, they see the fistful of dollars waved and they anticipate that they will be able to access those benefits. But, when the bitter truth emerges as to how difficult it is to access the programs, how difficult the guidelines are, those findings are not communicated in the blaze of publicity that attended the first announcement. With the present measure there was a blaze of publicity. I think it was the only mention of the environment, oblique though it may be, included in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Costello). .I suspect that what will happen is that there will be nowhere near the uptake of the $80 million. So what is being offered to the lowincome farming community of Australia, to those rightly regarded to be in greatest need, is an illusion. The illusion is that they too can access funds of a substantial order to assist them in repairing their damaged agricultural lands. But the truth is they will be able to do it only if they can find, from the banks or from their own personal resources, the capital to expend in order to draw down that rebate. As I indicated in my remarks previously, it seems highly improbable that that group of farmers whose taxable incomes are below $20,700 can collectively bring forward $240 million of additional capital expenditure. To put that in some context, last year the landcare component drew down some $120 million worth of funding under the Natural Heritage Trust. So, if this program actually draws on the full $80 million, it represents a doubling of farm commitment to landcare that would otherwise have occurred simply through the Natural Heritage Trust but funded by the lowest income earning farmers in Australia. I suspect the mathematics simply does not add up. The other point that I think should be put on the record is that the drawdown is against the Natural Heritage Trust. The Natural Heritage Trust has become the equivalent of the magic pudding to the coalition. Maybe some in the gallery would know the story of The Magic Pudding, one of Australia's most well loved children's tales by C. J. Dennis.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Mr Nehl)Norman Lindsay.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Sorry, Lindsay, of course. But the pudding was available to be cut and come again. It was the mythical magic political solution where you could carve off a slice and then have another one from whence you carved the first. The magic pudding's political equivalent has become the Natural Heritage Trust. What was once touted as the most significant commitment to the environment and landcare in this nation's history has become debauched. It has become debauched for three reasons. Firstly, it has become debauched because of the manner of its administration. I do not want to retail here what I have retailed at length previously about the way in which nine out of every $10 that have thus far been expended in the early rounds of the fund went to coalition held seats. I do not need to retail how the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) intervened personally to overturn the recommendations provided to him by the so-called independent advisory bodies that were set up in each of the states and territories. I do not need to address all the issues which go to the political rorting of the scheme. Those are clearly on the public record. But what I do want to say is that there are further reasons why one should regard the scheme as having been thoroughly debauched. The second reason to regard the scheme as thoroughly debauched is that one of the clear commitments of this government prior to the introduction of the trust was that it would be supplementary to the forward estimates of the Labor governmerit. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave his absolute guarantee that not one dollar of those forward estimates would be removed. Of course, we know from the budget figures that that was simply a misleading and untruthful statement. What has occurred is that the forward estimates that apply to both expenditure through the Department of the Environment for recurrent environmental expenditure and expenditure in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy have been reduced. So the value of the Natural Heritage Trust has been substantially diminished and funding withdrawn to apply to the normal recurrent purposes of the department, quite contrary to the pledges made to the Australian people when the Prime Minister went to the Sherbrooke Forest and set out on this misleading and deceitful course of conduct. The third point that is important to realise is that not only have the recurrent expenditures of the government been reduced but the fund has been drawn on to meet expenditures which would have normally come as special appropriations. For example, in my own state of Tasmania, where does the funding for the reservation of private forest lands which were associated with the regional forest agreements come from? It certainly was not provided for in the budget. It comes out of the Natural Heritage Trust. When you go up to Cape York and look at the CYPLUS agreement negotiated by the former Labor government, it cannot go ahead because this present government will not commit itself to it as a result of the intransienvironment gence of Borbidge. But some of the environmental concerns are to be addressed where from? Not from general expenditure in the forward estimates as we had-no, another steal from the Natural Heritage Trust. Tonight we see yet a further steal from the Natural Heritage Trust. We find that the fund has been reduced by $80 million to fund this tax initiative. Where else do you find a tax initiative being funded from a trust? You find that where people are deceitful and misleading. You find it when they say one thing before their election and do another afterwards. This government lacks all credibility now. It politically rorted the Natural Heritage Trust fund, it misled the Australian public that it would not diminish the commitment into the forward estimates put forward by the former Labor government, it has stolen tranches of money to meet the proper commitments of government in the normal course of their business from the fund and now it is meeting its revenue shortfall on the tax side by another bite into the Natural Heritage Trust. What we see in this measure is a good, well-crafted idea being debauched by two things: firstly, an overestimate of the number of beneficiaries, a misleading impression being left with the farming community that they will be able to draw down on this to their economic benefit when plainly those low income farmers will be struggling to meet the capital costs of moving into these fields. This, therefore, is unlikely to be as accessible to them as they would anticipate. It is the same kind of misleading that occurred with the farm retirement scheme. That is the first area where the Australian public are being set up for disappointment. The second reason is that it is just part of another process of using the Natural Heritage Trust as the magic pudding, which seems to be sliced and sliced again as if it keeps going. It does not keep going. It just means that the trust's real value to the Australian community is diminished. What was put forward to the Australian community as the most important and principled commitment of an Australian government to land repair and to management of the has now stumbled into ignominy. When you have the Australian Conservation Foundation and groups right across Australia now speaking out about the appalling environmental record of this government, the Natural Heritage Trust no longer gives any cover. It has no credibility, and the failure of its credibility is sheeted home to this government that has so abused the confidence of the Australian public by deceitfully cheating on the three key underlying principles that they pledged before the last election with respect to that trust. This is a government that deserves no trust. This is a government that has forfeited the right to trust. This is a government whose Prime Minister lacks any trust from the Australian community. This is a government whose funding of this tax arrangement would normally come straight from general revenue. If any of the opposition members who are cheerfully smiling can point to any other example where an appropriation of this nature has come from a specific appropriation of money, they are welcome to tell me. But no, all those nice members interjecting opposite are hypocrites because they cannot. The environment suffers as a consequence. The opposition is happy to support this measure. It will help some low income farmers, but certainly not the numbers the government holds out the promise to, and at the cost of direct funding expenditure, the debauching of the Natural Heritage Trust, because of that squandering of the opportunity that was offered to the Australian community by the Prime Minister at the last election. (Time expired) Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned. NA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being to.30 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Health System: Tasmania

Speaker: Mr QUICK
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: We have heard so much in the last few weeks about what is happening to our health system, and I would like to read a letter into Hansard to reflect what is happening to the health system in Tasmania. It reads: Dear Mr Harry Quick I am writing in regards of this so-called Health System you parliamentary people all seem to have your finger in. Well I'm here to tell you it stinks. By my writing this letter it probably won't make an ounce of difference but at least you know how us average low income people are treated and expected to live, like second class citizens. The RSPCA don't treat animals like this. I am 22 years old, married and have three children. They are aged three and a half, two and a half and three months. I recently went to my GP about this terrible pain I had been experiencing. He told me after several tests I had Gall stones. So then being referred to a surgeon who is meant to be the best. He tells me I need my gallstones removed but because of my age they would take the gallbladder out too. But there is approximately a 3 year waiting list to have this surgery performed at the Royal Hobart Hospital. Basically, he told me that unless I could pay just under $2000 to have this done or had private health cover I would just have to sit and wait. These people with private health cover or $2000 would have priority over me. With stupid recommendations of stay away from fatty foods. So I stuck to a strict diet of fruit and veges-five small meals a day. Guaranteed they couldn't Anyway, Monday 25th May I started experiencing terrible pain and put up with it knowing of this waiting list and the surgeon's attitude. Tuesday it was worse, so I rang him. He told me to go to the clinic between 9.30 and 10.00 am. When I arrived, after the usual wait, I was told to eat as I should There wasn't anything they could do, I wasn't the only one in pain nor was I the only one on this waiting list. Wednesday, 27th May: the pain is just so bad I am nearly doubled over and went to Accidents, Emergency at Royal Hobart Hospital. Not many questions asked but was I down for surgery? What had I eaten all day? My reply: one banana. They gave me a shot of pethidine and sent me home. Thursday 28th: suffered all day again in terrible pain till I couldn't take any more and back to Royal Hobart Hospital. Again after a four hour wait a shot of pethidine, no questions asked and back home. Friday 29th: arrived at Royal Hohart Hospital at approximately 10 am to sit in a waiting room for four hours in terrible pain after being called in and sat in a cubicle for a couple more hours. They prodded and poked, took me for ultrasound, took blood, offered me more pethidine which I rejected. After all this to be sent home being told even though I have suffered for a whole week I wouldn't be entitled to surgery, nor will I be moved up the list and if I come back they will admit me for drug relief. So here it is, Monday, 1st June, seven days later and I am at home in terrible pain, with recommendations of taking Panamax every four hours. Now tell me, animals don't suffer like this-why should I? And I'm damn sure you big nabs wouldn't have to suffer like this. With three children I am not capable of looking after what do I do? It's no good going to the Royal. Go in there with gall stones and come out a drug addict. I am no different than these people with good jobs, on private health cover Just because I am unemployed I have to suffer. Where's the justice! So much for this so-called Health System. I don't really know what your job is, but aren't you there for the people of Gagebrook, Bridgewater. I shouldn't have to suffer any more just because 1'm not one of the more fortunate people with money. How can they deny me this operation for anything up to three years? And to top it all off the bloody nurses are on strike-fabulous health system. Whoever has done this to the system needs shooting, they shouldn't be able to play with people's lives like this. Hal What a life mine is, spent in bed the majority of the time. Please, what can you do to help? I'm desperate. By the way, in three weeks, through not being able to eat, I've lost seven kilograms. What willi be like in three years? Yours sincerely live like this. Kaylene Sturzaker. And she is not the only one. You might laugh across the road, but these are real people. The health system in Tasmania is in crisis and something needs to be done instead of all the political grandstanding by all people in this House, on both sides of the House, because people like Kaylene are suffering. Wool Industry School Visit

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Today is the 201st anniversary of the landing of the first merinos on Australian and, like some other members, I have got a symbol of the wool industry here on my lapel to celebrate that event. As a former wool grower of Corriedale sheep, well known for their meat and lustrous 25to 30-micron wool, I have been very much part of this industry. There has been some confusion about the original importer, John Macarthur. His wife did much of the work with the original merino. He had certain roguish tendencies. My forebears were free settlers from Scotland. I would like to get that clearly on the record here in the parliament. But 3 June 1998 is a much more important occasion because we have in the gallery students from the schools of Lethbridge, Inverleigh, Meredith, Shelford, Anakie and B atesford, from the heartland of Corangamite, the premier wool growing area of Australia. The students are here to see the parliament action, and they have seen some quite lively performances, both this evening and yesterRiver, day. They have visited the High Court. They have visited the House of Representatives. They have seen it in its usual active state nobody there. They have seen the Japanese embassy and they have seen the Science and Technology Museum. Members will be interested to know that students had a mock parliament at Meredith where real democracy was in action, major until 1972. issues were discussed and there was grassroots debating. The member for Corangamite was appointed Speaker without debate, the legislation before the House was 'No food to be consumed at the school'. The government had a view: they were against junk food being consumed. The Prime lot Minister was appointed-Rebecca Smith, after a party room count. Sam Toulmin was apoffice pointed opposition leader. Strong speeches were made and there were a lot of interjecof tions. No suspensions were undertaken by the Speaker and the Speaker was totally in congamite. trol. I wish to draw to the House's attention that these young students started to behave like members of the House of Representatives. The doors were locked, a vote was taken and the majority was on the government side. soil Opinions were expressed on both sides about the value of the debate, and there was some concern that some members on the opposition side were supporting the government. That does not happen in this place. There was a heated debate about the local issues, and they understood that it is a privilege here in Australia to debate matters freely-unlike in Indonesia where troops, guns, nepotism and corruption have been the order of the day. Lethbridge is a very fine little village--{)ver 100 years old-in the Golden Plains Shire halfway between Bannockburn and Meredith. Inverleigh has a background in sheep and crops and is based on the Barwon River on the Hamilton Highway. MCConachy's Family Store is also the local post office. Shelford is the centre of a top merino woolgrowing area. Anakie is near the You Yangs in the seat of Corio and the member for Corio in (Mr O'Connor) is the member representing that group. Batesford is on the Moorabool and Meredith is the centre of a fine wool-growing area. It has a great number of rabbit popUlations and increasing blue gum with plantations, which the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who is at the table, would not understand. He has no understanding of matters like blue gum populations. Meredith the was the ho-e of Sir Henry Bolte, who was the Liberal Premier of Victoria from 1975 I thank the teachers who have helped bring the students here to Canberra: Rob Lamond and from Lethbridge, Debra Stavenuiter from junk Inverleigh, Erica Baulch from Meredith, Michael Kinnane from Meredith and John Tantau from Lethbridge. They have given a of time, devotion and enthusiasm to this event. The students have been in the whip's and they now have a clear understanding of democracy at work here in the House Representatives. There may be a future Prime Minister from the heartland of CoranThey can see the freedom with which big issues are debated here, although the honourable member for Denison does not fully understand the issues of land care and the allocation of funds. As I said, the students understand the freedom that we have to debate-not at the point of a gun like in the Middle East, Cambodia or Indonesia. (Time expired) School Visit

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: On indulgence, on behalf of the opposition, I extend the same welcome to your constituents and I wish them and you well.

Speaker: Mr SERCOMBE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to raise a matter which I believe is most serious within the portfolio of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). It concerns what I understand to be the letting by Come are of a contract without competitive tender, at a price of $600,000, to a Chicago based American company called AON Corporation. I am advised that the contract has been let to gather information from every government entity with respect to their insurance requirements. From the nature of the information being sought, it would seem that an attempt is being made to change the direction of Comcare from a purely workers compensation based corporation into a form of captive insurance company dealing with every class of insurance. Obviously AON, being a commercial broker, will have a significant advantage over other competitive brokers, even if they do allow competition, having been instrumental in gathering the information together and having met with every government entity. The effect of this, if it occurs, will be to remove many millions of dollars from the Australian insurance industry, giving it to Comcare and then presumably into the hands of international reinsurance companies, unless the government is going to put significant additional capital into Comcare. The consultancy and the advice would be wholly at the behest of 100 per cent offshore-owned entities. The potential for further losses of Australian jobs in the insurance industry is very real and many of those have disappeared in the last few years. As I indicated at the outset, my principal concern at this stage is that a contract of this scale could have been let by an organisation within the administration of the minister, without a competitive tender. I am also concerned that, without adequate investigation from independent expertise, the possibility of forming an all classes captive insurance company is being considered. It seems to me that, if this information is correct, it is an extraordinary breach of the minister's responsibilities in respect of his areas of administration, and I call on him, using this forum, to give a full explanation to Comcare the House. Violence in the Media

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight to speak on an issue for which I have grave concerns and which I feel very strongly about: the ever-pervading violence portrayed in the media, film, video games and the music industry within our society and which our children and young people are SUbjected to. Tonight I would like to refer to an article in yesterday's Australian by Ruth Ostrow, entitled 'Proof of pleasure positive is in the viewing'. In this article Ms Ostrow outlines the concern she has for her daughter who, at the age of four, is already shooting down her dollies with a make-believe gunher plastic Mr Banana shampoo bottle-while in the bathtub. I certainly do share with her those concerns. Ruth Ostrow makes comments about consenting adults, which she is entitled to, of course, but I would like to point out that we, as parents, must be ever vigilant as to what our children are exposed to and what we think is appropriate to be produced for entertainment. I would be most concerned if my four-yearold son were shooting at make-believe objects or if he were to be accidentally exposed to one of the sex shows on the radio or television, either in the car while strapped into his safety seat with the radio tuned to the wrong station or at home watching TV unsupervised. I would be absolutely mortified and paralysed at the bathroom door if a four-year-old son of mine, while playing in the bathtub, decided to demonstrate sexual techniques to his dolly with his Mr Banana shampoo bottle or if I overheard him discussing with his kindy mates the advantages of multiple orgasms for women bound in leather. All of these, as some suggest, are truths about sexuality-and sex, as does violence, sells. For instance, a few years ago the publishers of the basketball magazine Jamming published pornography in the magazine that sixand seven-year-olds purchase. I hope that my sons are not exposed in such a manner and that they respect women and grow up not to laugh at or degrade them but to have a wonderful, meaning and loving relationship with the women that they love. So, consenting adults, please by all means do what you like in the privacy of your own home-not in public nor in front of the children-whether it be sex or violence. Having said that, I am not surprised that, at the tender age of four, Ruth Ostrow's daughter is already trying to shoot and kill-in make-believe, of course. A cartoon I watched many years ago with my children while in the lounge room was a sadistic, violent portrayal of the Three Bears. Daddy Bear was continually verbally abusing Baby Bear, calling him stupid, dumb, useless, hopeless and no good while at the same time beating him around the head and body with a four-by-four, laughing all the time. It made me feel sick to the stomach to watch, so I turned it off so my children did not have to see it. When I rang the manager of the television station to complain, all he did, in an amused manner, was to tell me to switch it off if I did not like it. I remarked, 'That is fine for me, but what about children who aren't lucky enough to have their parent or caregiver sitting down watching with them?' His response was, 'It's only a cartoon.' My grave concern about the level of violence in the media and violence generally is the effect that it can have on our young people. Young people are our future. They hold the key to the future of Australia and the world. Many are generally very optimistic, vibrant and live life to the fullest. In an earlier speech on youth suicide, I stated that for some, however, the world seems to offer little hope or enjoyment and that many look for an escape, which is often death. Youth suicide is a tremendous problem in Australia. The growing prevalence of violence in the media and on film suggests that violence is the way to solve problems and recent research suggests that a continuing stream of violence desensitises us as a society. I have previously remarked on comments by my eldest son, who at the time was 14 years old. He asked me whether you could die if you had coke poured in your ears. When I asked why he would want to know whether that was a way to die, his answer was that he had been listening to some music on the radio and the lyrics of a song were listing lots of different ways to commit suicide. Of concern to me is that not only do we have a diet of enforced violence portrayed constantly on our televisions and video games for even very young children through to adolescents but also our adolescents are constantly bombarded with violent and sadistic role models within the music industry. Our society has a problem when games such as Mortal Combat, where the object of the game is to kill, destroy and maim in the most gruesome manner possible, are produced for entertainment. Or there is the game, Harvest, whereby you get the highest number of points for killing little innocent babies. In addition, we have the Necromunda Gangers game, whereby the object of the game is to kill and maim and to collect as many weapons-such as knives, grenades, pistols and guns-as one can for extra points. So what are we, as a community and a society, teaching our children? (Time expired) Pork Industry Indigenous Rights

Speaker: Ms HANSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Today in the House I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when he was going to intervene to save the Australian pork industry. This industry is mostly made up of family farms and is perhaps one of the best examples of Australian farming as a small business. Unfortunately the years of hard work, personal and financial commitment and dogged determination have suffered at the hands of uncaring government policy. This industry is currently being devastated by subsidised pig meat from Canada and, although it is clear the Howard government has the power to save this industry and the many Australian families reliant on its survival, it appears the government will not intervene. A study by the University of Queensland makes it clear foreign imports are destroying the Australian pork industry. It is equally clear the Howard government has the right, under article 19 of the World Trade Organisation Agreement, to suspend imports because of the demonstrable damage being done to this industry. When I asked the Prime Minister about this issue, his answer was one that would have given cold comfort to the dreadfully insecure families of pork farmers across Australia. The sacrifice of the pork industry on the altar of free trade is just one example. This international agenda must stop, and stop now. I call on the Howard government to reverse the rural decline and unemployment it is helping to sponsor. Tonight on A Current Affair, I would have thought Ray Martin would have been professional enough to divorce himself from the bias you would expect from his close links with the Aboriginal industry and those who discredit decent Aboriginal Australians with their obvious and grubby grab for money. I was wrong. As I have said, the real objective is not reconciliation but remuneration. On the subject of the dreadfully dangerous draft declaration of the rights of indigenous people and my parallel of the plans for Australia and the Canadian experience with Nunavut, I was somewhat taken aback that the indigenous nature of Nunavut could possibly be questioned. If Ray Martin has some communication from the Canadian government denying the true nature of Nunavut, then I suggest the people of this indigenous state are at odds with the Canadian government. Any doubt of this position can be clarified by simply turning to the Internet and typing in the address for Nunavut. My staff will happily make this address available to anyone interested in the truth-or at least the truth according to the people of Nunavut. Here is an example of what you will find: In 1999, the Inuit of the Nunavut area of Canada's Arctic will take on the responsibility of managing their own affairs, and those of the non-Inuit also living there. It certainly sounds like the Inuit Eskimos are clear on where they stand. Does Ray Martin seriously believe the Canadian government just carved out 350,000 square kilometres of freehold land for just 24,000 people just for the fun of it? As for Mr Jull, his involvement in these matters is also hard to deny, considering even just these snippets of available information: he was the research director of the Nunavut constitutional forum which negotiated the establishment of Nunavut; his work in the Office of Indigenous Affairs in Queensland; his association with the North Australian Research Unit; and the obvious use of his work by the Cape York Land Council. At the very least, Mr Jull's work has been the blueprint for the Aboriginal industry's plans for an indigenous state in Australia. There is much more, but this at least is enough to question the value of negotiating the draft declaration of the rights of indigenous people and its ramifications for other Australians. Suine, Mr Lui: Condolence

Speaker: Mr HICKS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Some members may recall that in May last year I paid tribute to two friends of mine, Lui and Terese Suine of Griffith, who were at that time celebrating 65 years of devoted marriage. Earlier in that year Lui had celebrated 70 years of life in Australia, having come to this country in 1927. As I said in the House at that time, Lui and Terese were typical of those Italian migrants who have come to Australia over the years and helped make it the great nation it is today. Lui and Terese Suine's contribution was made in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and one of Lui's proud statements was that there were only three months of his life in Australia in which he could not find work and these included the years of the Great Depression. Lui and Terese were born in Cavaso in the beautiful Veneto region of northern Italy, not far from the city of Venice. They were married in Griffith in 1932 and the happy result for Australia was five children, 18 grandchildren and more than 20 great-grandchildren. I admired and respected the Suines and was deeply saddened when Terese passed away nearly nine months ago. The last nine months, to say the least, have been difficult for Lui. With the support of his lovely family he has tried to get on with his life and care for himself and his small dog, a terrier named Jemma. It is with sadness that I now inform the House that in the eady hours of last Friday Lui passed away in his sleep and has now rejoined his beloved Terese. It was fitting that this great Australian of Italian heritage was buried yesterday, on the Italian national day. I offer my condolences to the extended Suine family and with them thank God for the lives of Lui and Terese who contributed so much to the Riverina region in which I live and to this nation.

Speaker: Mrs WEST
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight to speak on a subject portrayed daily by the media. All ages and stages of our human race can be victims of its effect. It has crept into everyday life and in some ways is an integral feature of our everyday existence. If we are not affected by it ourselves, we know of others who have been affected by it personally and physically. We read about it, we see it on television, we hear about it, we talk about it and many actually carry it out. The subject to which I refer, of course, is violence. We recognise violence as socially unacceptable behaviour. Perpetrators end up in courts, gaol or die as a result of violent acts. Victims of violence lead a changed life, suffer consequentially for their part in the and life is never, ever the same. r talk here generally about physical violence. It has become a feature of our daily entertainment and it is this aspect of the entertainment industry that I believe is doing our society a great injustice. Obviously, we do not have everybody out there in the streets committing violent acts. The majority of people in our community are not violent and show restraint and self-control when it comes to choosing the appropriate action and reaction to situations.
