What I am concerned about is the unrestricted diet of violence our children have foisted on them from the day their parents realise television can become the primary ehildminding tool. The seemingly harmless images of cartoons reinforce in a child's mind the painle.o;s depiction of violence: it is only pretend; it docs not really hurt. It is worse where children view the videos hired by their parents rated R, Restricted, and M, Mature Audiences Only, which they are technically not supposed to view but in the confines of their family home do view, with parents not realising the consequences. This is not a call for blanket censorship of those videos but a plea to parents to realise that they are responsible for their children and ultimately for ensuring their children's minds are not affected by intrusive acts of violence that are totally unnecessary and may lead to Violence disturbing psychoses. We have seen the effects of such a continued diet of violent entertainment in recent weeks-with realHfe examples of young killers who perpetrate violent acts with tragic circumstances. When you read the details, the effect is quite sickening-that a young person's life can be treated with such insensitivity and dispassion by others who are usually the same age or not much older. Police have revealed that they often find violent videos in the homes of criminals. It raises a question or two. Who's next? And why did they do this? Parents need to monitor what their children watch as entertainment. Parents also really need to reflect on their own personal choice of violence as a form of entertainment. Actors in films that depict such violent behavioursact and I mean the really graphic scenes-should also consider their part in this whole cultural acceptance of violence as a form of entertainment. There are a couple of films out now that portray violence against women. While there is not the usual blood and guts or gratuitous violence, they almost re-enact criminal acts committed in real life. We all know the famous saying 'We are what we eat'. Let us take that a step further by considering that we may become what we watch, and act accordingly. If we are fed a diet of television and violence, there is no telling what we are to become. Tasmania: Federation Fund

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Denison) (10.58 p.m.)Tonight I want to say a few words about a project in my own state of Tasmania which, unfortunately, has not been graced with any favours from this government. The project is a proposal for the construction of an AFL stadium. It has been advanced by a consortium which includes the business community and a union superannuation fund through the C+BUS scheme, so it would have suhstantial community support and the support of the Tasmanian government. It has been put forward for funding under the Centenary of Federation arrangements. Regrettably, although more than half the $1 billion that has been promised from the Centenary of Federation Fund had been thus far committed, not one dollar other than the amounts that have been allocated per electorate-that is, the $200,000 per federal member-has yet been allocated to Tasmania. That contrasts with other states where every other state has received a very significant benefit. The cruelest blow was dealt on the weekend when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) went to the marginal Liberal seat of Robertson and announced that the federal government would be making a $12 million contribution to a mUlti-purpose stadium-virtually the mirror image of the AFL stadium proposal in Tasmania. It is a cruel blow because New South Wales is actually in the middle of a building boom. It is going to be hosting the Olympics. There are enormous construction projects under way. My own state is the most economically disadvantaged at the present time. There is no building boom under way. In fact, construction workers are languishing for want of work. The failure of the present Prime Minister even to receive a delegation from those putting forward the proposal when he can travel to Robertson and hand out $12 million is a matter of grave regret. Question resolved in the affirmative. Main Committee adjourned at 10.16 p.m. REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMI'ITEE The following answers to questions were circulated: Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Does the midyear economic review released on 18 December 1997 contain a forecast growth in employment in 1997-98 of 1.25 per cent revised from the 2 per cent stated in the 1997-98 Budget but retain the forecast for the unemployment rate of 8 per cent; if so, how can the figures be reconciled. (2) Does the review contain forecasts that the unemployment rate will fall below 8 per cent in 1998-99 and that economic growth will fall from 3.75 per cent in 1997-98 to 3.25 per cent in 1998-99. (3) Is it a fact that economic growth of 4 per cent or more is needed to reduce unemployment; if so, how can the forecasts referred to in part (2) be reconciled. Mr Costello--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) In the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook (MYEFO), the Budget forecast for year average employment growth in 1997-98 was revised from 2 per cent to PA per cent, reflecting the weaker than anticipated outcome in the June quarter 1997. Forecast employment growth over the year to June 1998 was unchanged li'om the Budget at 2% per cent. Given monthly unemployment outcomes and no change in the forecast for employment growth during 1997-98, there was no change to the Budget forecast for an 8 per cent unemployment rate in the June quarter 1998. (2) The MYEFO did not publish a forecast for the unemployment rate in 1998-99. A full set of forecasts for 1998-99 is contained in the May 1998 Budget. (3) There is no unique rate of economic growth required to produce falls in the unemployment rate, since movements in the latter will be equally dependent on population growth and labour force participation. Residential Care Allowance: Changes , Mr Sawford asked the Minister representing the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) How many persons are affected by changes associated with the introduction of the residential care allowance and the removal of rent assistance for nursing NA Economic Review home residents consequently no longer able to claim the payment as a taxation rebate for medical expenses. (Question No. 2653) (2) What is the estimated saving to the Commonwealth from the measure for 1997-98. Mr Costello--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) From 1 January 1997 until 30 September 1997, pensioners living in nursing homes were eligible for Residential Care Allowance (RCA), with the rates and eligibility the same as for rent assistance. From 1 October 1997, RCA was replaced with the pensioner supplement, paid directly to service providers. This change affected all nursing home pensioner residents. The total number of nursing home residents for September 1997 averaged 71,326, of which around 90 per cent are estimated to be pensioners. Also, from 1 October 1997, the basic daily care fee for pensioner nursing home residents was reduced (from 87.5 per cent of basic age pension plus RCA to 85 per cent of basic age pension) to compensate for the loss of RCA. As income, RCA was not an expense, and as such the RCA payment itself could not be claimed under the medical expenses rebate. Only qualifying expenses can be claimed under the medical expenses rebate. It is not possible to estimate resident numbers who used their RCA to pay their fees and who claimed their nursing home expenses under the medical expenses rebate. However, this number would be small. Most residents who previously received RCA are full rate pensioners, and therefore have no tax liability from which to offset the medical expenses rebate. (2) RCA was abolished from 1 October 1997, with both the basic daily care fee for nursing home residents reduced, and the replacement pensioner supplement introduced, as compensation. Australian Service Medal (Question No. 2695) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister (Question No. 2684) for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Will ex-servicemen with 30 days continuous service in an operational area be eligible to receive the Australian Service Medal 1945-75. (2) Has Naval Personnel Services advised a number of ex-servicemen that they would be eligible for the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 Clasp Minesweeping; if so, how many veterans received the advice. (1) Has the clasp been formally gazetted; if so, when; if not, how will the veterans be recognised. Mrs Bishop-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1 ) Yes. If the area is prescribed for the purpose of an award of the Australian Service Medal 1945-75. (2) Yes. Some 40 veterans were advised that the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with Clasp 'Minesweeping' would be awarded. This included the then President of the Returned and Services League of Australia, Major General James, in December 1996. (3) A Clasp 'Mines weeping' will not be formally gazetted. However, eligibility for the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with Clasp'S W Pacific' to include minesweeping activities and bomb and mine clearance duties has been extended to include those eligible personnel. A formal Instrument of declaration and determination was approved by the Governor General on 16 April 1998. I refer the honourable member to my Media Release of 24 April 1998 which states, quote: "Approval to extend the provisions for eligibility of the award of the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 with Clasp'S W Pacific' was announced by the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, Bronwyn Bishop MP. "I am delighted to announce that recognition can now be given to those Australian Defence personnel who undertook minesweeping and bomb and mine clearance duties after World War II and missed out on an Imperial Naval General Service Medal or General Service Medal at the time," said Mrs Bishop. "These Imperial awards which provided recognition could only be earned if 180 days qualifying service was rendered. It is this Government's policy that certain service of 30 days or more should attract the Australian Service Medal 1945-75. Those who did qualify for an Imperial award for mines weeping and bomb and mine clearance duties, however, will not be entitled to the Australian Service Medal 1945-75 in recognition of those duties." Mrs Bishop said that the extension of eligibility resulted from a review carried out by the Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Honours and Awards, which consists of representatives from Government House, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The review identified that duties carried out in the South West Pacific were comparable to those of the British Occupation Forces in Japan which consisted of a wide range of duties, including minesweeping and bomb and mine clearance. Accordingly, those Service personnel who served in the Netherlands Indies, Portuguese Timor, Moratai Island, Sarawak, Brunei, British Borneo, Philippine Islands, Solomon Islands, Nauru and Ocean Islands, Burma, Malaya, Singapore, the Queensland coast and waters off the coast of China and the South West Pacific, for varying periods between from 3 September 1945 to 10 November 1956, will be eligible. The medal will be awarded for 30 days continuous service during the eligibility periods." unquote.
